title: Funny, Sad, and a little bit of things inbetween
text:
Finn is 12. His father has passed away, and now he feels as if he is turning invisible. Thats the basic premise, but the book soon shifts into what Finn is feeling, what his thoughts are, how he continues to live his life.
The prose is sparse and the illustrations add just the right amount of distraction and charm, making it a bit more plausible that you could be reading a book written by a tween. While not really a chronicle of the events that led up to his fathers death, this book serves as more of a journal for Finn, a place for him to express what is running through his head and heart.
Finn is a quirky young man, interested in the meaning of names, odd facts about bugs, and sharp observations on his feelings, his friend Melani, and how his brother and mom are plodding along after so much has changed.
The author has nailed the mindset of a greiving tween head on, and I have a new respect for those kids caught in the aftermath of a parents death, desertion, or even divorce. Finn goes through the stages of grief and comes to a realization at the end of the novel that is fitting and brings home the point of why Finn likes what names mean and how its interestig to collect those little nuggets of wisdom.
A book that is well done, but does have a bit of lag time in the middle. Thankfully, Finn gives us his permission to set the book aside and pick it up later when you feel like it. Its as if the author knew reading a book about a fatherless 12 year old could get heavy..he provided a way for us to break and digest before coming back to finish.
A good book for those who are wanting a bit of insight on grief, how tweens deal, and how ones own child might act if something terrible were to happen. (Minus the "Im-turning-invisible" part of course)

title: Dissappointing, considering the hype
text:
What a huge dissappointment! I found the book extremely boring. Maybe I've been spoiled by the recent fantasy/sf I've been reading, but I found the plot very slow moving, and generally uninteresting and uninvolving. I also disliked the extreme amount of humor and satire in this book. I prefer my novels to be more realistic. I like adult situations (complex relationships, betrayal, violence, etc), and I couldn't find any here. It felt as if I was watching one LONG episode of Futurama.
There were good things, however. The book was extremely short. I got through it in one sitting (about three hours), and I don't think I've ever done that before. Also, I found the book slightly humorous in parts, which served to barely keep my interest for that 3-hour reading stretch.

title: Bloom's Tribute to His Own Philosophy
text:
Bloom's books on Shakespeare are embarrassing. He does not bother to actually analyze lines from the plays under discussion, but rather makes achingly abstract pronouncements - anyone who could write without a trace of irony that "Shakespeare is God and the only God" cannot be treated seriously.
This book is less about Stevens than it is Bloom strutting his philosophical stuff. To note that Stevens is more Whitmanesque than Shelleyan in a particular poem is not a substitute for close analysis of the poem itself. His faux exegesis of "Sunday Morning" misses the point entirely. Instead of explicating the poem carefully Mr Bloom spouts out Platonic philosophy, failing of course to connect it to the poem itself. Because, you see, a close consideration of Stevens' poetry is not Bloom's goal. He's been writing the same book under different titles since the 1970s. He's lost in his own hall of mirrors narcissitically aping himself.
Anyone wishing for a fine book on Stevens' should hunt down the two texts by Helen Vendler, a critic whose only agenda is to bring the meaning of the poetry to light.

title: I got a refund
text: I was so looking forward to this book, as I am a huge Michael Connelly fan and I've read all of the Lincoln Lawyer, Bosch and Jack McEvoy books.  I purchased the Kindle version of this, unfortunately before I read the reviews.  After reading the reviews, I "returned" the book for a refund.  I don't want politics mingled in with my fiction.  Especially current ones.  I don't appreciate being called names for my political beliefs just because someone else doesn't agree.  This has made me sad and angry.  A fiction novel has no business commenting on current politics and I'm offended.  Mr. Connelly has lost another reader and I will make sure my friends and family never purchase or read another of his books.

text:
This book was okay. Not terrible but not great either. We were looking for fun Halloween books to read to our one year old and decided upon this one.

***Spoiler***It's about a witch who grows a very big pumpkin and then can't pick it. A few different Halloween characters stop by to help her. It finishes with everyone eating pumpkin pie. It's a cute plot idea but the story was just so-so.

text: Typical Harry Bosch!

title: 6 yr old loved the book!
text:
Bought this for a 6 yr old and she loved it!, especially the journey of the tree through the seasons and the apple pie recipe at the end, that family gave it 5 stars. My son would have considered this book ok though, I don't think he would have fallen in love with it, he read another apple theme book as a toddler, meant for slightly younger kids, that he loves. The plus point of this book is that it covers a lot of information subtly-the life cycle of an apple tree along with a side track of a robin family nesting on it. Like some of the reviewers, I too feel that the illustrations could have been better (they are kind of colorful but could have been cuter, with more fall colors while showing that season), and I also feel that apart from being very informative, the language could have been more engaging to read. I reduced the 2 stars for the average illustrations and the bland writing style, still worth a buy if you find it cheap(used copies), for the wealth of information it gives within the simple story. The book is too pricey brand new so I got a used one.
Recommended age 4-7 yrs. Below 4 yrs is definitely too young to actually notice and understand all the processes this book teaches. Go for a simpler apple book if it is for a toddler below 4.

title: Too neat
text: I may be overly critical, but this story was just too typical.  Strong female lead who overcomes; all the good guys win in the end; and of course, the corporate lawyer is guilty.

title: Horrifyingly amateur work
text: I think that the overall idea Mr. Metzger is attempting to acheive is fascinating, however the way he opts to implement his story is unyielding and grating.  First, there are far too many asides in the novel to explain in one sentence some fundamental law of physics.  Being a scientist, I found rather irritating, as the summaries were glib, and intended to have a hand waving effect to make the scene plausible.  Second, the character development is remarkably bad.  Most of the characters have one of three major personality quirks: Domineering, histrionic, or obsessive-compulsive.  There is very little (if any) depth given to any of the characters.  Third: The plot.....??? I like my science fiction to be more science than fiction, but that's a personal choice.  All in all, not worth the time. At all.  It gets a two star rating for having an idea I would like to see used in a much better novel.

title: Really Old Cookbook
text: Not a good bargain at all unless the 1984 edition becomes valuable.  I should have shopped better.  It may go to Goodwill some day.

title: Underwhelmed after reading so many great reviews
text: I was unfamiliar with Rachel prior to reading this book.  It was recommended from another purchase I made on Amazon and the reviews are so great!  I was underwhelmed by this book because I felt like I got nothing out of it.  I love motivational content that reinforces how strong, powerful, and capable women and entrepreneurs can be but the book is mainly Rachel's personal stories as evidence of those motivational concepts.  I admire how open and honest she is about her personal life but it wasn't worth the cost of the book to read.  Since I wasn't familiar with Rachel prior to this book I did not realize how much religion is a part of her brand.  I'm not disappointed or upset with her brand and how she presents herself, but I don't tend to agree with the idea that a Creator leads people to the right paths and decisions about their lives and businesses.  Rachel brings up points like that several times in the book.  If you are a non-religious entrepreneur looking for encouragement and motivation to pursue your goals and be more confident about yourself you may be unsatisfied with this book since many of the stories lean heavily on religious beliefs.  I thought it was well written, a fast read, and upbeat.  Just not a book I wound up getting much out of.

But for such a small book you have way too many characters and somewhere in the middle you just get lost. title: not smart
text: Despite the title of this book, Betsy is not a smart girl. She may have better grammar than the people she works with, she may even be more intelligent than most of them, but she gives little evidence of actually being smart. She spends the bulk of the book being snippy about her best friend's upcoming wedding (to the point that if she were my maid of honor, I would have fired her!) and obsessing about her juvenile relationship with her maybe-boyfriend. At the end of the book she has the predictable revelation about her life and her relationships and the true meaning of being happy, but she spent so much of the book acting like an idiot that I couldn't really bring myself to care.

title: Overhyped
text: After reading The Wide, Carnivorous Sky and Other Geographies (a collection of short stories) and this novel, my honest assessment is that John Langan is a fine writer but I think he tries to force a narrative. The Fisherman is about two coworkers who, after their wives pass, go fishing together routinely. Pretty compelling relationship. Then they go to a diner and the owner starts talking to them and then he tells an urban legend about a nearby lake—a novella’s worth of a tale. And there goes our protagonists. It’s almost as if—and I’m probably not wrong—he wrote the novella first, maybe years before, and then tried to find a way of turning it into a novel. No matter how you spin it, it’s a poorly realized narrative structure, bad pacing, flat characters, and an overused, predictable Pet Sematary plot. Anyway, it started promising but then I (and a goodly portion of Amazon reviewers, for the same exact reason) gradually lost interest and Langan wasn’t intuitive enough to realize this.

title: Overly simplistic, unrealistic
text:
Kiva lives a pampered life as one of the elite in ancient Alexandria. Her former best friend Seth is killed and she is chosen as a companion sacrifice. However, when she wakes on a space station, she is told that she has spent her life in virtual reality and has been chosen to go on a vital mission.

I know that this is a young adult book, but it was just overly simplistic. Kiva only had a slight reaction to being told that her entire life was a lie. For a hormonal teenager, this just did not feel realistic. It made no sense, even with an explanation, that a life or death survival mission would be left up to two 15 year olds. Maybe this book should be marketed to an even younger age group. Overall, a bust.

title: A Hearty Read, but a Bit Chewy
text:
If you're looking for a facts on what cowboys were and were not, this book certainly has them. If you're looking to be carried along by silken prose, you'd be better served looking elsewhere.

What I liked about the book: lots of information. I enjoyed reading about a cowboy's relationship with his horse, and reading actual examples of tombstone inscriptions that were placed on those few horses that made such an impact in life that in death they deserved not only burial but a marker with an inscription. I enjoyed reading the story about the traveler at the train depot hearing good news, and how a nearby group of cowboys - upon overhearing the man's good news - suddenly raised a ruckus simply to help the man celebrate. I enjoyed reading how important a cowboy's hat and saddle were, the detailed descriptions of his gear, his gait, and the physical deformities he suffered from a lifetime riding a horse - even riding a horse, rather than walking, when no more than 200 yards separated the cowboy from his destination.

What I did not like about the book: Most of it reads like this (or worse): "Associated with these men, obedient to their leadership, taking color from them, and so also a factor in formulating the social and political system of the Range were such of the cowboy's fellow employees as, not being cowboys, were therefore of a station more humble than he was." Sentences are unnecessarily cumbersome, and frequently I had to stop and re-read sentences or entire paragraphs in order to get it. I understand the book was written 80 years ago, but I'm not accustomed to reading this style of writing. The author also used quotes excessively. He often made sentences using the words of the time, but he quoted every word which I found very distracting being that it occurred page after page, chapter after chapter. In addition, there's no story here, no evolution of learning, no sense of being carried through time or of having a picture of cowboy life magically painted before your eyes. It read more like a shopping list: Cowboy gear was: item 1, item 2, item 3. Cowboy personality was: item 1, item 2, item 3. And so on.

The bottom line for me was that it was good information but, to be quite honest, I often found it hard to stay awake and generally could only manage half a chapter before I had to put it down and do something else. I felt like I was supposed to be memorizing multiple choice items for a test. It just isn't a thrilling read.

title: Very misleading
text: I thought it was going to be about taking notes with pictures. 90 percent of his notes are written. Feel totally ripped off.

title: A visual book with good ideas!
text: I purchased Out of the Album: Scrapbook and Paper Projects! (Design Originals) by Lisa Vollrath. I bought a used copy and it arrived in beautiful condition.The book is or shall I say booklet  in my opinion,is very thin to start out with. It was also written in 2005 so a lot of the projects have looks that are dated. It does have some reading to it but not much. Out of the Album is more a visual book thus the 3 out of 5 stars.There are some good ideas in it. These days we have templates,die cuts and fancy machines to get our images cut out. The day of the stencils is long gone for cutting out images! The stencil is still great for mixed media projects which they do show some of.I bought this book mainly for inspiration and I did receive some of that. Happy Crafting! L~

title: Save the fox, save the world
text:
This is a story about a mischievous half-fox who promises to protect 1 part of a magic scroll that summons a dragon who will grant the summoner one wish, be it for good or evil.

I liked the idea of the story, but not the execution of it. The mischievous fox would have been such a wonderful and loveable character if she hadn't been so naive and intent on hiding her half-fox nature. I mean... who doesn't know what sarcasm is? Also the super secret spy samurai just did not feel real to me either. The only character I really liked was the “filthy ronin dog” from which all the sarcasm comes from.

Overall the story progression was meandering and yet it felt very predictable at times.

There were some redeeming qualities, though. The sarcastic ronin added some humor to the story. Also, the Japanese language, culture, and folk tales included in the story were fascinating. I've never read another book with all of those elements in it, and they were interesting even when part of the explanations started to feel like reading a text-book.

Finally, I was surprised by the ending and, despite being periodically distracted by staring off into space while reading book 1, I am curious about what will happen in book 2 and I will probably read it.

title: still a hard book to read
text: I purchased this book after purchasing the 2nd edition for my graduate course on translations. If the 2nd edition was bad, this one is slightly better, but it is still a hard book to put into practice. Half of the stuff discussed in this book is not used by professional translators, and it is targeted towards students whose 1st language is English, not Spanish. So for a person like me, taking a Spanish course in translation, the book doesn't work. Unfortunately I don't know if there's a book written in Spanish about this topic, so that's what the professor assigned. (and he's from Spain... go figure!) The student will learn quite a bit of new terms related to the translation business, but that's about it. As a person who has worked on translation for the past five years, I have to say that less than half of what is discussed here is not used in the business. Bottom line: I can't wait to sell this book once the semester is over.

title: Missing entire pages from printing error. It's illegible!
text: Very disappointed. It came missing pages because of printing errors. The print job on this book wasn't done very well because the words are so faded that you can't read it at all. It's illegible.

title: Dissapointing, boring, waste of time
text: I am in two book clubs and I read books when it's NOT book club time. Out of all the wonderful books out there, our book club picked this. Absolutely the biggest waste of time! It wasn't the size that scared me, but it was so "dry". No feeling, no emotions what so ever! So boring, it would put me to sleep. From the very beginning, I felt like it was a very shallow & blah-blah-blah book.....There wasn't a character that I really cared about, except Anna Karenina. ONLY because that is what the title of the book is! The best love-affair ever written, no way! It might have been a scandelous book back in the day, but a total bore. And Levin talking and talking about farming, politics & his religious believes - it was so ridiculous. What got me was Tolstoy would write what the characters are thinking. But when he put in the book what Levin's dog was thinking, I just about threw the book away! Tolstoy NEVER could express emotions in his way of writting on any of these characters. Someone tell me what the big deal is.

title: Aftershock: Protect Yourself and Profit in the Next Global Financial...
text: It is a good book to know how financial world works. It is rigged in favor of big power and money. Book has some guidelines. Just like in the past, there will be fix when another financial storm comes. It  has to be big enough to affect big financial institutions not for an ordinary joe.

title: Disappointing.
text:
Not up to the standards I associate with a Scarpetta story. Basically, we have a look at one day in the life of Kay; one day full of neurosis and paranoia. The characters are flat and lifeless, the plot plods, there is no satisfactory resolution. I'm actually quite surprised by how much I did not enjoy this book. I was looking forward to a fun read about an intelligent woman kicking bum and taking names and I sat down to a whiny, mopey, brat. Lucy has become unbearable, Benton needs to run away, Pete is a caricature. Frankly, the antagonist is the most engaging character via her surveillance flash backs. Cornwell appears to have grown to despise the characters she created.

If you haven't read the preceding series, you will have no clue what is going on.

title: Hard to get into
text: This story had a great story line, but it got lost in a lot of boring monologues. The characters weren't very well developed. At the end of the story I still didn't know much about the main characters, just their circumstances.

title: 3 1/2 Stars - Hit and Miss
text:
Hit and Miss

I went into this book as a player of SWTOR and a fan of the lore. I had modest expectations and in some ways it greatly surpassed them while in others it fell short. I'd like to start with the strongest point of the book though, the main character, Theron Shan.

Theron is a rather interesting main character and he has a unique perspective on the things that take place around him. He has history with the Jedi even though he isn't a force user himself and is knowledgable on their beliefs and practices though he doesnt follow them. Theron displays this by often going from cynical and indulgent about things such as the force to naive and idealistic on matters of state and the war. That being said, this is such a good main character. Regardless of his views on things he is very analytical and is written in a way where you can really understand what he is thinking as he acquires more information. I always thought the Republic SIS (the republic's covert spy and operations network) was underused in the old Republic era lore and this really adds some nice flavor and depth to their agents and operations. That being said, Theron also has a bit of a backstory with Grand Master of the Jedi Satele Shan and Supreme Republic Commander Jace Malcom and this is where it starts to become more of a mixed bag as the story that is included often feels tacked on for dramatic effect or is just awkward.

There are more characters than Theron, Satele, and Jace though, and these characters often feel flat and uninteresting even when you want to feel otherwise. Theron has a female Twilek friend in a criminal gang that he often goes out of his way for and seems to really care for from his youth and his past with the Jedi. However, nothing ever really comes from or changes in
their odd relationship aside from her proving to be a useful contact later in the story. He is also accompanied by Master Gnost Dural whom some will remember from the SWTOR historical archives. He is a typical Jedi Master with the twist of the main villan being his former apprentice. He has little interest in saving her though and the only reason I cared about him was because of him being the same character who narrated the historical archives on the SWTOR website. He does his job as a Jedi well, but there is little depth or emotional connection to be had with his character. The villians are what you would expect from the Sith and, like Gnost Dural, they do their job without having any real depth or interest aside from the political machinations of the sith.

Another thing that was nice in this book was being able to see the latest events in the Old Republic timeline and how the war between the Republic and Sith Empire was going in its latest incarnation. They throw you a bone with some glimpses of politics and comments pointing to the larger scope of the war but its nothign particulary in depth or substantial which I found a letdown and took away from the sense of scale and conflict. But in the end this is Therons story and all other devices
serve as a medium to tell it.

It's a decent book in the Old Republic series and the character of Theron Shan is really the selling point of this book in my opinion. I would even like to see more SIS operations detailing new events in the war centered around his viewpoint or have him reappear as a supporting character in future peices of lore. But if you are looking for a good stand alone book that can really suck you into the Old Republic era I would give this a pass.

title: Borderline unreadable
text:
I enjoyed the first book in the Hatching Series a lot and each subsequent book a little less. I appreciated the tight , punchy chapters and changes in point of view which reminded me of World War Z in a highly positive way. I wish I had found out the fate of every character but in the end the broader story was worth it.

I say this because The Mansion is the exact opposite. It focuses on a very limited cast of characters in one primary setting. The first chapter was a long, painful, repetitive slog with verbose but uninspiring descriptions of roughing it in a cabin where software was being developed. Sometimes they didn't have electricity but somehow they invented something better than Alexa and better than Google. Ok. Sure.

I feel guilty for reviewing something I am having a hard time finishing, but if I can save someone else from this, it's worth it.

title: Not like her usual books
text:
I have enjoyed other books by Ms. Sellers, but I just did not care for this one. What I have liked about her other books are the non-stop action and the clever plot. This book wasn't really a novel. It's an editorial thinly wrapped in a story. And the story plods.

Ms. Sellers is using this book to press for decriminalizing drug use. Her passion is so strong that I believe that she or someone very close to her spent some time in jail for drug possession. When you are so passionate about an issue, I think you lose the perspective you need to write an interesting book. For instance, the Amazon book description says that the main character is undercover but finds the group she's infiltrated to be sympathetic. I don't think the writing in the story supported that contention.

If you're considering this book as your first Sellers' story, I would select another one. It isn't characteristic of her work.

If you've looked at the other reviews, you can see that lots of people disagree with me. If you feel as passionately as Ms. Sellers, you may like this book too because you'll be ardently agreeing with what she says and you won't notice that there is very little story. For me, when I want an editorial, I buy a non-fiction book. I wanted a novel when I bought this book and didn't get one.

title: Cool, but it's not the next Book Thief.
text:
Protect the diamonds
Survive the clubs
Dig deep through the spades
Feel the hearts

This description of I Am the Messenger sounds interesting enough, when you know that it’s about Ed receiving playing cards in the mail with special instructions written on them from an anonymous source, but I was honestly just bored with most of the story, even while listening to the audiobook. This book reminded me of Zusak’s Underdogs trilogy, probably because of the personality of the main character. I didn’t really like those books, and I didn’t really care for this story either. There was nothing inherently wrong with it—it’s a really neat, well-written story—but it just wasn’t for me.

Ed was a fine character, but I didn’t particularly connect with him or like him. I didn’t dislike him either though. I did think the book’s plot was smart. The ending was pretty great too, and although I should have guessed it, I didn’t. But then the actual ending after the reveal was disappointing and left me with the obvious questions of who? I don’t like not getting answers in my books.

I like the message of this book: everyone is struggling with something and everyone needs help, and anyone can benefit and feel better after serving another. I think that’s a great takeaway.

Although this book grew on me the more I read it, I was still just feeling very meh about the whole thing by the end.

If I Am the Messenger wasn’t written by Markus Zusak, I doubt I would have read it. This is my fifth book by him, and the only good one was The Book Thief, unfortunately. I wish I liked them all, but I don’t. I still have Bridge of Clay left but once I read that I’ll have read all Zusak’s books. That one’s a similar situation: I don’t think I would read it if it wasn’t by Zusak, but because it is, I do want to read it. But I also don’t think I’m going to like it though, just based on what I’ve heard about the story and what I know about my own reading tastes. I’m becoming increasingly convinced that The Book Thief was a one-hit-wonder by Zusak, and that makes me really sad. It was an incredible book, and I wish I could say the same about his others.

title: An Insider Novel-Too Narrow in Scope to be Satisfying
text:
This novel was first published as daily installments in an Edinburgh newspaper. In turn, the novel is divided into a 100+ very short chapters. Alexander McCall Smith's intended audience was the Edinburgh newspaper readers who had to follow the novel on a daily basis. Consequently, the novel is filled with insider references that Edinburgh readers would appreciate. Afterall, it is always a little bit thrilling to see one's home town mentioned in a story. All these inside references to neighborhoods and local politics are less interesting to a reader living in another country.

I am a loyal fan of Alexander McCall Smith. His Number One Ladies Detective Agency novels are subperb and the Professor Von Igelfeld stories are some of the funniest stories that I have ever read. Unfortunately, McCall Smith does not deliver in this novel. The story line is jagged and many interesting threads are never persued. There are some very humorous moments but all in all the novel is strangely disjointed.

Writing novels in daily or weekly chapters must be one of the most daunting tasks that any novelist can undertake. Unfortunately, only the greatest writers can do this well. Dumas and Dickens come to mind. They were successful because they took on ambitious story lines with very wide scopes of detail and character. McCall Smith fails in this novel because his scope is too narrow and pedestrian. These small intimate Edinburgh stories are not made for daily newspaper deadlines. Unfortunately, he could not realize this novel within the constraints of one newspaper column a day. This would have been a much better novel, if he would have sat down and wrote it like a conventional novel. It was an interesting experiment but he should stick to the format that best works for him.

title: Three Stars
text: Enformitive and good incite as to what the Germans had during the war

title: The Company Of Cats
text: Marian Babson's The Company Of Cats turns a gossip column informant into an interior decorator for an eccentric multimillionaire.  The subsequent murders and line up of suspects lacks the usual flair of Miss Babson's best  work.  The ingredients for a good light-hearted read are all there, but  somehow the unexpected will, thoroughly unpleasant suspects, hidden money  stash, missing cat and the subsequent parade of impostors just didn't jell.  The only memorable characters were the three cats- Sally, Salvatore and  Sassy. Unfortunately, this mystery just wasn't the "cat's meow."

title: not enough info in recipes
text:
I hate buying cookbooks in plastic wrap but it was $20 at the amazon book store. Cooking my second recipe in the book and having the same problems as the first. He doesn’t state how long any of the recipes will take from start to finish (some of us have lives and can’t cook for 2 hours a day), he doesn’t say how long to do activities like whisking, and he doesn’t say what temperatures to cook things at. His cook times are also insane, 30 minutes for onions to turn golden brown? That’s too long! Also his vegetable portions are condescending. I live in the Bay Area and have to leave my onions in the fridge because it’s so moist and warm in our kitchen (no A/C and the room gets sun nearly all day). He could’ve suggested any other fixes for if you can’t obey his rules 24/7.
This book sucks.

title: Slow and disappointing
text: I've tried and tried to get into this book . . . the cover and book jacket looked so appealing and I spent so much money on it.  But I find it very slow and unexciting.  I keep picking it up, hoping the next chapter will be more riveting, but it isn't.  The main character is great, however.  I really like her.  In fact, all of the characters are well developed and interesting.  So what's the problem?  I think it's because I can always predict exactly what's going to happen.  It moves at a slow pace and there are few, if any, unexpected surprises.  So I can only give it two stars and call it SLOW and DISAPPOINTING.  I bought it for my son, but after reading it myself, I'm not even going to recommend it to him, because I know he'll find it painfully slow and dull.

title: Not very unexpected
text: Disappointed in the stories. Lack complexity.

title: Allowances, EXCEPT FOR Briar...
text:
I am making allowances for this being a debut novel, and social commentary is difficult to write as fiction.

However, that doesn’t excuse allowing your characters to be highly stereotypical.

And nothing excuses putting a toddler in a situation in which the people she depends on for everything talk about her and her future — often quite explicitly and on television — like she is not even there and has no understanding of the language — without some consequences. Poor Briar.

title: The parade that never ends!
text:
I am hesitant to give this book 3 stars, but to be fair, the beginning was exciting and frightening. A world reknown sculptor is kidnapping families and feeding them wholesome meals, forcing them to exercise until their bodies are taut and fit, then encases their bodies in amalgamate to make molds of their bodies that depict their suffering. He then casts the molds with bronze. He cleverly sculpts different heads onto the statues so they won't be identified. He is truly a monster.

That was the premise of the story and the author did a great job conveying the horror these families went through. He did a excellent job depicting the maddness necessary to perform such heinous acts against another human being. What he didn't do very well was end the book. The ending was rushed, stupid, and lacked imagination.

The book is not a total waste of time, but there are too many great suspense novels out there to devote precious time to this one that just becomes phony and tiring in the end.

title: Lack of clear intructions.
text: I purchased this book when it first came out.  I was initially pleased and made place mats by using one of the patterns. They came out well and I had no problems.  I recently completed a warp to make Serendipity, one of the more attractive patterns featured in the book. I reviewed the directions for threading but counting up the number of ends I would need and comparing the count with the pattern in the book I had a different count. I recounted several times and even tried several ways of adding things up but my end count remained the same. I assume that I misunderstood the sparse directions which were not clear.  It would have taken little effort to include clear instructions. I will not waste the warp, I will use for another project but it won't be from this book.

title: Boring.. save your money
text: Boring.. save your money. The author spends most of his time telling long drawn out stories about his classes and test. Very boring and a disappointment. I barely finished a few pages of reading about his classes.

title: Not impressed
text:
Four lives, the first one entertaining, the next two so hurried and compressed that it appears they were included only to advance the timeline of the last one; way too much text devoted to superfluous sex, bodily orifices, bodily fluids, excrement, which didn't enhance the characters and made me think more Greenwich Village in the 70s than ancient Egypt. The ending had little emotional impact and added little meaning to the story.

I would have enjoyed it more if it were half the size and the author had spent more time crafting the story and less time fantasizing about critical acclaim for breaking new ground and dashing modern taboos.

title: A Solid Narration Helped the Story
text:
A Scattered Thoughts and Rogue Words Review (An Ali Audiobook Review)
Rating: 2.5 out of 5 stars
The horrific murder of a local woman rocks Morristown, Mississipi. With her death, veteran police chief Eli Gallagher feels he’s failed his small town, despite trying his best to serve and protect everyone in his jurisdiction. Sometimes that’s harder than it looks, given that rich and poor don’t always get along, and life on the other side of the tracks can turn deadly.

By his side is conscientious young Deputy Stan Leach. Together they work to discover the killer. But as they uncover evidence, their personal lives begin to unravel. Eli’s long-distance boyfriend telephones saying he’s getting married to a woman. Stan learns that the man he helped shelter wants to move on. When the clues unveil a history of abuse, the two men pull together to bring the murdered woman justice and maybe find the answers to theother questions in their lives.
This is a novella by a new to me author. The story was just ok for me. The majority of the story is about the two main characters in relationships with other people. We see those relationships and eventually why those don’t work out. They end up working a horrible murder case together and take comfort in each other. All of a sudden they are a couple and it is the end of the book. We get an epilogue which shows their happily ever after but I felt cheated. I felt like the book was about the other relationships and we didn’t get to see any of this relationship develop. The ending was very abrupt in my opinion and honestly I wasn’t too happy with the way it all played out.
The book was narrated by K.C Kelly and I felt like he did a nice job. He had a nice voice and I was always able to tell which character was talking.
Although the narration was solid and I liked that aspect, I didn’t really enjoy the story as a whole.
Cover: I like the cover and felt it was well done. It’s an attractive cover that catches your eye. It’s also a nice representation of the story.

title: Too gory.
text:
Bough this for my school library from another vendor. The graphics are really 'bad' nightmarish.
Gory and gory unleashed.
My 8th grade critics did not like it.
Frankly, I cannot think of any age child that I would offer this to.

title: Scraps of Paper
text: The plot was interesting, I believe the characters could have been enhanced, fleshed out more.

title: Déjà vu all over again
text:
I read the Dream Realms Series by this author, which by the way has now mysteriously disappeared from Amazon, and as far as I can tell this is the exact same story with a few minor changes. A quick look at her blog confirmed my suspicions. She is announcing this as a new series when in fact she has not done anything new for a while.

Perhaps the author decided to rework or edit the story in order to put out a better version, but I feel that she should have told her readers that this is not a "new" book. It's not right to allow loyal readers to pay twice for the same product.

title: Wow, what a terrible "book"
text: These reviews have to be written by family members and friends. This book is an absolute disaster. People need to have 5 things in common to have the five literacies. They also need to have four tenets to learn their way to a better future. After you learn the five things and four more things and two more things followed by five things and six more things, then you will learn the five literacies. And after you make it past 186 pages and are three pages past the first literacy, you're met with four conditions that can be applied to make the five literacies effective. You'll also see the seven critical organizing principles underpinning the five literacies a couple more pages later. And well after the 122 3, 4, and 5 step lists, I guess you'll know how to be a "global leader".  I actually skimmed through this whole book and read it because it was entertainingly terrible.

title: Oh dear
text: I suspect the same people who liked 50 Shades of Grey are the ones who like/love this book. It's trash and does a disservice to women, in general and probably to the FBI. To think that there is a FBI female agent who is as inept as this one is asking the reader to suspend belief.  It's too big an ask, for me. Some people took issue with the use of "Girl" (as opposed to "Woman") but all in all it's actually appropriate. The character is about as immature as you can be.  Couldn't waste my time finishing this. Thankful it was free

title: Lyrical, but...
text:
I really tried to like this lyrical novel. I would have found it as beautiful as the numerous five star reviews that it has received, however, there were too many unbelievable aspects to it for me to by into the premise.

SPOILERS:
1. A six year old girl who raises herself in the depth of a marsh without ever getting sick, not even a cold?
2. The girl, Kya, has a terrible diet but never suffers malnutrition or illness from lack of necessary nutrients.
3. Names of characters that would never have been used at that time.
3. Material objects, e.g., a boat, her shack, suitcase, clothes, etc., that never need repair and never deteriorate.
4. An absolutely ridiculous court scene.

And on and on.

title: It's okay
text: Some interesting observations and explanations, but dragged on too much about his own stories. I want to read the art of war now.

title: Three Stars
text: Well written. JP

title: Three Stars
text: Overall, okay. The story line drags a bit.

title: Interesting, but doesn't help game play.
text: I guess it is interesting, but I was really hoping it had more information, like which attacks are most or least effective against each creature. Probably, if I had read the description, I would have seen that it has interesting stuff, but nothing that improves my game play. Sad day.

title: good info, bad organization
text:
The information in this book is great, but the organization and editing is horrid. I would be reading along and the text would wander off onto other subjects and eventually drift back to where it started.
If you have to have this book, try and find another one that makes more sense to your head if this one doesn't.

title: Huge Disappointment
text: I was so looking forward to reading a new Judy Blume book, especially after having loved her books as an adolescent. What a disappointment this book was. The writing style was immature, the plot zig-zagged all over the place, and there was no depth to any of the characters. I kept waiting for the storyline to develop into something meaningful, but sadly the book just dragged on. It was an effort to finish this book, and I can honestly say it was one of the worst books I have read in a long time.

title: One Star
text: Not a good textbook if this is your very first exposure to financial statements of any kind!

title: Too busy
text: This book is too busy for me.  Too many lives entwined. Too many people talking.  This is the first one I read and skipped a lot.  It was not a good book.  It is unrealistic.  I can't and won't read any more.  All those people talking.  I am glad at least Jasmine spoke well enough.  Geez, those workers spoke badly.  What is being portrayed to us in this book?  It is so very long, but the saga isn't over. 😩

title: Book Review
text: I've only read 1/2 of the book, but to be honest I thought that it went on and on about two simple little points.  Perhaps redundancy is the best way to learn?

title: least favorite children's book ever
text: Perhaps appropriate for discussion with an older child, but written and drawn for younger ones. It brings to mind cartoon Camel cigarette art drawn to appeal to adolescents. As a parable, this story has power and merit along the lines of the song "Cat's In The Cradle" by Harry Chapin, but its presentation in a format for young children is totally inappropriate. This is a horrible, disturbing book.

title: Book ripped
text: Book came ripped, I will never buy a book offline again.

title: disappointing
text: Unfortunately this particular book took way to many multiple plots, none of which appear to capture this reader's interest.  In addition, the story has too many characters and not enough character development, so there is confusion as to who is who and what reason they are included in the story.  The story was  difficult to follow, and rather dull. It has become a task to continue reading, but have decided to finish reading it even though it has not totally kept my interest. I trust the next book will be better as I have enjoyed this series and it will be a shame to discontinue the  series because of this particular book.

title: Too many characters, doing too many things!
text: Yep, that's why I wasn't nuts about this book. Also, the main character was a new (ish) lawyer, yet she really seemed so ditzy and shallow. Not my kind of gal. The plot was OK, believable, to an extent. I made it to the OK end, and I was glad to have done so. Not a great book, but not a very bad one, either.

title: Three Stars
text: Kind of weird lines. Overall, it's ok.

title: basic knowledge that we all know
text: Nothing special here. Just the same things you know you should be doing- spending less, saving more. Most of the examples involve "regular people" making $80-100k per year. This book pretty much reinforces the notion that most people are screwed because they barely make enough to get by, much less save $500k to $1 million for retirement.

title: Save your money, the internet has NEWER information, and it is free.
text: This book is so outdated it should be in the bargain  bin. If you are just starting the rc world, you will get some useful information out of this book. I on other hand, was in the rc universe in the past, and I was hoping to learn more about brushless versus brushed equipment and more about li-on batteries. These were not in existence when I built rc cars and trucks years ago, nor were they in this book!! For the price they wanted, I thought it would have been more up to date than it was. I don't know when things got so much better in the rc world and was looking for that info, this book failed.

title: Good concept, poor execution
text: I was intrigued by the concept of this story, and it starts out well drawing you in with the basic premise and characters.  However, somewhere in the middle it starts to drag and by the end I was only finishing it because I had invested the time to get that far.  The idea is unique and well-executed at first, but it gets off-track and becomes boring along the way.

title: A Strange Attempt at Stream of Consciousness
text: Tried reading. People don't even think like this. But, pedantic authors write. Makes some readers feel intellectual. Like having a Joyce novel on the shelf. Thanks for sending $12.95. Too irritating. Stopped reading.

title: Don't be fooled, it can be very technical of a read
text: I am not a scientist.  But, I am not an idiot.  I generally love books like this.  But most don't read like this... "Stress and glucorticoids have inverted-U effects here as well.".  So.... be aware you will read a few pages and feel like you have just sat there and spent time.  There are very cool ideas but boy do you have to slog thru some very dry, highly technical, pointy-headed language to get to them.

title: people or substance
text:
First, this is a "people" book more concerned with the personalities that created DARPA than what has come through the doors of DARPA that has contributed to the technological advancements for both the department of defense and the public-at-large. He seems concerned that the reader not only understand the individuals but how clever he has been in being able to gain access to those personalities who know what is happening behind the walls.

Second, it is clear that Belfiore gained considerable knowledge about rockets from his previous book. He is more comfortable in writing about this area of DARPA rather than about the game-changing world of computers and artificial intelligence or the larger DARPA agenda. He frankly admits his lack of understanding and seems willing to let that lack of knowledge ride in exchange for defaulting to the personalities working in these arenas.

He points out that much of his information comes from DARPA contractors who aren't veiled in the same "secrecy" or opaqueness of DARPA itself. Yet he has not taken the time to explore the breadth of this contracted research but limits himself more to the historic, the visible and his personal zone of comfort.

What Belfiore hits by accident and dismisses in order to retain his narrow focus is that while DARPA is "edgy" it is only the tip of a very large iceberg of military research by each of the various branches, some of which are of a similar nature to what DARPA is doing. One would think, from this book, that DARPA represents where the defense industry's research and development's edge is today.
It's not sufficiently technologically detailed, and does not significantly clarify what is currently going on behind the closed doors. It is more a personal tale of travel through the corridors of history and personalities than the essence of what makes DARPA a force on the frontiers of research today and for the future. It should find itself abridged in Readers Digest.

title: interesting overview, but no practical advice
text: This book defines digital disruption and describes some of the benefits and pitfalls of being too innovative, but I felt it was all too theoretical. I would have liked more guidance on how to apply this to one's own business in certain industries.  It is a popular buzzphrase in business at the moment and a friend of mine just did a dissertation on the same topic. He focused on his own industry and that was more interesting to me. This is a good general read on the topic, but it can be tough going at times.

title: A collection of short stories
text:
I can't recommend this history. It appears to be an analysis of the campaign, but I found it to be a collection of short stories without a theme.

The stories were mostly episodes which led up to the naval campaign, but not a detailed analysis of the battle, and definitely not an analysis of the consequences of the campaign or war.

A key place where there was too little coverage was of Holland and what the Duke of Parma did, and then didn't do there. We learn a fair amount of the events leading up to the invasion and the need for Parma's participation, and practically nothing about why he did essentially nothing.

Yes some of the stories about the build up to the campaign (it wasn't a battle, it was a campaign in a long war) were interesting and important. But fundamentally, this book lacked the perspective and analysis of a historian, instead it displayed the skill of a storyteller.

Instead, I would recommend "The Spanish Armada" by C. Martin, as a more complete history and one illustrated with photographs and maps.

title: A Movie Script in a Book
text:
Storyline: The story is about a boy, Mike, who runs away because he doesn't like the rules in the house. He and his dog, Barney (who I pictured to be much smaller in the book than is shown in the trailer), get trapped on a railroad car traveling southeast. When the train stops, they discover that they have been on a circus train and have traveled quite a distance from home. Big Bob is a circus clown who takes Mike and Barney in. And the story goes from there...

Strengths: The book moves at a good pace and flows well for the most part. Readers are put in the driver's seat to imagine what everything looks like. The book is a very fast read with simple language and sentence structure. My husband felt it was a very competent book. I asked his opinion since I happen to be a woman and not a man. He felt it would be a very easy read for a child who is used to watching television and video games rather than reading books.

Weaknesses: This book is written at a 2nd or 3rd grade reading level, in my opinion. It has as much description as Dori Hillestad Butler's The Buddy Files series. Whereas, I felt the description was appropriate in The Buddy Files series, that is a weakness to me in this book because I would want even reluctant readers to learn to comprehend writing that is more detailed and specific. This book (as you can see by the trailer) is really set in the 1950s or 1960s rather than today. That isn't specified in the book. There were also several points in the story that were very stilted to me. For example, I wasn't sure how he got home in the first chapter of the book.

Best Audience for this Book: This book would be great for a child that is used to watching television and isn't used to a lot of descriptive language in a book. It is written like a movie script without illustrations.

My conclusions...
Is this a book you could hand your child and not worry about? Yes. So, if you are of the mind that you just want your child to read and just want to make sure there isn't anything in the content to be concerned about, then this book would be fine.

Is this a book I would recommend across the board? Well...what we read becomes our model for how and what we write. We want to read good examples of writing with description and good sentence structure because it helps us become better writers. Reading helps our children learn how to write, how to spell, and even how to speak. In education theory, there is an idea explained by Vygotsky about scaffolding. We want children to read a step or two above where they're at. We don't want them to get frustrated, but we do want them to be challenged. This book is written at a 3rd grade reading level for readers 8-13 years old. I think it would be appropriate reading for a 3rd, 4th, or 5th grade boy who is a reluctant reader. If a boy is in middle school, they will need more examples of description so that their own writing can improve and they can grow in their ability to complete their school assignments. This book is what I think a middle school boy might write. That is fine. But, by Vygotsky's theory, you want them to read a step or two above that. The book I received in the mail today from the Christian Heroes: Then & Now series is a good example of that step above for a middle school reader.

Please note that I received a complimentary copy of this book from Comfort Publishing for review.

title: The Good, Bad, & Ugly
text:
These books are addictive, or I would not still be reading them, but IMO, the series has a number frustrating faults. On one hand, Mr. Martin can write chapters that are downright brilliant and are as good as any fantasy I have read. Most of the characters are well drawn with a sly sense of humor that can make me laugh out loud. Mr. Martin has a fertile, original imagination.

On the other hand....

After almost three thousand pages of reading, I am convinced that these books are intentionally padded with fluff that even Mr. Martin's considerable ability cannot sustain. Some scenes are bloated like a wordy first draft that was never edited. The ability to write economically and move the plot along without unnecessary detail is not one of the author's strengths. Characters have circular arguments that go on and on, even though the outcome is obvious. This kind of thing happens so often that it's got to be an end in itself. These books are designed to be loonnnngggg, to bulge on bookstore shelves. I thought "Storm of Swords" was better in this respect than the previous two volumes, but there were still segments I found just plain boring and needlessly over written at the expense of other plot lines.

The way that most characters lose out most of the time in this series is a bit depressing and makes me wonder if the author was dealing with some personal demons. It's like a detective novel where the hero inevitably gets beaten up at the beginning, so pay back is sweeter in the end. Well, there's been thousands of pages of "beaten up," with very little "payback." Also, there's been little romantic love or sex in this series, while there's been quite a bit more sex that's been either forced or paid for. Why?

Much has been made by some reviewers of the author's "inventive" killing off of main figures or radically changing their characters, or changing plot direction in this volume. I just found this capricious and undisciplined. It's like Martin grew tired of some of his characters or didn't quite know what to do with them, or just had too many to deal with, so he bumped some of them off. While this was done within a plot context, it had the air of simple authorial execution rather than really being plot driven.

From the get go, I believe Mr. Martin has spent his writing day focusing on whatever he felt like. He introduces characters or locations that are quickly dropped for no apparent reason, yet he spends an inordinate amount of time on trivial behavior of other characters. I really think he is making this stuff up almost as he is typing it. If he has any kind of overall vision for the arc of the plot, it appears to change all the time. This mutability is not the imitation of reality, it's authorial self-indulgence. (I am tempted to call it laziness, but the guy has cranked out several thousand pages.)

Mr. Martin is particularly effective at manipulating the reader by generating suspense through parallel plotting and cliff hangers. This suspense is often cheap or artificial. For example, a character appears to die at the end of a chapter. It turns out later that they did not. Anyone who was in the room when they "died" would know they didn't die, but the author has miss-represented the facts to the reader to create suspense. Yes, that's an authorial tool, but I'd call it cheesy pulp writing and not very inventive. Mr. Martin uses such crutches to keep the reader interested. If his pacing was brisker, with tighter scenes and focused plotting that has internal logic, he wouldn't need such tricks.

Mr. Martin is very diligent at setting lots of such manipulative suspense hooks to keep the reader reading and buying more books. It's a needed spur for the reader to get through the boring bits. "Well this chapter is really dull, but I must push on to find out what happens to Tyrion in the next one." "That last volume really dragged at times, but I've got to see if Dany gets to Westros with the dragon's in the next one." When a reader has invested thousands of pages in a storyline, it's hard to just put it down, even if it is sometimes dull, especially if the author keeps hatching more intriguing plots than he ever resolves.

I have read that there is a rumor that this series will end at six volumes. Given the pace of plot development, I'm not sure Martin can or wants to end it at only six. A better series title might be, "George R R Martin's Perpetual IRA Machine."

text:

I have skipped the following novels by the author writing those books.
This book is also fiction, but the publisher seems to treat it as a true story.
I have to admit it's better than the outlaw book, and it has some good characters and the relationships were reasonable. And it was easy reading; good writing with only a few unusual words for a Western. Probably close to Bill Johnstone's writing style.
But I like my Westerns to have decent endings, this one ended badly. A perfect chance to end a "fiction" story with a pleasant ending with a happy couple was really passed up for "realism". But It was good that the kid got the gun and the badge!
Norm

title: Interesting Ideas but wasnt for me
text:
Julia Crane tackles the interesting idea of “Cyborgs” in her newest book “Freak of Nature”. The main character is a cross between a feminine version of Data form Star Trek and Robocop. She is strong and much to the chagrin of her creators she has a mind of her own.

Having donated her body to science she never expected what the out come could be. Free will and the right to choose what happens to your body are all questioned in this sci-fi saga.

While quick moving, this story delves into a romance which seems illogical and unrealistic. In one breath a character can’t feel something as simple as wind or get cold but then she’s excited and feels pleasure at the touch of another’s skin against hers. To be fair the moral implications are truly well thought out but end up unconvincing due to the hit and run style of the author. Spending a little more time with the ideas introduce would have solved most of the issues and been a huge plus. The main problem with the story though is it just doesn’t reach a climax. Ending the story with a “to be continued” actually does more harm then good. It ended too soon, not giving enough to entice this reader into the 2nd book.

title: Not much to it
text: I’m afraid like Jake, the main character in this book, the author’s best work so far, imo, has been You Should Have Known.  Now that was a great book and one you could sink your teeth into.

title: Trek Isn't Supposed to be Depressing!
text:
But this is! The book has 3 short stories set in the Star Trek universe, but from different perspectives of time. What would have happened if this person died or this person lived, or this person accepts a transfer to another ship or makes a scientific breakthrough, what have you. Well I don't want to give anything away, but the answer is pain, and unyielding horror and suffering apparently. The Trek as it played out on tv and the movies is apparently the only one worth living in as it is the only one with a potentially hopeful future.

Both of the first two stories made me so sad I really didn't want to read the third. Nothing good happened. Usually with Trek even when they face terrible circumstances there is a sense of hopefullness, the possibility of coming through victorious. There was nothing of that here. Something bad happened and then something even worse happened after it and there was no end in sight. Kirk's doomed son, David Marcus is a main character in the first story "The Chimes At Midnight" and I can't think of another more tragic character with the possible exception of Othello or King Lear maybe. I haven't read a Shakesperian tragedy in 15 years, what does that tell you, that I should think of such a thing while reading this?

It makes me sadder than I can say to give a Star Trek book only 2 stars. Really I'd give it 2 1/2 just cause its Trek but they don't do that here, more's the pity. Still the third story Brave New World was good. It had hope. It has nearly isurmountable odds that our intrepid heroes overcome with cunning and and intelligence and good old fashioned sticktoittiveness. Get the book for that story alone.

I'll say this: if you like never ending drama, like the new BattleStar Galactica series, then you should be alright with the first two stories. I wasn't able to watch BSG after Season 1 but I know it still has a lot of raging fans so it must appeal to somebody. But if you like your scifi with relatively happy endings, I don't think that 2/3 of this book is for you.

title: Un Viaje Lento
text:
I am a fan of historical fiction, especially mysteries. In my youth I read every one of the [[ASIN:0060751401 Judge Dee Mysteries]] by Robert Van Guilin several times each. As with this book, they are full of sex and violence as well as historical information. One thing each of the Judge Dee books had was a Dramatis Personae: a list of all the named characters, something this novel sorely needs, because there are dozens of characters who maddeningly pop in and out. Put the book down for a few days, and you are likely to forget who is who.

For an historian, especially a British historian, it’s disappointing how many anachronisms are contained within these pages. The story takes place in the the mid-sixteenth century (1584), but late in the narrative, the country doctor gives the hero laudanum, something which was unknown until the 1660s. Likewise, Carr has people firing rifles. Firearms with a rifled bore (hence the name) were not made until the next century. Carr lists two weapons historians he consulted, yet he puts safety catches on matchlock pistols. (He’s off by three-hundred years on that one.)

There is a rich history of sixteenth-century Spain, but the novel is not worth it. Worst of all are all the descriptive passages which make reading this a rough slog. There are several road trips, each with detailed descriptions of the countryside and villages. The journey from Valladolid to Belamar takes the protagonists twelve days. It may take the reader the same amount of time to trudge through those pages.

title: There’s a reason for the title…
text: There was a lot of hype about this book — totally unfounded.

title: That Sinking Feeling
text:
The Doctor and Charley arrive in future Venice hours before it sinks. Can an ancient curse be reversed in time to save the great city?

This story is filled with familiar, perhaps even stereotypical, characters. There is an unsavoury Duke, a strange old woman, a mutated human, and followers of a strange cult. All these things have long been staples of Doctor Who, but for some reason this story failed to grab me. Instead I found it to be rather formulaic.

There is, however, no denying the incredible rapport between Paul McGann and India Fisher. This is the first story the pair recorded, but their character seem like old friends. Their performances are truly the best thing about this audio.

2.5 stars

title: Another good holiday read
text:
Like most of Katia Lief's novels, "Next Time You See Me" (aka "[[ASIN:B00563M3I8 Hide and Seek]]" -- its UK title) is an above-averagely penned thriller, which makes for an excellent novel for a long plane flight, or an idle few days on the beach. The story is a sequel to the "[[ASIN:0091937914 You Are Next]]" but does not require the reader to have read the earlier work. Indeed, its plot line spins out in an entirely new direction, although readers of the earlier volume may find themselves wondering more than a few times whether it will suddenly tie into the earlier one in some meatier sort of a way.

Like its predecessor, the book would convert effortlessly and effectively into a screenplay; it has the right mix of action and dialogue, a comfortable cast size and a sufficiently simple (simplistic almost) plot-line but with a potent narrative capable of delivering a comfortable suspension of disbelief through an atavistic response to the story's emotional flow, rather than needing any rational figuring of the events themselves.

Also like its predecessor, the book delivers no real surprises, but neither does it disappoint; it's worth more than three stars really but doesn't quite deserve four.

title: This is pretentious prose. When you read Gomrich's "A ...
text: This is pretentious prose. When you read Gomrich's "A little History of the World" with its stunningly clear writing, Mieville's book is the exact opposite. I'm reading it because I'm interested in the topic. I just wished he had aimed for clarity. I'm halfway through, painfully, always hoping that the author will finally lighten up.

title: If it was as good as the title
text: I'm not one to give away the ending to a novel. Even an ending, if you can call it that,as absurd as this one. So, let's start with the characters. Qui-Gon and Obi-Wan need no introduction. However, there is this character Rael Averross,who is supposed to be a Jedi, but dresses like a slob, smokes, drinks alot, sleeps around and doesn't seem to have anything to do with " The Force ". Also, he made a bad decision, that obviously should not have been made, that got his Padawan killed. Ok so the Jedi Council sends him off to rule a planet until its princess , who is a child, is old enough to be crowned Queen. Really? This guy can't handle the job so he asks for back up namely Qui-Gon with Obi-Wan his Padawan, who are at odds for most of the story because they each think they have failed the other. Also, the Jedi Council has invited Qui-Gon to join the Council. Now Qui-Gon  believes in old Jedi prophecies, which the others including Obi-Wan don't, and he actually seems to be one with The Force, when needed. He has a record of being at odds with the Council at times and a bit of a free thinker which master Yoda certainly doesn't care for since he voted against the invite.  So, before Qui-Gon decides off they go to help Rael. They get there and the story drags on and on about the usual corporate greed, mining, using slaves, etc. Now there's a story line involving a couple of jewl thieves that should've been completely left out, imho, since it takes away from the main plot, which is infantile at best, again imho. There's a group of bad guys who are good guys that actually want to save the planet from the other bad guys etc. It's a mess but not one that makes sense in the end. Real is so useless as a Jedi he doesn't have a clue as to what's going on  even at the end when his precious child Queen, whom he adores, turns on him and loathes him more than any other creature in the galaxy. A generous 2 stars for Qui-Gon whose character saved the novel from total trash.

title: Good book for music historians
text: This is a good, easy to read (I mean real easy...like it's written for a child) book about the career of Tommy James, how and why he wrote some of his songs (I enjoyed about the origin of the song "mony,mony") and how he was controlled by mobsters that influenced radio and record sales. I especially loved his compliments or insults of fellow pop artists. The main weakness of the book is that the narrative sugarcoats his own life and treats his failed marriages in too light of a manner. This is hardly intellectual fodder but it makes for a good "beach read".

title: A sad and poorly written commentary on firefighting
text: Larry Brown has written “On Fire - a personal account of life and death choices.” To this reader, this “fireman’s diary” falls far short of print worthy. From Brown’s elementary voice to the boastful fanfare of the world of firefighting, this 181-page narrative was mostly disappointing. His depiction of firefighters as beer swilling buffoons whose main interest is watching sex and violence on television stands in odd contrast to his sense of self importance as a life saver. Fortunately today’s fire service largely enjoys a higher level of education and professionalism than that described in the book. It is puzzling that Brown received high profile blurbs from the likes of John Grisham and New York Times Book Review.

title: waste of money
text: This book concentrates on editing xaml code rather than using the gui provided in Blend.  There is zero information on Databinding and database use within Blend.  It provides no insight into Blend's use or abilities.  I don't know which audience the author was trying to reach with this book.  A complete waste of money.

title: The Utopia of Apocalyptic Novels!
text:
“I grew up in the Apocalypse, yet I still felt as if I belonged in another time.”

Wyatt Sullivan woke up in an abandoned bus in a time where deserts are the natural landscape and Feral beasts roam the earth looking to tear you to shreds. Smart and resourceful, he’s managed to keep himself alive for years with gadgets and gizmos until one day his radio signal picks up a human voice. He follows it, comes face to face with death, and wakes up with a cybernetic arm that grants him awesome powers. Will he use his newfound powers to save humanity? Or join the dark side?

The concept and science behind this book are extremely interesting. The physics of how the technology works while affecting the landscape are explained in a way that made me believe this could all really happen and that I understand how time/space dimensions work. (I don’t know anything about time/space dimensions.) I got Mad Max vibes mixed with Terminator - a duo I can appreciate.

However, I will say, a lot fell flat for me. I think this book could have greatly benefited from line editing, cuts on repetitive expositions, and more in-depth dives into the world itself and how Wyatt came to function properly after being alone for so long without memories. There wasn’t really a climax or any character development - everything happened exactly the way a good guy would want it to happen with evil doers turning good the moment of conflict which is not very believable. I would’ve liked to have seen Wyatt dip his toes into evil for a moment rather than be this string of holy consciousness and I would’ve liked to have seen more evil acts and betrayal from our dear Mr. Mayor to make me really hate him.

Overall, awesome concept just too good to be true for me.

It reads like it was written by a 17 year old girl who just finished French 1, spent a week in Paris, and then watched a movie about WWII. I agree with the other reviewers that say it is modern chick lit set in WWII. Terrible.

title: Stupid is as stupid does
text:
I write this for those who are not deterred by the negative reviews. I wasn't! wasn't expecting much, but at least hoped for some fun. Wikipedia is actually my idea of fun so I at least thought a thriller about fun things like codes and history and conspiracy theories such would be at least entertaining, even if the majority of the book consisted of People Talking About Things. Moreover, my standards for popular paperback thrillers are low (if people are complaining about the terrible writing, they clearly haven't read many bestseller thrillers. I mean, somebody want to defend the literary skills of Rollins or Grisham etc? Bahaha).

Where do I begin with the Stupid? I will not bore you with a laundry list. Suffice it to say that the first time any character does anything remotely intelligent is in chapter *110* when a CIA agent notices wheelchair marks in the carpet (no worries, not a spolier and nothing any generic detective wouldn't figure out).

I am a fan of far-fetched plots so long as they're logical within their world, so to speak. I'll suspend disbelief as long as the storytelling is good. I'll even excuse the bloated and formulaic plotting since I have a ffwd button I don't mind using as the same pointless details/dialog are repeated for the 110th time. But all of the above is so dumb I could only imagine that Brown was making stuff up as he went along. Plot twists actually rely on people doing stupid, illogical things. This is not fun.

Critics have panned Brown for his latest book being nothing but a glorified travel guide, and even that doesn't bother me! So long as it's interesting and absorbing enough. I didn't mind the Dan Brown Wikipedia Lectures in the beginning...until the story began to fall so flat that my mind would start wandering as I imagined Dan Brown on his 3-day tour of DC grabbing museum brochures and recording docent lectures. Not that I don't like museum brochures. I just don't want to see Dan Brown copying them on his computer, I'd rather be able to imagine characters in those places, which my visions of Dan Brown on Tour kept blocking.

Critics have panned Robert Langdon as being supercilious and obnoxious as he lectures everyone because he's smarter than everyone else. Lecture away, professor, so long as what you have to say is actually professor-like! Okay, true, there are lots of misinformed supercilious professors out there. However! The Internet! Libraries! People who know more about a subject than you the writer and can easily be interviewed! More than one book on a topic! Robert Langdon is, in this book, weirdly uninformed about certain religious texts he spouts off about. I've been annoyed by cheap research in other thrillers too, but Langdon should know better! So should his esoteric buddies.

I'm telling all of y'all, I should've gotten some enjoyment out of this book. My standards were low, I'm a nerd who likes lectures, I have no fear of skipping pointless passages. But I wasted my time! I should've taken a clue from the Wikipedia article on this book that was probably buffed up by a publicist trying to rebut criticisms of the book...I wondered why even Hollywood dropped the story and politely moved on to Inferno instead. I imagine that, in spite of having paid Brown a ton of moola for it, they eventually had to realize it no amount of script doctoring could make it into more than a terribly boring movie.

Anyway, if you're still not deterred, I strongly suggest instead of dropping your hard-earned money on this disappointing story that you borrow this from your local library (tons of *free!* electronic books/audiobooks if you knew not) and be ready to listen to it on 1.5x with your finger on the ffwd button.

title: Not so much.
text: While this book was at times witty, charming, and thought-provoking, mostly it was a very cumbersome read. The thoughts and ideas presented kept going around in circles like something that goes around in circles a lot!! The endless footnotes (nearly every page) kept interrupting what little logical flow sporadically existed. While the footnotes did give the impression that well researched material was being presented, they crossed the line from footnote/s into foot fungus. A persistent itching, that never seems to go away. The end result was that I could only read about 20 pages at a time, before I became uninterested in what might come next. The time I wasted could have been better spent doing my own research on the internet, instead of reading what Mary found in a google search.

title: I like the book - it is informative and full of ...

title: Don't bother, not worth over $40
text:
This book is way too basic. For the price it is a terrible value. Some of the advice seems outdated or useless, such as letting people know that they can get forms from the IRS website, or use tax software. They spend an entire chapter on setting up an office. I don't mean choosing an office space. I mean things like, you will need a phone, copier, and office supplies. I was expecting more of a textbook on how to operate a practice, including procedures, marketing, etc. The marketing chapter is virtually useless as well, with no novel ideas; network, tell your friends, do a direct mail campaign, etc. If it were 20 bucks, I would have kept it. For almost 50, I had to return it. I rarely if ever return an item, so that says how strongly I felt the value was not there. I purchased instead, "The Enrolled Agent Tax Consulting Practice Guide: Learn How to Develop, Market, and Operate a Profitable Tax and IRS Representation Practice" http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004RCLYIE/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_4
For $7.99 in the Kindle edition it has much more valuable ideas. Even if not an EA trying to focus on representation it has better value. It also has interviews with actual practitioners on how they run their practices.
If you are absolutely clueless as to how to even set up an office it might have some value, otherwise steer clear.
