title: Disjointed and short on detail but conveys the horror.
text:
Caruso was a Lieutenant in the 9th Marines, 3rd Marine division, which he joined towards the end of its time on Guam. He was involved in only one combat incident there but his two weeks on Iwo saw him exposed to a lot more. Unfortunately these are generally presented in short vignettes, sometimes with minimal detail and a lack of context in terms of when it took place. There are a few occasions where he does go into more detail, like when he is under attack at night, with grenades landing in his foxhole but mostly he is too sparse with the details and it is clear he left a lot out. There are quite a few passages provided by fellow veterans and some of these are quite graphic. They serve, to an extent, in fleshing Caruso's story out a little more. Caruso also includes some potted histories for some of the men he knew who were killed. Altogether these certainly convey the horror of the battle but Caruso's own story is lost at times.

Caruso was clearly the real deal as a soldier. The five officers above him were all first day casualties and he found himself commanding the company - from the front - almost from the start. He does provide some interesting information regarding some of his decisions but mostly he is writing about his interactions with his brother marines. Many of these become casualties and he provides statistics that emphasize the scale of these. By the time he is wounded less than 40 men are left in his company.

This is a short book that can easily be read in a few hours. It is based on some articles Caruso did about the campaign, which were apparently very well received by fellow veterans. Perhaps because of this, it is closer to a memorial to his comrades than a typical personal memoir - it is just not complete enough for me for that. It doesn't conform to a traditional narrative structure and Caruso doesn't build his story. Accordingly, in my opinion, it fails to engage the reader. I'd have liked to give it 2 1/2 stars. It is still informative in a general way though and the tragedy of it all is very clear. But there are other memoirs (see my list) where it is all revealed in a more complete and compelling manner. My recomemendation - Of some interest.

title: Graphic and Disturbing
text:
I'll start this review with a warning. The Girl in the Road contains some very graphic scenes in terms of both sex and violence. While that's not my cup of tea, I can handle it up to a point. Unfortunately, this book went far beyond that point; there is one brief but highly disturbing scene involving an adult engaging in sexual acts with a young child. For me, that is just too much, and it is not anything I ever want to read in a book.

That being said, if you can handle extremely disturbing sexual situations and violent scenes, you might find you really enjoy this book. Up until that particular scene I mentioned above, I was quite happy with The Girl in the Road. There is an intensity in the narration that draws the reader in, and the skyrocketing levels of desperation and urgency make it difficult to put the book down.

The story was unique, compelling, and addictive, but the content wasn't right for me. Without the incredibly disturbing scene, I would have given this 4 stars, but with it I'm bringing it down to just 2.

title: A bit dramatic
text:
Pros:
*Characters were interesting, sad we didn't get to know Chloe more.
*Plot was interesting and I thought her take on the mermaid/merman legend was very interesting. The physical similarities really stood out, and the abilities were cool to read about. I like that she explained some of their history and how their society works, where they live, how they've managed to stay hidden for so long, etc.

Cons:
*The main character's mother was confusing to me. I suppose she'll be explained in further detail in the following books, especially considering what we learn at the end of the book, but as it is in this one, she seemed to flip back and forth and her reactions to some things were unusual (some readers may point out that that too could be attributed to her secret but considering how long she has lived the way she does, I don't buy it). And actually I felt that way about a few characters - they made dramatic shifts in mood and opinions, and some of their reasoning didn't really make sense.
*Predictable. Emma wasn't that much of a mystery to me. In fact I spent most of the book wondering why it took Galen and the other characters so long to figure out what she was and why. Heck it had to basically be pointed out to them.
*I get that grieving is different for everyone and some time has passed, but I thought that Emma's overall reaction to the loss of her best and seemingly only friend was a bit well, it flipped back and forth. At first it seemed very realistic but then Galen showed up and it was like she forgot except for very few later points in the book that were used to further the plot.
*Based on what I know about shark attacks, I would say that this one was VERY unrealistic. That should have been researched better.

On a personal note, why does everything have to be a series? Authors can't get to the point in one book anymore. I ordered three books from amazon vine all from separate authors, only one didn't turn out to be the first in a series. I get it, they're trying to sell more books but I think they would do better if they had less quantity and more quality.

Anyway, all in all it was a good read, passed the time. But I'm not really looking forward to the sequel.

title: The book tries to be more that it is
text:
This novel by Richard Grant is set before WWII, in 1937/8, in Germany and Washington DC. The author follows a set of unlikely characters involved in the shadowy world of espionage and counter-espionage. Canaris, Heydrich, plus a cast of made up characters, all play their individual parts in this story.

We follow a semi-plot of Canaris reaching out to more neutral elements in the United States, and being thwarted time and time again. We follow a US Senator, his “fixer” and his delicate son as they weave in and out of the fairly convoluted plot.

This is one of those books, to my observation, that tries to be more that it is – pointing the way towards some elusive message. So, I had a really hard time deciding if this was a three star book trying for four stars, or if it was a four star book, failing to bring in that fourth star and only getting three. In the end, since I cannot give 3.5 stars, I will settle on three.

The author speaks German, and wants to brag about that – so many phrases in German and without the following translation in English – pretentious, is my interpretation. And put in places they were not needed to move the plot along – for example – the mention that the film playing was Walt Disney’s “Schneewittchen und die sieben Zwerge” – which translates as Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs – but the author does not tell you that – I am. As far as I was concerned – unneeded level of complexity or bragging.

A pet peeve of mine is the term “gone missing” – this is a 21st century affectation – the term is “missing” – as in “the man is missing” not “the man has gone missing”, or even worse “the man went missing.” The author uses “gone missing” in this novel set in 1938 – that phrase would not have been used.

Another pet peeve of mine, people in trouble, take out enemies and then flee, and do not pick up the weapons of the fallen enemy so they have a weapon for future use – this happens when Oskar slashes the Gestapo man with the knife, and then leaves a perfectly good weapon (pistol) as they move off. At least the author has Von Ewigholz think to take the weapon from the other dead Gestapo agent, when his Walther PPK runs dry. Speaking of said PPK – Oskar carries it for several days, without ever checking to see exactly how many cartridges (note, cartridges not bullets) it contained after they had acquired it. Another pet peeve – a cartridge is the entire package – shell casing, primer, powder, and bullet – a bullet is just the lead projectile – thus it is incorrect to say how many bullets are in a weapon – the correct usage is to say how many cartridges are in the weapon.

The author has one of the SS characters in the book standing at his Berlin office on Prinz-Albrecht- Strasse in his office of the “Reich Security Main Office”. The correct term is "Reich Main Security Office”. For an author that keeps banging us over the head with German phrases, to get this wrong is very jarring.

One thing I will give the author is his correct attitude of the German people towards “jaywalking”. They do not do it. He has the comment made that the people jaywalking must be tourists. Very true – on the street in Frankfurt 20-25 years ago we watched as tourist parents took their child across the road before the light had changed, and they were yelled at by the locals saying they were setting a bad example for their child and were being bad parents. To be honest, I agreed!

A very detailed book – and it does give a fairly accurate feeling of how it feels to live in a police state where one has to watch every word spoken and care must be taken to whom one will speak freely, even when there is supposedly no one listening. After all, being paranoid is not crazy when there really are people out there trying to get you. Just ask most any student on a University Campus today.

An interesting book – it won’t be for everyone – and as I said right between a 3 and 4 star rating.

title: Meh.

title: Flimsy is Right

His interactions with women and people on the island were pretty insignificant. This book was just too scatterbrained, too boring, and too desperate. The organizational pattern and writing style is probably one of the most intriguing I've ever read, but the writer failed to develop the plotline for me.

title: You can get this online for free!
text: This is a good source to learn Croatian but had I known you could simply look this entire manual up on the FSI website and also listen to the lessons there, I would not have bothered to purchase it! This should not be sold when it is online for free. All you get is the CD so it's not like they have at least printed the manual for you to spare you the cost of the paper. You have to print it yourself. That said, it's a good resource but it's also very old. The language has likely evolved a great deal since then. I believe this was produced in the 1960's. Overall, I'm glad I have it because I love languages and find it interesting to have this resource.

title: Nothing Particularly Special
text:
Author: Alyson Noel
Pages: 320
Source: Purchased from Barnes and Noble
Standalone of Series: 1st in Series

Since a horrible accident claimed the lives of her family, sixteen-year-old Ever can see auras, hear people's thoughts, and know a person's life story by touch. Going out of her way to shield herself from human contact to suppress her abilities has branded her as a freak at her new high school--but everything changes when she meets Damen Auguste...
Ever sees Damen and feels an instant recognition. He is gorgeous, exotic and wealthy, and he holds many secrets. Damen is able to make things appear and disappear, he always seems to know what she's thinking--and he's the only one who can silence the noise and the random energy in her head. She doesn't know who he really is--or what he is. Damen equal parts light and darkness, and he belongs to an enchanted new world where no one ever dies.
* * *

Evermore was simply another fish in the current of mainstream paranormal romance. Admittedly, the idea of Alchemy is not a great deal common, but there are the unavoidable stereotypes that hold true throughout all of today's YA Paranormal Fantasy.

The unearthly beautiful boy who captivates the female protagonist with his unique looks and debonair charm that NO other man could ever equate to.
The main female character that is utterly defenseless when it comes to her love interest. (See above example.)
The mundane bitch who's only goal in life is to see the leading lady fall flat on her love struck little ass.
The inhuman bitch who is out to kill our leading lady, for xyz reasons.

The list goes on. Really, it does.

But, Evermore was a good read. I can't take that away from Alyson Noel. She knows how to write a captivating story that does leave you wanting more. I can see where the Twilight comparisons come in, but, really, look at Evermore for what it is: A fun read.

Ever was kind of bratty, I thought. She was too stuck in the past, not even trying to move forward with her life. She alienated everyone, even her two best friends Miles and Haven. I understand she lost her family in a car accident, but she won't even give her aunt the gratitude she deserves for taking care of Ever. And then, of course, classic case of crush on the mysterious hot new guy...

I do recommend it to anyone not looking for anything not already done before, but is still a good book.

Plot: 3/5
Cover: 5/5
Writing: 4/5
Uniqueness: 4/5
Characters: 3.5/5

title: Poirot on the case again
text: Hercule Poirot is on vacation and meet a couple by the name of Opalsen. Mrs. Opalsen wears lots of jewelry and goe to get a pearl necklace to show Poirot and it turns out the necklace has been stolen. It's up tp Hastings and Poirot to solve the mystery. This is a nice short story.

title: I don't see this helping
text:
This does not help students.

There are fundamental flaws with the ICTS Basic Skills Test system period.
It is not a cheap test to take - it is not covered by grants or scholarships, it is pretty much
out of pocket.

You can use this prep material, the prep material on the ICTS website, or any of the host of other
ICTS 300 test prep books available, but it won't help you.

Why? Because you will never know what you missed on the test.
That's right. ICTS only gives you your numeric score and a pass/fail graph results.
Each test section you took has a results page. They all lead to the exact same page, which is only the graph and number (like Reading - 199). You will never be allowed to see your test answers, never allowed to know what areas in which you are weak.
This is a huge flaw. ICTS claims they can't give back test results because people would cheat. Sounds to me like the only ones cheating are the folks at ICTS. They cheat the students out of any real help this way.

Let's say you scored 180 on the math out of a possible 300 (and the needed 240). Okay, you missed the goal by at least 60 points.
So, where is your weakness? Instead of results that even go so far as to say you got 80% of the algebra questions right, 40% of the geometry questions right and 75% of the basic math right, you get a blanket number with no breakdown. You won't know if you are weak in geometry or some other area. You might have had a perfect score on all the geometry, but messed up the algebra questions, and need to review algebra. You'll never know.

As it is, this is a nice financial racket for ICTS, but only milks the students. The Basic Skills 300 is very expensive to take.
The majority of students now fail this test after the Sep 2010 changes. I don't think a whole set of students suddenly got dumber, but that is what this test would lead someone to think. It keeps a lot of very good students out of their desired major, because without a score of at least 240 on each of the sections of this test, you cannot get into the education programs. Wanted to be a teacher since you were in elementary yourself? Can't think of anything else you've ever wanted to do? well, time to rethink your life, because Illinois has decided for you that if you can't pass their test with random hidden scoring, you can't possibly teach.

What this test DOES do is show who can test well, or who is fresh out of high school.
Those people who love tests as a challenge or personal game to be won will love it. The white-knuckle testers, those
who break out into a sweat when they hear the word "test" will likely fail.
Those who are recent high school graduates will have all of this sort of data fresh on their minds, and probably do okay.
If you are older, it has been a while since you were in school and you want to go back for a teaching certificate
now that your kids are older, good luck with passing! You probably won't be able to get certified in Illinois. After all, there is a
shortage of teachers, IL certainly does not rank highly in national testing results, so instead of helping more students
get into good programs, they keep them at arm's length and lock them out. There are people with master's degrees who cannot
pass this test. Of course, they won't know why either, because of the ICTS policy of not sharing ANYTHING about your test results
with you except the grand total.

Until ICTS can help students know WHAT they missed so they can study harder, it is a total shot in the dark, and both a waste
of money and time. The education programs in the state of Illinois are already very limited in scope and in the amount of space for students. They don't put education as a priority here, in my opinion. I didn't grow up here, thank goodness. But my spouse who did still is lacking in some very basic skills. Much like many states are doing, teachers teach to meet federal funding guidelines, rather than making sure all students have the skills they are trying to teach. They have a tight timeline and can't really spend the time with students like they should - the principal will be on their backs about meeting the school goals for federal funds.
So, ICTS helps to feed the un-education machine here by putting this test as a requirement, with nothing but practice tests to go on - there is NOTHING a student can do to help find out what they are missing on the tests. NOTHING. So, students continue to practice a broad variety of skills in hopes of passing it the next time they take it. Good luck - it's another random shot. You'll still not know what you missed or didn't miss - only the little black and white graph that will tell you if you tested good enough to apply to an education program.

So, to sum up, if you don't pass the test the first time, you won't know why. You can, however, pay even more money out to ICTS for another chance to waste a morning several months later, long after you need to have passed. You can't get into the IL education programs to help you learn to be an effective teacher until you can prove you already know everything and don't need the program.
Yep - if you can do a great job on the test and already HAVE all the skills, then we'll let you into the education program, and you can spend the next two or three years taking classes that might or might not help you actually be a good teacher. But hey - it's only money and time. Those are both endless, right? Right? (And I think we've all had teachers that were very smart themselves, probably passed this test with a great score, but who can't manage to communicate the subject matter to the students, or who makes the students hate the subject after being in one of their classes! What a waste of human resources - this test rules out a lot of very good people who are not strong test takers.)

This test proves NOTHING except showing who is good at taking tests.
It shows NOTHING about the potential to be a great teacher.
You can practice until you see test questions in your sleep, but you still will never know what you need to work on, because
ICTS keeps it all a secret.

title: I was not captivated!
text:
This book is about the bravery of the American Presidents from 1789 to 1989, and how they changed and shaped American policy.

I didn't much enjoy reading this book. I liked the chapters on George Washington and Lincoln (probably because I have read their biographies), but wasn't captivated enough by the stories of the other presidents. I didn't find bravery in many of the stories. Some presidents did shape US policy, but that in itself is not bravery! It was more like self-preservation. I also didn't like the author's style of writing. Furthermore, the chapters are not broken down by the name of presidents, so it is difficult to use this book as a cross-reference.

I would have liked to see chapters on Clinton and Bush junior. Why did the author choose presidents up to 1989 only? Why not up to the present day? This book was after all published in 2007, so Clinton and Bush could have been included.

title: this was not one of his better efforts, but it could have been
text: I've read all of Dick Francis' books and (I believe) also all of those of his son Felix.  While Felix has done an admirable job following in his father's footsteps, this was not one of his better efforts, but it could have been.  The story was interesting and moving along quite well for most of the book.  He did a very good job of getting local details correct which shows excellent research.  Where he misses the boat is on the ending.  It was extremely rushed and felt like he just cobbled something together to be done with it.  It really was a tremendous let down and not at all in keeping with what we have come to expect from the Francis franchise of books.

title: Disappointing
text: How can someone write about the Roma people without knowing that the term "Gypsy" is like the N-word to them? And I 'm sorry that Ms. Ashford didn't grow up eating tortillas and tostadas, but she could easily discover what they are.  These mistakes really distracted from the book.  Otherwise, it felt sketchy and the characters were superficial.

title: Made in China junk
text: Made in China junk

title: Does not meet the objective or definition of the title.
text: Practical Classics, subtitled “50 Reasons to Rerread 50 Books You Haven’t Touched Since High School” by book editor Kevin Smokler purports to examine books that he read in high school and now is rereading as an adult with a different perspective. It is a nice idea, but it does not work for several reasons. First of all, most of us did not read these books in English classes we took in high school. In fact few books are read in their entirety in English classes; plays, poems and anthologies being preferred as they are shorter and thus provide a wider range of reading experiences. Secondly, some of Smokler’s choices are obscure or lesser works and some are not even books.  Rather, the choices seem to be preferences that the author has now in his adult professional capacity.  Third, what you read in high school depends to a large degree on what school you attended and when. Also, it may be nitpicking, but why are these books “practical” classics; how does this term differ from an ordinary classic? Finally, Smokler really does not provide much of a comparison between the experience of reading these works as a teenager and reading them as a mature adult.  Instead each passage includes information about the author and some critical and usually positive commentary about the book, the sort of information that is found in standard book reviews.  In sum, Practical Classics reads more like a series of book reviews than an effort to understand books from two different perspectives. Still, the book may well be worth reading. For one, the author lists works you may not have read and in some cases even heard of. Reading this works now, for the first time, may well be a worthwhile experience. Clearly, Smokler loves books and you may learn to love them as well if you do not already do so.

title: kept reading to find out what would happen
text:
Kathryn and Chris have been together for nine years, when Chris mentions an interest in another woman. Kathryn encourages Chris to go out on a date with Emily and it escalates from there.

Why would Kathryn encourage her boyfriend to go on a date with someone else? Does she feel her relationship is so solid with Chris that even if he goes on a date, or a couple of dates, or it turns into a fling, that their relationship will be fine? It seemed a little crazy.

Kathryn tries to pretend she's cool with it, but it does bother her to see Chris dating Emily.

I kept reading to see where this crazy idea was going to end up. The ending wasn't too surprising. Chris is an idiot.

title: Disappointing book and code on audio signal processing
text:
This book is simply hideous, and if the rating system would let me give it zero stars I would do just that. The text will not enlighten you if you do not understand audio signal processing, and if you already do understand it, nothing will be added to your knowledge. The only thing worthwhile about the book is the table of contents, since it does act as an outline of the subjects you should know, in order, if you intend to learn about digital audio signal processing. Following this table of contents as a guide, you should learn about psychoacoustics, digital signal processing in general, analysis & synthesis of sound, user interface methods, and finally effects specific to sound and compression methods if you wish to call yourself knowledgeable of audio signal processing. Unfortunately, you will learn none of that from this book. Instead, what you get is a sort of wandering novel consisting of the author's memoirs and musings on signal processing subjects. There are virtually no instructive diagrams, no equations, no pseudocode, just page after page of conversational text. Sure, I grant you that the author talks about subjects that I have not found in other texts, but that is part of the whole problem- he just chatters on incessantly about these subjects without being the least bit instructive. Some authors who write useless texts at least include source code on their CD's that partially make up for their lack of talent as writers/instructors. In this case you shall have no such luck. The code is one monolithic ball of lint so deeply entrenched in windows-specific MFC code that it is virtually impossible to unravel. There are no comments to speak of to enlighten you as to what is going on in any of the code. Instead the reader will find comments such as "i suggest somebody to fix that" and "saves typing later".
If you do want to learn about digital audio processing, you might want to take a tip from the table of contents and start with psychoacoustics and pick up the excellent "Music, Cognition, and Computerized Sound: An Introduction to Psychoacoustics" by Perry Cook, which is good enough for self-study. For DSP for the music-centric reader, try "A Digital Signal Processing Primer : With Applications to Digital Audio and Computer Music" by Ken Steiglitz- it is very instructive, has plenty of equations and diagrams, and reads like a novel. Next, for analysis and synthesis of sound, find a copy of "Musical Applications of Microprocessors" by Hal Chamberlain. It was written in 1985, but it is an excellent introduction to sound analysis and synthesis in general and has a very good section on digital filters specific to audio. These three volumes should get you on your way to saying you understand digital audio processing. If you are a more advanced reader, read the two excellent volumes by Udo Zolzer- "Digital Audio Signal Processing" and "DAFX"- in that order.

title: A bit much for me
text: Whereas Sheldon explains everything so you can understand it, this book seemed like it was too indepth.  No disrespect to the author, it was just too much information for me to "grab and go"  on the topics I wanted to learn about.  For now I'll stick to Bicyclings guide to bikes.

title: Suspense, great action scenes, but predictable
text:
Characters

Danny is a decent character. Flawed, trying to do the right thing, and utterly believable. Helen was strong and never a damsel in distress. They were great characters together and I really enjoyed their interactions. I hadn't expected there to be romance in the book and I wasn't sure if it added to or detracted from the book. I won't lie, at times I felt the romance was filler but I enjoyed it. That being said, the biggest issue wasn't with the characters, even though the 'bad guy' was a little over the top at times (almost generic), it was the jarring character POV shifts.

Plot

Predictable. It was interesting, and suspenseful, but it was almost painfully predictable. I thought there was going to be an awesome twist but it didn't happen. I really enjoyed the fight scenes, the author did an excellent job of writing them in such a way that they were easy to follow along.

Overall

I enjoyed it. Besides getting lost a few times on who was talking, or what POV I was in, it was good. There were a few convenient moments that made me think the main character should have been Professor Melchor because without him this entire rescue couldn't have even gotten off the ground. Despite its flaws the writer's depiction of the Philippines was amazing. I was swept away into the setting and loved the overall progression of the novel.

Rating

3 stars.

It was okay. The bad and good balanced out; this was an enjoyable, suspenseful book. It is a 'reset' book that isn't too complicated and is a book you can put in gear and just cruise through. Beware of POV shifts, but that is paired with an engrossing look at the Philippines and awesome action scenes.

title: Unprofessional and Confusing
text:
I loved the books the Whitfields have written on Healing the Inner Child and Boundaries, and stumbled on this by accident. I love the Moody Blues, love their other books, assumed I would love it.

Got the paperback version, and there are charts that are graphically aligned in ways that are extremely difficult to read. The authors weave in their own interpretations of the lyrics, which may be interesting; however I was much troubled by their assertion that the lyrics are in the public domain (I don't believe this to be true); likewise their use of photographs in which the assertion is that many were too old to find/give credits. That's just not how it works, folks. You can't use photos and lyrics without express permission and credits UNLESS the work in is the public domain - and even then you usually have to use credits and cite sources. (Song titles are okay.) My guess is that the band decided not to issue a cease-and-desist because they felt the sales of this book is too small potatoes.

Re: the text itself... mostly free of typos and spelling errors, but (mostly) in sans serif font, which works for e-books, but is non-standard and much harder to read for print books. The content itself is often repetitive and rambling and simply not clear.

I felt like I was on a bad acid trip.

title: Well Written and Interesting - but not Trustworthy
text:
This book is frustrating. It is an interesting subject and it is both well written and well documented. So if you come a cross some factoid that you wonder about - there is enough material in the text (but not in footnotes) that you can trace the topic back to its source. But the tone of the text lends a certain skepticism. Mr. Mann is an advocate not just an observer. He takes the position that the Indians who occupied the Americas before Columbus were good and the Europeans who came across the oceans at the end of the fifteenth century were bad. He has a lot of scholarship but his has a persistent anti-white bias that make the whole book questionable.

Let me give a simple easy to understand example. He writes (on page 136) that the worst calumny against the Aztecs is the charge of human sacrifice. Mann admits that the Aztecs (which he calls the Triple Alliance) did commit human sacrifice but equates it with the Spanish Auto-da-fe. there are several problems with this account. First Human Sacrifice was not and never has been main atrocity attributed to the Aztecs. The Aztec practice that he totally ignores is cannibalism. Secondly the Spanish auto-da-fe kills only a relatively small number of people whereas the Aztec body count in their ceremonies was much larger. And of course many authorities think the reason the Aztecs were constantly at war with their neighbors was for meat.

Wikipedia states that all the victims of the Spanish Inquisition over the entire period of the Counter Reformation were probably only about 3,000 victims. Wikipedia also cites authorities including Victor Davis Hansen that the annual number of human sacrifices by the Aztecs alone was at least 20,000 and may have been as high as 84,000. And you must remember that the Maya and other groups were also holding their own slaughters. The Spanish Inquisition took place for a few years and then stopped. The Mesoamerican human sacrifices took place annually for centuries. Another difference is that the Auto-da-Fe was for adults only whereas the Aztec and the Maya seemed to prefer to sacrifice children. Go to the Yucatan and the tour guides will show the holes where the Maya threw teenagers every year to bring rains.

Most modern readers find it hard to admire the Aztecs because they seem to have been a large scale cannibal culture.

On page 141 Ma section labeled " Assigning Blame". Not surprisingly Mann assigns the decimation of New World Indians to the Europeans who introduced Small Pox and other diseases. But this is a myopic judgement. Small Pox may have begun in China. We can't be sure but we do know that Small Pox decimated China and brought an end to the Han Dynasty. Shortly thereafter Small Pox got to Rome (the Antonine Plague) and brought about the decline of the Roman Empire. Small Pox stayed in Europe and Asia for another thousand years . Not surprisingly when Europeans got across the Atlantic they had no choice but to bring Small Pox with them.

Five hundred years later white people found a cure for Small Pox and exterminated the virus. You would think that whites rather than being blamed, whites should be thanked for their medical science. The Indians in the New World were victims of Smallpox. It destroyed their civilization just as it had earlier destroyed the civilizations of Rome and China. Fortunately white men found a cure.

title: outdated and of limited use
text: This book is really lacking on current or useful information. It's mostly a cursory high-level overview. For anyone seriously interested in web services I'd recommend getting a different book! 271 pages not counting the index or glossary. title: So you want to be a chef
text:
Issue 3 of Lucky Peach continues to be a good read, but this issue isn't as strong or nearly as accessible as the first two. It's the cooks and chefs issue!

What does that even mean? Are there celebrity chefs uttering expletives and regaling us with tales of drunken rampage, cynicism, and life itself? It means that this issue isn't for everyone. Yes, there's cussing. There's also plenty of fantastic stories of and interviews with chefs that range from street food vendors in southeast Asia, to head chefs of Michelin rated restaurants, and everyone in between. There's also some interesting food tossed in for good measure.

If you're someone who is interested in cooking as a career, or wish to have a restaurant of your own some day, this issue is for you. Some of the lessons and warnings you may have heard before, but it's always nice to get a good slap in the face every now and again for a reality check. Especially when it's so well written and in giggle inducing anecdotes. Lucky Peach issue 3 explores a lot of the trials and tribulations of making the career choice of being a cook. "Enroll in the Culinary Institute", they said. "Be a cook, it'll be FUN", they said. Like that old trope on joining the military, being a cook isn't without its share of dangers and unintended consequences. Chang et al share their ideas on what this career (and lifestyle, in many cases), means for them and where they think it's headed. For better or worse.

I'm not a professional chef, nor do I have aspirations of ever being one. I don't know the names of all of the hot restaurants and 85% of the famous chef's names dropped within the first 5 pages. Nor do I care to. There's nothing wrong with people that do follow those things, but my interest in Lucky Peach and food writing stems from a desire to be awesome in finding inspiration to do interesting things in the kitchen, that my family has yet to experience. And that causes a little bit of a disconnect for me with this issue. Entering my 30's, I can totally relate to a lot of the experiences and questions raised when one is figuring out just what the endgame is in any career choice; those things are communicated through the lens of the culinary world in this issue, but they could easily apply to any trade, from porn producer to plumber (same thing?).

Again, it's a great read, but I can see this issue not having as broad appeal as the first two. If you liked the first two issues, buy this. Continue supporting fresh writing and a neat quarterly. If this is the first time for you to read Lucky Peach and are more interested in something like recipes, you might want to get your hands on the earlier issues first.

title: Great premise but execution not so hot
text:
The premise of this book is excellent; a super secret assassin who has no emotion, who thinks logically because he cannot do otherwise, a man who a childhood friend refers to as 'Spock.'

I was enjoying the first half of the book, but then it started to go off the rails. He was entirely too pally-pally with his team, their exploits so-far being confined to one mission really didn't take into account that bad guys can be smart SOBs... Just where it should've started to get really gritty, it became rather simplistic. For uber-experts in their fields, they collectively seemed very naïve.

A pity, I thought. I won't read the back-story book, but I'll read the next book about Noah Wolf when (if) it comes out and make a final determination then, but I can tell you at this point - Mr. Archer is no Russell Blake ('Jet') or Steven Konkoly ('Black Flagged').

title: Illustrations very poor
text: This is my favorite childhood story and from many reviews heard that the woman's translation is much better than the more recent man's translation. Since there was limited availability on her translation, i narrowed it to this one. There is no jacket. But mostly, the black-and-white illustrations look like they've been copied from a copy, and previously copied from a copy. Lost detail. I told the recipient i would like to hand color and ink in the details on these illustrations and apologized for my bad choice and not having enough time to return it before the party. The paper is not high quality. The cover is okay, not what i was hoping for a classic book gift.

title: I hated the characters and the story
text: I hated the characters and the story.  The writing was good, and it is quite popular but I couldn't wait for it to end.

title: Saint Louis is Still in Better Shape Than This Book Ever Was
text:
So Jonathan Franzen is the new greatest American author, huh? With accolades over his latest novel and the cover of Time magazine, I can only assume that he has improved substantially since writing THE 27TH CITY, his first novel. And assume I will continue doing because, to put it mildly, this clunker did not exactly whet my appetite to dig further into his works. It is almost difficult to pull the separate strands apart as to what makes this book really quite bad.

The characters themselves are two-dimensional, none giving us a reason to care what happens to them, and none are drawn very realistically. Bad enough that, but add in numerous minor characters with meaningless connections with everything else, and who add basically nothing to the book except the frustration of taking the reader on meandering tangents, and one cannot help but think that Franzen put them in just to make the book bigger and more ambitious than was warranted.

Franzen, apparently under some belief that his characters are not the only ones who should meander, treats us to prose equally confused. Really, I do not need or even want things just spoon fed to me. But there were times, more than a few, in THE 27TH CITY, when I had to stop and simply figure out which of the (many useless) characters was actually the focus of some such passage. This narrative is more winding than 1970s Latin American magical realism, even more unappetizing on American soil.

And, really, the plot? Truly, and I mean truly, ridiculous. Those pesky Indians coming over to old Saint Lou and just blow the place to smithereens! Helicopter attacks on private homes, bombs exploding in stadiums. Yeah, and no one connects the dots. No FBI figuring out, hey, this is the same type of work done by communist insurgents on the subcontinent, and a bunch of them just moved into town; Hey, maybe there is a connection!! This level of suspension of disbelief is usually reserved for the works of Ray Bradbury but would be a stretch even for a typical John Irving book. That Franzen was clearly trying to write an even more realistic novel makes this plot line all the more ludicrous.

Sometimes I read an author (Ian McEwan comes to mind) and, based on one book, I want to read more. For Jonathan Franzen, THE 27TH CITY had the exact opposite effect. THE CORRECTIONS, FREEDOM? No way, Jose.

title: Damaged
text: Some pages  were outside the binder and damaged. Some of the holes for the binders were damaged due to movement/friction since the pages were not set properly inside the binder. One of the pages was bent and created a crease on the paper,  didn’t expect this for something that is brand new.

title: Depressive-sadistic
text:
The book is incredibly depressive, culminating in a series of chapters that I can only describe as sadistic. A very good original idea of involuntary time-travel kept me reading until the end, because I'm a science finction fan, but it is rather a book about clinical depression, drugs, suicide, torture, and death. Oh, and references to drugs and painkillers look more like advertisement. The story line goes from bad to worse.

I could not sleep well after finishing the book. Now I deeply regret that I read it. Horrible!

title: Not worth purchasing or reading.
text: It’s not a biography/book. It is just an extended version of the author’s biased opinion. People who write biographies or stories about other people have at least some kind of admiration about their subjects. And most importantly knowledge about the person they write about. It’s not the case here. The book lacks both. The author is neither knowledgeable nor has a deep understanding of who Thiel is and why he does what he does. Don’t waste your time and money.

text: This book was like bad fanfiction where no one was believable, especially the main character. It had so many unnecessary sidebars and it and it's characters came across disjointed.

title: OK
text: It is ok--not exactly what I expected but I think I can learn how to do the borders.  I was looking for something a little more simple.

title: ehh
text: This book is fairly dry. I got it as a textbook for class and honestly it is an act of futility. How can you teach someone ethics? I suppose it does a good job of trying to get you to see that ethical thinking comes from every point of view and that your ethical behavior may be against what I consider ethical. But honestly not exactly what I would consider a thrilling read. Basically just something to generate interesting debates and conversation.

title: It's a Mess!
text:
I was so excited to receive this book, specially after seeing its ratings. BIG DISAPPOINTMENT!
This book is a total mess. It looks like something written and illustrated for KIDS. I wish I had looked at the reviews with images. Drawings randomly cover all the pages and the text is scattered all over between the drawings. It's a total mess. I am baffled by the ratings; then, the recipes must be good. I am not interested in finding that out. I will be returning it.

UPDATE (12/31/2022). One of my sons wants to give it a try. By the time he does, the return time frame will be long gone. Well, it is an inexpensive book...
I still think the book is a total mess.

title: Not quite as good as the first two.
text:
This will not be an abnormally long review nor will it have any spoilers. I am going to start with saying this is not a bad book, I am hesitant to give it 3 stars instead of 4 but compared to the other two books it just seemed out of place. Collins achieved her goal of making war look awful. But she lost a lot of what made the first books so captivating. The relationships that are build and continued throughout the first two are what made them so memorable and treasured and this book just does not contain that sort of care for those relationships. I feel peoples personalities are cheapened and made into once faced people.
Now aside from all that, I could not put the book down. If you have read the first two you simply have to read this one to give yourself some closure to this wild ride of a series. It is constantly go go go and it always has you with your fingers on the next page waiting to see what happens next. I would recommend this book to anyone who has read the first two but just be weary, although it is a must read for closure, it is not the same as the first two.

title: Difficult  subject delicately  handled.
text: This review is from someone no longer familiar with kids books. My reviews are generally for grown-ups. Therefore, I've  confined this review to the originality of theme. The story allows and encourages a child to have an open minded approach to the unknown, the unfamiliar and the different, a lesson crucial in these times of division. I recommend the book to anyone wanting to broaden both vision and life acceptance in their children  Carmel has taken this difficult theme and made it approachable with great delicacy. A.R.Donenfeld-Vernoux 5-star reviewed Amazon author.

title: Young lady poet military genius???
text: This book is supposed to be about a war across galaxies that involves humans and other alien races.  There isn't much of a description of the war nor the reasons for the war.  The hero is this young lady that is a poet and is talented with  languages. Through a secret language she can manipulate matter and come up with amazing military tactics. This book just goes on and on discussing languages.  The hero has a relationship with a brain damage criminal that can barely talk, so their attraction doesn't makes much sense. The book is fairly disjointed and incoherent.  I don't understand why it got those Nebula awards.  Perhaps the judges were lady poets that loved the idea of a young lady poet SciFi hero.

title: It was OK

title: rip off alert
text:
1 star only because Amazon doesn't have 0 stars as an option...

Nothing at all in this book resembles the marketing for it or the description for it (the blurb on the dust cover has nothing to do with the content of the book either). Events/characters from the first book - which I enjoyed - are barely mentioned in passing in this one. Anyone buying this, expecting the plot to actually continue - you know, like is kinda sorta *normal* in a sequel - you're out of luck. This looks to be another one of those sci-fi series about to split off into a half a dozen different storylines, with multiple authors *supposedly* co-authoring books with the writer who started the original (you know, like basically every title Baen books publishes, for instance); books which often only vaguely resemble the original work, if at all. Books that I suspect the original authors have little or anything to do with writing.

But, the most damning thing about this book is that it's utterly boring. We get stuck with one of sci-fi writers' favorite tricks to fill pages...a "data dump" on the space navy hierarchy/procedures for a newbie on board Troy and another one on becoming a welder in space. Fills up the pages, for sure. And of zero interest to me.

No thanks. This might be smart marketing for fans of Ringo who buy everything he publishes just because his name is on it, but Mr. Ringo just cost himself whatever his cut would have been from me buying the next one in this series. Unfortunately, this sort of thing is commonplace in publishing today, but it's dishonest and disgusting, and they'll continue doing it with this series without any further purchases by me.

Mr. Ringo should be ashamed of himself to have this published with his name on it.

title: What a Wreck of a Story
text:
[CAUTION CONTAINS SPOILERS]
I've never read anything from this author before, however, the premise of this book really appealed to me. I found the mystique of diving into an ancient earth space vessel that leads to another dimension very intriguing. Especially since said vessel's technology dates backs before a time for its own potential to exist.

Unfortunately, this story didn't intrigued me as I had hoped. I was very disappointed with how the discovery of another dimension was handled. It was so blasé. They find a doorway to another dimension and instead of exploring it, they blow it up? What is the point? Nothing really became of the story. There was lack of a sense of adventure you expect to find with stories that concentrate on exploration of the unknown. There wasn't much action and the heroine spent most of her time thinking, researching books and databases, instead of exploring the final frontier.

I did manage to read this entire book, however, I do admit to skipping through the long-winded parts [which were many]. I gave this book one-star because it wasn't entirely all bad [and because Amazon doesn't allow you to rate a book ZERO stars]. There were a couple of dives that piqued my curiosity but like the rest of the story they all seem to fall flat.

I honestly don't feel like I'm missing out if I banish this series from my reading list. Basically I found this book a waste of my time and I will not be reading book 2 in this series. In addition, this book is way over priced; thank goodness I checked this book out from the library instead of buying it. What a waste of a potentially brilliant storyline.

title: Boring and Poorly Written
text:
This was one of the worst and poorly written books I have ever read. If it were not so short (162 pages), I would have DNF’d it. Perhaps the problem is with the translator, I don’t know, but the book is difficult to read and the prose does not flow well at all.

The story is told in the first person by an unnamed narrator. She lets her daughter move in with her, and her daughter brings her lesbian girlfriend with her as well. This causes great grief with the narrator who feels she did not raise her daughter “properly.” The story also centers around the narrator’s job as a nurse at a nursing home. She is in charge of the care for an elderly patient, but she is prevented from properly caring for this patient by her employer, who ignores the patient’s infected bed sores and forces the narrator to not change the patient’s diaper when it is soiled. This adds more grief to the narrator.

I might have had more empathy for the narrator if her name was provided. As it is, it was difficult to relate to her. The daughter is selfish and a narcissist, who was unlikeable. The only character with any redeeming qualities was Lane, the daughter’s lesbian girlfriend.

Now that you know the narrative, you don’t have to read the book. Not worth the time.

title: Not All That

title: Of historical interest to conservationists. Recommended for library collections
text:
I had very high hopes for Paul Errington's OF WILDERNESS AND WOLVES. After all, I was enthralled by Canadian Farley Mowat's classic, NEVER CRY WOLF, many years ago. But I found the Errington book rather disappointing, mainly because of its awkward, often wooden writing style. While Errington was much respected and widely recognized in his own time as a naturalist and conservationist, writing appears to have been somewhat problematic for him. We learn from editor Matthew Wynn Silvis's Introduction that Errington first wrote OF WILDERNESS AND WOLVES in the sixties, but he was never able to get it published. This University of Iowa Press edition is the first time these essays have been published in book form. Ironically, perhaps the main reason Errington could not get his book published was that it was submitted at about the same time that Mowat's NEVER CRY WOLF (1963) was published. Errington's publishers probably knew that Mowat's book, already enormously successful - and far more readable - would overshadow Errington's work.

And I think they were right. Because far too much of Errington's text - certainly the first hundred-plus pages - are marred by stilted unnatural prose. Here are a couple of examples -

"Complexities in natural relationships have surely been a part of Life as long as Life has been on our planet, and surely Life has been acquiring complexity in relationships as it has been acquiring complexity in its forms."

- or -

"The public generally overrates the population effects of predation upon wild animals, at the same time generally underrating the effects of the less spectacular factors that may operate more fundamentally."

I mean, try reading a few dozen pages of that kind of prose without yawning, I dare you. Especially when what you really wanted - were expecting - was an interesting story of wolves and life in the wilderness. Instead you get what reads like an awkward dissertation or scholarly study. And it IS a scholarly study. I get that. But in reaching for that distinction, Errington made the results of his prodigious research, along with his years of field work and personal observation, simply, well, dull.

For me, the one redeeming section of the book, the one INTERESTING and most readable part, was "Of Wolves and the Big Bog." In that chapter he falls into a much more personal, mostly first-person, mode, telling of a winter he spent as a young man (circa 1921) camping alone, hunting and trapping. He lived in a primitive shack on the northern shore of Upper Red Lake. The Big Bog was -

"... a vast swampy area. There on Minnesota road maps, occupying most of the north central part of the state and extending up to the Canadian border, lay one of the biggest blank spaces in the United States."

Although he hoped to bag a wolf or two that winter, he only caught fleeting glimpses of them. There was plenty of other wildlife available though - lynx, fisher, weasel, muskrat, beaver, bobcat and more - and his traplines were pretty lucrative. He tells too of his loneliness and his friendship with a white-footed mouse that shared his cabin and "cached prune pits in my footwear." Errington's solitary winter in the Big Bog country brought to mind another book I read years ago, Pete Fromm's marvelous memoir, INDIAN CREEK CHRONICLES: A WINTER ALONE IN THE WILDERNESS.

One good chapter, however, does not a great book make. Much of the remainder of the book was something of a slog, seemingly cobbled together, with frequent citations from Aldo Leopold, his son, Starker Leopold, and other noted naturalists, a section about wolves in Scandinavia, and a brief mention of an ongoing study of wolves and moose on Isle Royale in Lake Superior. This latter reference served to remind me how very long ago Errington was writing this book, as numerous studies have since come out about the Isle Royale wolf packs.

Iowa is to be commended for finally bringing Errington's work on wolves into print, because there is, I am sure, plenty of important wolf-and-wilderness data here, and scholars of those subjects will probably find much to ponder. I doubt, however, that the general public will find very much of interest here. Recommended primarily for library collections. (three and a half stars)

- Tim Bazzett, author of the memoir, BOOKLOVER

title: Bummer
text:
I was so excited, empowered and happy after reading conversations with God Book 1 (CWG), that I ran to the book store to see which book I should read next.

One thing I noticed while trying to decide on a book, was that all the books I was checking, started off with the similar statement of "you have been led to get this book by a higher power", not in those exact words, but that was the message. The first time I heard that was when reading (listening to the audiobook) CWG book 1. The first time ever hearing those words felt magical like "it was meant to be, meant for me". Reading it at the beginning of each of the other books I looked through, made me feel foolish.

Because CWG Book 1 was such an awesome experience (I finished it In a few days, then went back to listen to it again). I decided to get another in the CWG series to see if I experienced the same "awe" and purchased the Communion With God audiobook.

I was disappointed with Communion with God, it contradicted some of the things explained in CWG book 1. In CWG book 1, one of the things that gave me comfort was that it stated that when we are lookimg to God for guidance or answers God tries to answer us with signs or by trying to speak to us through our feelings, or giving us ideas\inspiration and if we ignore these even by a song like when we turn on the radio. It stated that God is always communicating with us. However in Communion with God, he states that:

* There are no signs
* God gave us free will for us to do what we want to, therefore God is not going to direct us
* God would not be so cruel as to communicate with us by using signs, if God wanted to communicate with us God would just talk to us directly. Neale states in this book (through the voice of God) that God could present him\herself to us if communication was necessary....

Hmm totally different than what was said in CWG book 1.

Communion with God it states you should not choose masters that tell you that the only way to connect with God is if you buy this or that book or if you follow this religion or that. That you only need to silence your mind and go within... Well as my trip to the library showed.... There are a bunch of CWG books, later when reading Amazon reviews online I even found out about CWG memberships and seminars. While I think it's great that the author found success through his encounter with God, the contradictions in this book made me lose the excitement I felt for the original book.

title: not the most usefull
text:
this book is nice and handy, small enough to fit into a cargo pocket or back pocket on a pair of pants. it does have a nice feature of not only translating the words/phrases to another language, but it also puts the phonographic spelling to, so you can actually say the words and pronounce them correctly.

Other than that, this book is pretty useless. It does not have too many key phrases that are needed during travel. Doesnt help for if someone rattles off an answer to your question in another language...because you will not know what they just said to you. Honestly, you can look up all the key phrases you will need on google translate and make your own cheat sheet, or use a translator app on your phone and it will get you by just fine.

this book does have some nice little culture tips, which is nice for certain countries, but you can look up that online as well and make your own little guide about eye contact and body language or hand shaking in other countries.

title: Don't Waste Your Money
text: It was not my understanding when reading about this book prior to purchasing that it was 4 different stories.  They were each very short and none really had the room for character or plot development.  The first, "And the Angels Shall Sing" was a spin off of the Vigilante series and worked the best of any of them.  For anyone who had not read that series though it would have not made very much sense at all.  Of the  four, the last "A Golden Tree" I thought made the least sense of all.  The story was very disjointed and a lot of it just plain did not work as a story at all.  I was kind of confused at the end of the story and it did not really did not explain the ending at all.  As far as I am concerned it was a complete waste of money.

title: Not Enjoying It
text: This book is VERY detailed, and, in my opinion, goes into too much background that is irrelevant to the story line.  I've been skipping over more pages than I'm reading.  I'm half finished, struggling to get to the end . . .

title: Basic Recipes
text:
I'll start out by saying I like the show, cute family. However this cookbook was a big disappointment. Most recipes are old classics that have been perfected over the years then adjusted as our tastes and diets change. I'm not sure why the classics were redone other than to simplify or dumb down the recipes. The changes don't make the recipes healthier or taste better.

The opening starts with a guide to very common herbs with a taste description: Mint; menthol icy. Parsley; bitter. Clearly a reference for new eaters.

Then there's a guide to seasoning blends using dried spices and herbs, even dried parsley. A heavy dose of dried herbs are used throughout the book even when fresh would taste better. I love using spices, but herbs can so easily be found fresh or grown on a window sill I just don't understand the liberal use of dried herbs, particularly those that change considerably in flavor and nutritional value once dried. Garlic powder, garlic salt, and onion powder is used abundantly. It must be a regional taste preference.

The Friendsgiving casserole is a simplified chicken pot pie but so rich with all the heavy cream, cube of butter and tub of sour cream.

The Chicken Parm is covered in Ritz and mayo. It isn't deep fried, just a skillet fry to crisp it but then mayo/parm is smeared on and sogs it.

I didn't buy the first book. This one had so many positive reviews I bought it, but it honestly confounds me how it got the high ratings. I would suggest this book for beginning cooks but there are so many better first cookbooks out there. The pictures with many recipes are pretty.

title: Disappointing
text:
This is about a boy who, after a near-fatal childhood accident, became an introspective poet. But I did not find it to be something that would pull me into the narrative or learn very much about the character.

The book is small, the typeface as well. No photos other than that on the front. The narratives were detached, seemed to ramble on. This book seemed to be a series of vignettes which sometimes appeared to be illusions or dreams. I could not really relate to the child, nor could I relate to the writer who was more of a disembodied voice than a narrator, or a fly-on-the-wall.

If at least there had been a photo of the child with his favorite dog (as mentioned on one of the opening pages), perhaps it would have added some "body" to this book, but nothing here was really compelling. Nothing really brought us closer to the boy as a child and then a man.

Cloudy writing at best.

title: One Star
text: book was damaged

title: Boring, slow, shallow characters and storyline.
text: I have so many great books by Janet Daily, from my book club days. I love every one of them. That's just one of the reasons I was so disappointed in this one, LONG, TALL, CHRISTMAS.  I was bored, and did not look forward to reading it each night. The characters were dull, uninteresting, and seemed all around shallow to me. I didn't care enough about any of them to keep turning the pages, and the storyline was the same way. Will the UPS man be back with the package of presents? Will they find a real tree? Will Amy stop pouting and crying--not that she didn't have reasons. Will Kylie punish her kids again for being human? Will Kylie grow up? Will Shane decide what he wants in life? Will Hunter meet any new friends? Will Henry and Muriel see the light, albeit after years and years of waste?  Will everyone like what they're eating? Will they be able to get along? Auuuggghhhhh!  It was all such an uncomfortable read. Nothing really going on for an in depth storyline, just the most unpleasant of day to day routine. I have read so many really good Christmas novels, mostly romance,  that this was outstanding for how bad it was. The answers to the questions were as uninteresting as the questions themselves.  This whole book felt rushed and slapped together at the last minute. I agree with the reviewers who don't think Janet Dailey wrote this. It feels like a ghost writer took a sketch of characters and a loose outline,  and then threw it together without any thought or feeling for what he/she was doing or putting out. Probably just for the money.(So bad even the model on the cover is hiding his face, so he won't be identified with any of it. haha) Anyway, I am sorry I didn't like it, but Janet Dailey was a great writer. I refuse to count this one.

title: Extremely wordy
text: This book was way too long and extremely wordy.  The first few sentences felt like tongue twisters.  My daughter lost interest very quickly.

title: I enjoyed it, but I didn’t love it.
text:
3.5 stars

Coming Home to Seashell Harbor is the first book in a new series by Miranda Liasson and I enjoyed it, but I didn’t love it. The hero and heroine were high school sweethearts until he decided to break up with her before she could break up with him, now years later his pro football career was ended early due to an injury and her life is tabloid fodder when she is dumped by her A-lister Hollywood boyfriend for someone else. They both return home at the same time and end up in a competition over the building her grandmother’s pet boarding business is in.

I had a hard time connecting with both of these characters, they were perfectly fine but I honestly felt like we never really got to know them. Tony (Cam) Cammareri came home to get away from the media and try and figure out his next step which he believes is opening a sports bar type establishment in his home town. Hadley Wells has worked saving the reputations of some of Hollywood’s biggest stars but the uproar over her relationship going south sends her packing back to Seashell Harbor where she plans to rest and help her grandmother with her pet boarding business. Both characters just felt a bit flat; Hadley had big dreams as a teenager to save the world, help animals but ended up in a very different career yet she never talked about that change. Cam wanted out of town and knew football was his answer but he has a wonderful family so why was he so anxious to leave? I guess I just felt disconnected from these characters. The other issue was I didn’t feel the heat between them at all, I felt their friendship even at the start when they were in “competition” for Hadley’s grandmother’s building, but no sizzle and this has nothing to do with the behind closed door sex scenes, I read a lot of books like that and sometimes the heat between the characters is so hot that the imagination of what goes on behind those doors is smokin’!

The town, it’s residents, Tony’s family, Hadley’s friends were all interesting and I felt the series was set up well. I actually am looking forward to reading more in this series, but the romance between these two just felt off. I feel bad, I’ve enjoyed Ms. Liasson’s work in the past but this couple didn’t resonate with me even if the rest of the story did.

Review copy provided for a voluntary review.

title: My bad for not reading the whole thing
text: I bought this map for my classroom and missed the fact that part of Guatemala is on one side of the map, and the other part is on the opposite side of the map.  I was hoping to display the whole country at the same time.  My bad for not reading the whole thing!  The quality is good and if you are using it for traveling it will be great, but not so great for my classroom.

title: So close to greatness
text: The book has some great writing, the author is a good story teller for the most part. Unfortunately one of the books biggest strengths is also on of its weakest points: ambiguity. The author uses ambiguity masterfully in some places, leaving readers no option but to let their imaginations run wild. In other places, I couldn’t help but wonder why the main character made certain assumptions (that unfortunately became pivotal to the narrative). The author should have fleshed out one plot point In particular that had me wondering where a particular leap in logic came from, when no rational person would make such an assumption without evidence, evidence that is never provided. Again this assumption was not only correct but pivotal to the main plot; something that felt forced in the end. That being said I would still recommend giving ‘Unspeakable Things’ a read. All In all it was a good read, a good story, but one that could have been just a little better.

It was an intriguing plot and structure, but this book is very dark and gritty with adult themes and rainbows. title: meandering and drawn out
text: great character development, but you never get a sense of what made them fall in love. they seemed to be friends for the entire story and all the sudden they are in love, but not a deep passionate love. this was very difficult and tedious to read and i couldn't wait to finish it so i could move on to something else. btw,the ending was atrocious. for great romance, diana gabaldon and marsha canham rule.

title: Interesting but forgettable
text: I love that this novel did not focus on the Jewish people, but rather the German people and a child at that.  But, the death narrator bothered me a lot as my mind began to wander about him ... like,  if he's death why does he have to physically climb through windows, why is he telling me the ending, why is Leisel so special that he chose her to write about, etc.  He also seemed to put distance between me as reader and the main characters.  The result was that I felt little for these characters, interesting as they were.  It was very well-written and had a great plot, but Mr. Death ruined it for me.

title: Why did I waste my time? SPOILER
text:
This was my first and last by Lisa Scottline. This book is a jumbled up mess. It started off good and kept my interest but went downhill. The first 3/4 of the book are the court case and what happened in the weeks before the court case. It was drawn out way too long and got boring. I almost stopped reading about halfway through but decided to trudge on thinking it might get better. It didn't.

This book is not what I would call a thriller by any means. Well, I was thrilled when it was over but that's not the point.

!!SPOILER ALERT!!!

The book is about a stepdad (Noah) and his court case of the murder of his step daughter. This goes every other chapter, along with the mother (Maggie) and her point of view.

The story goes along very slowly until we find out the step daughter wasn't really the step daughter but an imposter. The real daughter was kidnapped and put in a sex traffic ring. WTH? All of this happens in the last few pages. There was no mention of anything suspicious (besides the murder) until the very end and it was all jammed in 30 pages or so. It was like she added the last chapters of a different book onto this one. It would have been more interesting if this storyline was presented much earlier on.

There were also a few chapters about Noah and his experiences in jail. This added nothing at all to the story and could have been left out completely. I'm not sure where she was going with those chapters but she shouldn't have went there.

Glad it's over, won't read another!

title: Definitely not an intimate biography!
