title: Terrible, Unless You're Looking for an Example of How NOT to Write
text: I have made my living as a professional writer for 30 years, and I can definitively say this is absolutely the worst manual on writing I have ever written. Pyne has some good ideas in here, but they are pretty much the ideas you would find in most writing manuals. The difference is that Pyne buries them in a heaping mass of prose, so his good ideas are easy to miss. What is ironic is that he writes disdainfully about writing tight. I see why he does not care for that approach; he cannot do it. The worst thing about this book is not the lardy writing, though; it's that Pyne uses extended similies and/or metaphors in virtually every paragraph. The resulting prose is exhausting and confusing. This tome is a perfect example of how NOT to write.

title: Too many stories
text: None  worth following.

title: Kendra isn't very likeable.
text: I've read all of the books in this series. Unfortunately, the theme is getting old. Kendra is always very angry and very rude. She 'assists' the FBI but managed to run the investigation, give orders to everyone and makes certain that everyone better hurry to do what she wants. Also, she goes off on her own because she can't wait for anyone to do their job. Hopefully the author will mix things up in the next book and make Kendra a nicer and smarter woman.

title: Disappointing - not what I thought it would be
text:
I wanted to like this. It included three of my favorite things: classic movies, RPGs, and what specifically caught my eye about this title, explorations of how to enhance RPGs with storytelling principles.

Instead, 88% of the content was spent analyzing a few hundred individual beats, one by one, over and over, across three fixed texts. Spoiler alert: Stories have ups and downs.

But what do you do with your beat analysis? How do you apply beat analysis as a GM?

The section that finally got around to that - the reason I bought the book - amounted to less than 1% of the book's content. There are a few general comments and suggestions, and that's it. The book doesn't drill down into methods or techniques for applying beat analysis to RPGs. There are no worked examples of planning or running scenarios for an RPG.

How about applying the beat idea as a player? Well, no, it seems, because it would be "a massive feat of passive-aggressiveness" and "appalling" to look at a GM's story beats. Wow, all that content about beat analysis, including encouragements for you to try it yourself, but suddenly it's appalling to have these thoughts as a player.

Maybe you'd enjoy this book if you want to see a point-by-point deconstruction of Hamlet, Dr. No, or Casablanca because that's what this book mostly is.

title: Must Be Me
text:
"In The Company Of Angels", seems to have captured the feeling of others who have written about the book. N.M. Kelby certainly has written a charming short story but I fail to see what the fuss is about.
The locale she sets her story in is charming, and the metaphors she creates from the town's product are for the most part well done. But there was nothing in this tale that has not appeared in a variety of other forms, and has not taken place during this ever-popular time period.
I appear to be in the minority here, but I found the story too familiar, and at times a bit too precious

title: Good Book!
text:
Ace of Shade is a good book that takes you on a dangerous trip through the shadiest parts of the city of sin and it's a mighty fun trip to be on.
This book is a one that takes you on a ten day trip where the main character learns things are not what she's always thought they were. She meets up with a boy her mother said to look for if she ever was gone too long. Mischief and chaos ensue. This is filled with schemes and trickery as well as assorted gangs and street lords. There are some very intricate storylines involving ownership of ones being in many ways and people have certain abilities they are born with that help (or hinder) them along. It's quite complicated and I don't want to go into detail because I don't want to slip and give anything away! A slew of characters are introduced. All of the characters are quite interesting and each and everyone have such unique personalities they are fun to get to know. The set up and scenery descriptions are perfectly written so you can picture everything from the casinos to the back streets.
I think that as long as you can accept that this all takes place in just ten short days, which most I suppose who pick this up will be able to do, and the books synopsis sounds good to you then you should give it a shot. It's good and I have a feeling by the time more read this and more reviews are added (it's at 70 reviews as I type this one) it will likely be a highly rated book. It's got a very good opening for the next in the series.

title: Too much fluff
text: I watched the show The Terminal List and enjoyed it, so I bought the boxed version of the first three novels.  I didn't care too much for True Believer, because there is too much "extra" in the book, like the first 100 pages.  The writing is ok, but the book needed some serious editing.

title: Limited information for new user of an air fryer.
text: Nothing outstanding.  Run of the mill crank out cook book.

title: Not the best of this series
text: More predictable and a "rambling "  dialog. Midway thru the book I found myself skipping paragraphs, non- essential details just bogging down the flow. It felt like she had to meet a word quota. Not my cup of tea. The first 2 in this series were much much better!

title: This is a VERY short book - finished it in ...
text: This is a VERY short book - finished it in about 1 hour!  But, I must say the presented information was enough to make me seek a more in depth look at these incredible women.

title: Slowly interesting
text: "Stand the Storm" was interesting from a historical perspective but it did not capture much in the way of the personalities of the time or the characters.  While I respected Gabriel and his family, I could not warm up to them.  The book was well written but also one that was very easy to put down.

title: Pretty good information
text: Pretty good information, but not really what I thought.  I wanted a book that discussed opening a clinic as an NP

title: There's a saying...
text:
You know that statement "You can never have too much of a good thing"? Well, you can, and whoever said that clearly never read Tim Curran.

I realize I have praised Curran in the past, and I will still praise him for being such an original and twisted author. He writes like no one else and his stories are like no one else's. In a world where increasingly mundane authors are reaching ridiculous amounts of sales for lackluster books, there are still the underground, clever, and much more talented writers who can still pen something that isn't cookie-cutter and the same old story with different names. Thank God that Tim Curran is one of those kind of guys.

Like "Cannibal Corpse", "The Hive" and "Resurrection", "Hag Night" is pretty much non stop. The action never relents and Curran, being the clever author that he is, always find yet another way to ramp up the violence or the suspense. He can still craft some pretty believable and like-able characters as well. And unlike his other works, you actually liked every character here...well with the exception of Megga, but then again, I think that was pretty well planed as well. The other thing that is clearly evident in all of the author's library, and shown no better than in this one, is the amount of knowledge Curran has for simple things that could otherwise be overlooked. He knows the details of old, 18th century houses, the way life was in those days, and the guy obviously knows his horror films, mentioning bizarre and B-Rated ones that only a true fan of the genre would.

Unfortunately (and I just realized I use that word a lot), it's that originality that comes back to bite "Hag Night." Curran has always been known to scribble down some pretty apt descriptions in his novels. Usually many, many, many times, over and over again. I appreciate new ways to describe things and the more crazy and outlandish the better, but sometimes Curran needs to know when to pull in the reigns a bit and just leave some of it up to our own imagination. Like I did with "Cannibal Corpse", I'll leave you one of his numerous examples of overwrought illustration:

"She saw the hunched, tenebrous form making its way amongst the moss-covered slabs and leaning headstones, gliding through the blowing snow. It had been a woman before the raves of interment, before the cold and fat dormancy of its sleep. But it was no longer a woman. It was an appetite. And this was its primary motivation, the candle that still burned and flickered in the hollow mortuary of its flesh. It glowed with an even, hungry light like a black taper seen through a frosted window. And it was this hunger that would renew it, temake it, rekindle it's pestilental spirit, transform it from a sculpture of mausoleum dust and drifting web into the semblance of a woman again."

Now, I'm all for these kinda details...once in a while. Curran puts these things on every page, often times more than once. I don't know how many times the word "pestilence" was used, or how frequently we, the readers were told about the vampires red eyes or their desires by "feasting on brain and organ, shearing skin and chomping down throat meat."

I'm not gonna say much else about this book or its author. The details are here for you to see. All I'm going to say in closing is that you could do far, far worse in picking an author to read, but don't go for "Hag Night" right off the bat. Try an older one like "Dead Sea" or "Biohazard."

title: Boring
text:
The Sympathizer has been widely praised and received countless awards.
However, for me, this book just did not click. I got to almost to half of it and was unable to find a reason to keep going. I did not find it witty, nor disturbing, nor educational. It was, in plain, terms, boring.

title: i thought the meditations and reflections were focused toward work ...
text: i thought the meditations and reflections were focused toward work and parenting.  although some of the calendar contains it; the majority are feminist quips.  I am not against that; however it is not what I expected.

title: Great concept, horrible story telling
text: The author spends like 5 chapters to spill out one of his points. Yes the book is somewhat relevant to "why popcorn costs so much at the movie theatre." But really, do you really want to spend 12 hours reading just to find out? No.

title: Information about Siri that you might want to know
text: I have used this book a little bit to get started using Siri. However, after some of the basics, like how to get to Siri and how to talk to Siri, it seems one doesn't need it that much.

title: Uh, Did i pick up "Marley and Me" by accident?  It's all about the author and his dog
text:
Ever hear your friends with babies talk on and on about their precious angels? while they drone on, you feign interest but kinda don't care b/c it's not your baby?

Same thing with this book. I was expecting a meaty, fascinating non-fiction insight into the world of a dog. Instead, I got a lot of "all about me, me, me, and my dog Stella" stories that i really don't care to read about. The opening chapters are about acquiring Stella, the author's experience growing up with dogs, his interactions with Stella, how Stella looks at him, etc, all of Stella's trials and tribulations, Stella this, Stella that.

Come ON! when are we going to get to the real non-fiction "meat" of the book? I skip ahead several more chapters, and yes, the author did some research in talking to canine experts about the psychology of dogs, inside a dog's head, various factoids about dog history, but all these nuggets are interspersed with asides about Stella.

The basic chapter structure goes like this:
1) Describe observation of Stella's behavior.
2) Segueway into interesting tidbit of dog info.
3) Go back to Stella: *So that's why she acts that way!*
4) Interview a few experts, add in some quotes
5) Insert anecdote about Stella.

Sorry... i'm sure Stella is lovely, but I want to read about DOGS. Not YOUR dog.

I kept checking the front of the book, thinking, "Did i pick up 'Marley and Me' by accident?"

Editors don't necessarily make the best writers. I adore, worship, and respect New York Mag, and upon hearing that NY Mag Editor John Homans wrote this, thought it'd be good. I wanted a serious book hoping to learn more about dogs. Instead, i couldn't even process that information because he had to insert Stella in throughout the whole book.

title: 😡
text:
Very fragile material
It needs to be treated as porcelain... disappointed!

title: DISAPPOINTED!
text: This book was a big disappointment to me. It tells what the different tools do, but neglects to tell HOW to use them. It's not just clicking on a tool. Very often there are other keys needed in conjunction with it. The book doesn't always say this. It doesn't "walk you through the steps" as Kelby's Lightroom book does. This is a good reference manual for those familiar with elements and need to simply look up something now and then. I'm taking lessons and looked up something I knew how to do. By no means was it clear in the book!

title: Other languages better; Korean fails
text: Own two other Pimsleur languages, and it's likely a statement more about the Korean language than Pimsleur, but this is no where as good as either Japanese or Spanish.  Pronunciation is very difficult to understand, and lessons follow "stock" Pimsleur without additional explanation.  For example, no explanation of how to pronounce the hybrid "R-L" sound; in Japanese lessons this was much easier to comprehend.  Have listened to lesson 1 on three separate occasions and still cannot remember the first phrase, "Do you speak English?"  For this specific language, Pimsleur Basic system fails to explain necessary details.

title: Person on CD sounded like she was speed reading so I gave up within ...
text: Person on CD sounded like she was speed reading so I gave up within a short period of time.  I'll give it another try later.

title: The sweet book my daughter can't sit through
text:
This is a pretty good book with a sweet message. My 10 month old has got fairly high energy and so I've only gotten her to sit through the entire book once or twice. I think maybe she'll enjoy it more when she gets older.

My one big complaint is the flow of the book. It just felt like there were some places where words weren't selected quite right. Almost as if the author had picked out rhyming words and then built the sentences so that the rhymes would land in the right place. There were some definite spots where it felt forced.

Overall though, good book. I'm going to hang onto this one and try again with daughter when she's a little older.

title: So totally unbelievable - not what I expected.
text: I'd read and reviewed another of Debbie Macomber's books and hoped this would be just as good.  It wasn't.  The characters were totally unbelievable, and the story line was almost silly.  I'm glad this was not the the first book of Debbie Macomber's I read or it would probably be my last!

title: Una
text: Una was a good story but took too long to tell.  The ending was abrupt, I would like to have heard how Una adjusted after the war.

title: This item was ok 👌
text: I liked this

title: A Fast Read
text: I enjoyed the book because it kept me guessing about who the Authority was, what caused the fall of the government, what the conditions of the country were. The characters were well developed and the plot was simple and straightforward. The clean language and lack of sexual descriptions make the book suitable for 12 year olds. My problem came when the book ended at 92% (on my Kindle) and the Afterword, which was an unnecessary expression of his political views, completed the book.

title: Disappointing!
text: This book wasn't even close to being realistic.  Typically I love the Alex Cross books but this one wish I had not bothered to purchase!

title: Decent premise - poor execution
text:
Let me prefice this review by saying I love the LLWS. I watch it every year. While I am saddened by the comercialization of it, ESPN still puts on a good show.

This is a book I was excited to see, due to the above mentioned love for the LLWS. However, what follows are 256 pages of boredom. Instead of focusing on one years worth of kids, the author thinks it would be a great idea to jump around, in no particular order, through several stories from different years. This creates a disjointed feel and doesn't allow the book to build any momentum.

The author makes it a point to mention ESPN a couple times in akward fashion. It's only when you realize that the author works for ESPN do those mentions make sense. It comes across as fake and unnecessary.

The actual book has a plodding feel to it. Almost like a short magazine article being stretched into a novel. Some of the individual stories are interesting, but others leave me wondering why they were included in this book. Maybe it was to beef up the page count?

In the end, this book holds a very good premise, but the execution of that premise is severely lacking. Even being a hardcore LLWS fan, I found this book a bore so I can't in good faith recommend it to many other people.

title: Three Stars
text: Not very entertaining

title: Obnoxious and extremely *BORING*
text:
I truly wish I had read some of the negative reviews before buying this book. This is politically correct garbage. Her spiritual quests were the most obnoxious chapters I've ever read in my life which essentially comprise of her deciding she needed to "find" herself in another religion, several poorly written pages of incorrect, water-downed, historical information about her new obsession, finding nothing useful or grounding in the religion, then deciding there is truth in it. Really? Why not have the courage to stand by your original observations?

I can not fathom why there are so many positive reviews for this book - I think most of them must be fake. I'd give this 0 stars if I could. Don't waste your money.

title: incredible
text: really wonderful account of a man's journey to a foreign land. i've read my fair share of books like this and Klitzman is the first person i am not annoyed with in some form or another. He is incredibly aware of the plight of the people he is helping and is concerned not only for the well being of the tribe but the whole system of different tribes that work together around Kuru mountain.

the people who gave this book 3 starts are very close

title: Good but short and more like a magazine.
text:
Its a fun little book with lots of pictures, my son adores Mr Brady and the Patriots. But, we had bought this for a book report, and it turns out this is more of a magazine-style booklet than an actual book about Tom Brady. I wish we had known that ahead of time.
Its ok because we ended up finding an appropriate chapter-style book at the local library for his report, and he still loves this book so we decided not to return it. But yeah- don't make the same mistake I did if you're looking for something book report worthy.

title: Nice Book but Not As Useful As I'd Hoped
text: I took this book with me to Paris and while it was a useful resource for general information and timings of markets, it lacked real usability. It would have been far more helpful to have an aggregated schedule for the markets. Fortunately I realized this ahead of time and made my own. Additionally the descriptions didn't give an accurate feel of what the markets were like. I chose which markets to go to based on how the writers described them and found the markets, while still wonderful, much different than described. The book is based on relationships they made more than being strictly a guidebook and I think that's where it loses its effectiveness. If you're only in Paris a week or two, those relationships won't be something you can experience. This book needs more precise information, more usability, and many more pictures. I found it to be more of a travel journal than a guidebook.

title: Not a bad book at all
text: Not a bad book at all. I got it for my daughter because she was obsessed with the movie, but like everything else, she read it once. Now it sits on the shelf with the rest of the one time reads.

title: Interesting Premise
text:
I have mixed feelings about this book. I did like it — the premise was unique, that depression and suicide is an almost viral epidemic among teenagers and needs to be treated by reprogramming them. But, somehow, I didn’t love the book. Maybe the romance was too predictable? Not sure. It was definitely one of those formulaic bad boy/good girl romances.
However, I did enjoy the world building of the dystopian future and the imagination of the epidemic and the story moved along. The teenagers were definitely the more well rounded characters and it frustrated me that the adults, while trying to prevent suicide in teens, did everything to promote it by not allowing anything but good feelings or off you go to get programmed. Anyone living under that kind of pressure would crack. It just felt like in their protection of kids the adults lost all common sense.

title: Reads like an instruction manual
text: The book reads like an instruction manual to database systems. The examples are terrible and there are numerous logical mistakes within the text—even the answer keys that the professor has is full of errors.

title: Don't bother
text:
This book is full of errors. Look up the errata...it's huge.
You end up beating your head against the wall trying to figure out why the code doesn't work, and it turns out to be the authors' fault.

Shame on them. Head First used to be great resources. If you can't trust the content as early as Chapter 5, why go forward?

I hope to find a good Java book that has some QC behind it.

title: Story Follows A Predictable Path
text:
When a young woman is found dead in an affluent part of Emerson, Massachusetts, those who knew her are reluctant to talk with the police. Eden Perry’s death leads to the investigation of the lives of three teenagers who were partying with her that night. Hannah, soft spoken and filled with anxiety. Jack, rich, popular around school with the reputation of being on the edge. Christopher, always on the outside looking in. As the police hone in on one of them, the others and their parents will do anything to keep the bullseye squarely on the young suspect. Will the truth be told or only the perception of the truth?

Locust Lane went down the predictable path and stayed there, to my disappointment. The author had an opportunity to change the narrative, but instead reached for the cliché. Though the police bias was not overly explained, it was implied. The novel ended exactly where I knew it was going, though it took a long time to get there. Having read other books like Locust Lane in the past, it just did not stand out for me.

The audio version of Locust Lane was well narrated, with veteran voice actress Cassandra Campbell lending her skills. However, this was not enough to propel the novel higher than three stars.

Disclaimer: I was given an Advanced Audio Copy of Locust Lane by NetGalley and the publisher. The decision to listen to and review this book was entirely my own.

title: Not what I was hoping for
text: This book is written well and has good information, but its just not what I was hoping for.  I understand my personal issues affect how I interpret and react to situations.  I am sure that I learned some things from this book -  - but there are some truly difficult interpersonal situations that are not as simple as "I can control myself".  example - incessant whining, victim mentality, lying, ect... I was hoping to find tools to better manage those type of issues

title: Perspectives on Astronomy (with CengageNOW, Virtual Astronomy Labs Printed Access Card)
text: Book itself was in fairly good shape, however it was advertised to have the other book cengageNow and it was missing.

title: Good way to blow a lot of cash.
text: The people that put this pamphlet out are no different then big Pharma they complain about. They should be taken out, and shot. There is no useful information here. No real cures for anything. Way over priced. I might be able to understand four or five dollars. I wouldn't be surprised if it were the Clinton Cartel trying to make more money from it.

title: Great concept, total fail on execution
text: Are the characters all straight out of elementary school? All interactions seem to be along the vein of "I know you are but what am I". The search starts out well but then bogs down in so much "playground rules" convo that it becomes difficult to get from one chapter to the other. If you can look past that the action is adequate.

title: Not that special
text: Just another ABC book with Clifford on the cover. Not advanced enough for children over 3. No story to it.

title: Enjoyable, but not as good as his longer stuff.
text: Short story form, not as much atmosphere or action as the novels. Fairly enjoyable. A morally murky resolution.

title: Not for adults or superfans of the film
text: I'm an adult who grew up in the 80s watching The Dark Crystal regularly on VHS. This book feels like it's aimed at 11-13 year olds. I'm sure I would have enjoyed it at that age but it's not worth reading if you're an old school fan in your 30s or 40s.

title: Too basic and not helpful
text: If you want to get an overview of how various option strategies work then this does the job. If you want to trade options, this book is USELESS. It is written at a high level, gives VERY LITTLE PRACTIAL ADVISE. Having bought this book recently, I am now looking to buy a book that I can actually use.

title: Book writing 101
text:
Being on social media and all, this non-fiction piece is written slightly tangentially (almost as if the author had just pulled together dozens of their blogs!) and probably almost works better as a reference book - i.e. look up the chapter you are interested in and just read that.

While I did enjoy the book, and found some parts to be informing, I feel like Social Media 101 is not entirely user friendly. Being computer savy but not expert, I often found myself floundering when Brogan name dropped and didn't bother explaining anything that would be obvious to a social media user already.

All in all, this is more of an `interesting pointers' book rather than a well constructed thesis on the use of social media. The book could have perhaps been stronger if it had been related to specific business ideas other than just sales pitches. Not a huge burden to read but hardly a light bulb in the dark either.

title: Stupid Ending
text:
This story held my attention until the very end. Then instead of just wrapping it up in a nice package, the author just ruined the entire story with a totally stupid and idiotic ending.

Read the first 95%, then make up your own ending. The last 5% doesn't even fit the rest of the book.

title: Meh
text: Not enough photos. Uninspiring.

title: Not Great
text: This one one of the worst anthologies of BANR I’ve ever read, with the exception of three or four pieces. The best story was “Cat Person” by Kristen Roupenian. Five stars! It prompted me to purchase her book of short stories, “You Know You Want This” which I just started.

title: Manipulative
text:
SPOILERS...This book is about two psychopaths. Claire and Taylor/Amber. The first part of the book is intriguing. The chapters are titled: Now, Before, Then. Amber is in a coma, but it’s really not a coma. Her stalker ex-boyfriend has put a paralytic in her IV. She can hear everything and is aware of everything that goes on around her. (Now) The backstory is great and I slowly started to realize that something was wrong with both women. (Then) But...

The last third of the book does a 180. It literally blows up. Quickly. Everything you thought was true isn’t. The diary entries are written by Claire. (Before) Taylor is Amber. I felt manipulated and angry that I had to reread chapters to understand what the heck is going on. The three stars are for the 2/3 of the book I enjoyed. The suspense was terrific, and it developed in a linear fashion until it all blew up and ruined everything. These psycho women leave a morbid trail behind them. Like when Amber kills Claire...burning her alive and taking her two twin children. Sick.

title: Classic Reacher--which, I fear, is starting to get cliche.
text: Reacher is back in a big-stakes story. That's not necessarily a good thing. Personally, I enjoy the Reacher books where the scope is smaller--local thugs that flaunt their evil just as Reacher happens to be thumbing or Greyhounding through. That's what makes the series for me--it's like Steinbeck's "Travels with Charley" meets Sherlock Holmes. Meets Conan the Barbarian. It's as if David Carradine's character from "Kung Fu" was rewritten for "Wolverine." The big-scope books like "Without Fail" and the latest, "Personal," that's where I usually don't buy all of Reacher's omniscient rampaging. Conspiracies with national security, international jet-setting--that's not Reacher. Not to me. Reacher is ultimately a cop. He just happens to be the size of a professional wrestler with the morality of a samurai in the old west. He has the mind, body, and world-view to understand unnecessary evil and know how to deal with it on its own level. Still (fresh from reading it over a 36 hour period), I can't find too much to hate about it. Possibly because Child has given us a new glimpse into Reacher's past that helps us to understand the antihero's POV. And maybe because there's the classic Reacher monstrous villain (Little Joey). Or maybe it's because we get to see Reacher finally using an iPad or texting. Overall, the stakes seem big, but this ends up being a smaller Reacher story. A "Personal" problem (bad dum shh!) Perhaps that's why I didn't mind the fact that he had secret agents, satellite images, and private jets at his disposal to solve this conflict. Most of it is still classic Reacher, which (unfortunately) is starting to fell less fresh--fairly cliche. The next Reacher book down the pipe will be number 20. I hope we can glimpse more into Reacher's past as Personal provided--while viewing Reacher taking care of business in a new way.

title: Well written coming of age novel.
text:
[Defy the Night] by [Heather and Lydia Munn] was a very telling coming of age story. In fact throughout most of the book I really did not like the main character, Magali. I thought she was selfish and egotistical. I guess that was the point though.

The setting of "free" France during early World War II is something most people are not aware of because it was when most of the world was in denial. The people there fought on silently doing what they could for whom they could. This was not the Resistance as most people know of but perhaps it's predecessor.

The book was very well written and as I stated before the characters definitely had their own personalities. I will be adding this book to my classroom library and recommending it to the school library.

title: On the Edge of Being Good
text:
There are so many things that are wrong with Edge of Evil by J.A. Jance that it is difficult to know where to start. However, let me say that it amazes me that the excellent writer who gives us the wonderful JP Beaumont series can turn around and write something as abysmal as this. Granted, her Joanna Brady series, although fun, also lacks the quality of the Beaumont series, which makes me think that maybe Jance should not be writing female characters.

Okay, first of all, within the first 10 pages I discovered two continuity errors that slipped by the editors. And I found more than a few typos throughout the book. So count sloppy editing as one strike against the book. Second, the plot itself lacks cohesion. Okay, veteran newscaster Alison Reynolds gets bounced from her job because she is too old. Her stupid husband of 7 years, who is a network bigwig, gets mad because she intends to pursue legal action against the TV station. But that's okay because she suddenly learns that her husband is a real sleazebag and has been cheating on her for years so she files for divorce.

But then her best friend from high school goes mysteriously missing and then is found dead, an apparent suicide after receiving a diagnosis of ALS. And although she hasn't seen her friend in at least 2 years, her friend's small children consider her their best friend and unburden themselves to her. And her friend's husband is also a sleazebag who was sleeping around.

But the police don't think the death of the friend is suspicious and are happy to accept it as a suicide. And in the meantime, Alison's college-aged, and too wonderful to be true son, sets her up as a blogger, and her blog immediately attracts a huge audience. The topics on her blog roam the gamut from quack treatments for ALS to spousal abuse to scumbag husbands to the stupidity of the TV station for firing her.

I could go on- I've only touched the surface of the iceberg in hitting at some of the various plot points (there are more). However, here's my down and dirty summation-- if you want to read a book that hops from one discordant plot point to another and never has any cohesion and expects you to suspend belief on every single page- hey, this is the book for you. However, if that doesn't interest you, find one of Jance's Beaumont books. Your brain will thank you.

title: Printed upside down
text: So.... I bought this as a gift for someone. Not only was it packaged ridiculously poorly, the book is bound upside down and backwards. I get that things happen, but for a $33 dollar book, fix it. D&D is supported enough to re-run the printing, or at least realize charging full price for a print accident is bad business.

title: Completely annoyed me
text:
I am surprised by the praise heaped on the 'creativity' of this book. I don't know what is so creative about ripping off a character from one of the greatest books of all time. In any case, Samsa's meeting of famous people through history was nothing but an excuse for Marc Estrin to soap box his liberal agenda, culminating in a nuclear-war protest that I am sure Estrin himself has frequently been a part of.

If you don't share Estrin's political philosophy, once you break through the thin creative veneer, you will find yourself, like I did, very annoyed with this work. Estrin tried to cover his own smug viewpoint through the humility of his character (who is actually somewhat likeable), but it didn't work for me.

[Update April 18, 2007]: When I wrote this review, I knew nothing of Estrin, and drew my conclusions by reading between the lines in the book. I just recently happened accross an online interview of him, and sure enough, he's an anti-war activist. Obviously there is nothing wrong with that, but I think it serves to reinforce my postion on the book. If you share Estrins political viewpoint, you will likely enjoy the novel; if not, you will find it as bad as I did.

title: Formulaic, cliche-laden manuscript doesn't thrill
text:
I admit to making it only through the first 100 pages of this collection of formulaic plots and characters. Essentially this book is a collection of cliches, one laid atop another.

It's a dark and stormy night - literally - and the German submarine launches a spy - a woman, just to give it a modern twist - into the sea. On shore, a man and a woman acting as shore patrol steal a bit of touchy-feely (can't have a man and woman together without sexual tension, right?) and then terror strikes.

Off in the English Isles, a man with a deep, dark past is teaching others how to kill . . .

It doesn't take long - perhaps a half-dozen pages - to realize that you've read all of this before in other novels.

The characters are not only paper-thin, but retreads as well. The plot is so overblown and so filled with holes that it is impossble not to trip over the potholes.

Best to pass this one by.

Jerry

title: Terrific idea, but I wish it was executed better
text:
I love thoughtful and intelligent Christian fiction, so I was excited by the premise of this book and the rest of Kingdom series. It promised to be a Pilgrim’s Progress type of allegory, that paralleled events from Genesis to Revelation. But would it deliver?

In the first book, Kingdom’s Dawn, we meet the main characters Leinad and Tess. After peril arrives when his parents accept gifts from Lucius, they eventually find themselves in slavery, just like Israel in Egypt.

The connections with Biblical characters and events in this story are mostly obvious. Payton & Denin represent Adam and Eve, while other characters drawn from the Bible include Gabrik (angel Gabriel), Lord Fairos (Pharaoh). Leinad (which is “Daniel” spelled backwards), represents several individuals in the first book, namely Seth, Noah, Abram, Joseph and Moses. Arrethrae is Terra Earth spelled backwards, and this technique is used for several names (Benreu = Reuben, Eminafs = Famine), and the Vactor Deluge parallels the Great Flood. And if you can’t figure the connections for yourself, the back of the book has some commentary explaining everything, including the significance of Cedric (believers from Peter to present), Tess (faithful remnant that believes prophets), and of course Leinad (Old Testament prophets from Seth to Malachi).

Does it work? Sadly I don’t think so. I enjoy thoughtful allegory, but it needs to be done carefully and well, and that’s not the case here. The comparisons are just too obvious, that it no longer is a story of its own. What’s more, the allusions to Biblical characters and events are often cheesy, the use of reversed names being a case in point. Cheesy dialogue like "good morning sunshine" clashes with serious subject matter. At one point Leinad and Tess hug, and it all feels more like a cheap romance, rather than a serious story. There are questions and answers at the end, which encourage you to engage with the ideas being allegorized, but these only serve to show that the story can’t really speak for itself, but needs commentary.

To the author’s credit, he appears to have used a thesaurus to include some big words. But quite frankly he’s not a strong writer, and he often makes the mistake of telling us what happens, rather than describe and show it. As a result there is no sense of immersion in the story, and it’s just poor story-telling at best.

In the end, the concept is clever, but it’s just poorly executed. Unfortunately the story often seems overly childish and cheese, and lacks real literary value, despite the attempt to allegorize important truths. The result is that it diminishes and cheapens the important spiritual message it is trying to communicate. Sadly, this is a bad example of Christian fiction, I won’t be reading any more in this series, and can’t recommend it. Instead, read the Narnia Chronicles or Pilgrim’s Progress. (July 2019)

title: Very Good, but not as good as the classic, Alas Babylon.
text: One of my favorite books of all time is Alas, Babylon and after re-reading that, this book on a similar theme was brought to my attention.There is no doubt it is an excellent book, brutally realistic in it's depiction of a section of the United States after a nuclear explosion in the atmosphere, but overall  the book is uneven and not the classic that is Alas, Babylon. This book is told from the viewpoint of only one character, and there are large stretches of the book dealing with meetings taking place where the real action has taken place outside the framework of the story and is only discussed in the meeting. Because of this, we as the reader are not thrust into the action at all. At times actions take place in the book, but we are only brought in afterwards. It doesn't work for me. Alas, Babylon had a main character, but we also got to see the viewpoints of others. This book is also heavy on a military outlook as the survivors need to defend themselves, all very realistic and reasonable, but I really wish it had told the same story but with more angles and viewpoints. While the picture it paints is bleak, I still feel reality would be much worse and a lot less organized then it is in this book.

title: The Good, the Bad
text:
Grade: B-
An e-galley was provided by the publisher in exchange for review consideration.

The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly: Sherlock is big in YA these days, and now middle grade is no exception. It was refreshing to read a middle grade Sherlock remixing, mostly because most YA adaptations end up being just so dark and heavy. Of course, not everything is light in The Great Shelby Holmes, but overall, it was a fun romp that I could see many middle grade readers loving.
I especially liked Watson. He was just so great and normal, and I thought his voice was strong. Shelby grated on my nerves just a little, but not Watson. I enjoyed the references to other Sherlock things. Overall, though, there was just that lack of connection that I need to love a book. The writing does read pretty young, which was a little disappointing.
As far as mysteries go, this one was pretty simple and for some reason, I assumed there would be multiple dog-nappings which I think I would've preferred to the actual plot line. That would've made the book a lot longer, though, and perhaps too complicated for a middle grade book, but I don't know if I could say that for certain.
The Great Shelby Holmes was very clean across the board.

The Verdict: It was good. I'm just not the target audience, so I didn't love it as much as I would've liked to.

title: Worthless book
text: Aside from a few interesting sidelights on journalists' working conditions fifty years ago, in the Dark Ages of news gathering, this book is a complete waste of time. Poorly written, quoting long, unimportant conversations no one could possibly recall in such detail, amateurish in the extreme, this book did not deserve a publisher. What a waste of money and time. It provides some of the flavor of the public consternation felt at the time, but that doesn't compensate for the horrible boredom of the rest of the book. And even those aspects were ruined by incompetent writing skills.

title: Great Photography Poorly Presented
text: The low review is for the book, not the photography. The photography is five star, but the images are too tiny. Even when there is only one image per page the images are usually smaller (often much smaller) than a 3.5" x 5" print. There is a lot of wasted white space on almost every page. This book does have a lot of Christenberry photography, but the tiny image size disappoints.

title: Poetry well worth reading
text:
I was given a review copy of this book by the publisher via NetGalley and voluntarily reviewed it.

Having read and enjoyed the poet’s Whiskey, Words, And A Shovel III, I was delighted to get my hands on the revised edition of the first collection. I enjoyed this collection. I didn’t like it as much as III so it gets a lower rating. The poems deal with the same themes as III and some of them are effective, hard-hitting and emotional. Rin explores themes found repeated multiple times in contemporary poetry: love, loss and heartache. Very little new can be said about these themes but Sin manages it a few times. However, some of the poems didn’t work for me especially the ones describing how a woman feels engaging with the world. These were very cliché. At times I felt some of the poems were too short and lacked depth, so short I’d hasten to call them poems at all. There is some good stuff in Whiskey, Words, And A Shovel I and some not so good stuff so I didn’t completely love it. I would recommend it though.

title: Neighbors
text:
In so many ways Ed Andrews' personal story of mortgage disaster was both more and less than I expected. Busted: Life Inside the Great Mortgage Meltdown presents the embarrassing story of a New York Times economic reporter's personal financial and personal crises of the last few years. One would expect that an educated and informed person would have averted predatory loans and would not have spent so far beyond one's means, but we humans are complicated, and Andrews' story is like that of many others. He divorced, and faced increased expenses by adding his own housing expenses. He remarried, and his costs increased further. Both he and his new wife were reckless with spending and never quite found a productive way of talking about money and spending. For readers who love schadenfreude, Busted will be very satisfying. For fans of reality television, this print version of Cribs might be entertaining. For any reader who wonders about what kind of people get themselves into financial muddles, Andrews and his wife offer some answers but little sympathy because of their selfishness, immaturity and overall recklessness. If these people are our neighbors, the neighborhood is in trouble.

Rating: Two-star (Mildly Recommended)

title: Airplane Reading
text:
Frances Osborne's "The Bolter" is a diverting read, but only within the limited context of its subject matter. After all, is Idina Sackville a particularly interesting character? I think not. She struck me as a dime-a-dozen hedonist and degenerate, who managed to convince herself that her lifestyle was sophisticated and worldly, when it was in fact empty and ghastly. If she were around today, she'd be appearing in amateur porno movies and posting them on the Internet. And the same is true of the whole Happy Valley set. What base and dreary people.

If Osborne had taken a more jaundiced approach, she might have succeeded in painting a deservedly acid portrait of these upper-crust vulgarians. Instead, Osborne has allowed her blood relationship with Idina to corrupt her as a writer. Osborne's portrayal of her relative and the tiresome creeps in her orbit has been romanticized; worse -- softened, sweetened, and sentimentalized to a sickly degree. Quick, somebody, an insulin shot!

An excellent book on these delusional dolts is "White Mischief", by James Fox, which focuses on the fascinating mystery of the murder of Lord Erroll. I believe the book is out of print. A pity, because it's incomparably superior to "The Bolter".

title: Himmmming and Hawwwwwing
text:
I must say that when I saw the reviews for this book I was upset. I really wanted Sophia and Deck to get together. I mean, that's how Brockmann set it up. I had received the book the day before I read the reviews. I was furious that Brockmann decided to change the tide. I wanted to return the book immediately. Well, I got distracted and didn't get to the book for a few days and so I got over my initial anger.

Well, I ended up reading the book. I can't say I wasn't disappointed. Although Brockmann made a good effort of rearranging everything we had hitherto read about Deck, Sophia, and Dave I was left feeling kind of blah. Yeah, the way she wrote it went okay, but the fact that she changed our perception of Deck, Tracy, Dave and Sophia by rearranging their personalities didn't fly true with me. I couldn't get over waiting for Dave to do something completely geeky or for Tracy to do something completely dumb blondish.

I'm disappointed that Brockmann chose to represent the characters one way in previous books, then changed their characters to show different personalities. I realize it is a work of fiction, but the reason most of us read these types of books is for the realism that is represented. When things go way beyond reality (i.e. completely changing your IQ and personality), the book and author loses credibility.

Does this mean I will no longer read Brockmann books? No. But I feel like if it happens again, I might go looking elsewhere for my thrills. I love the troubleshooter series. I've read EVERY one. However, I have a hard time dealing with such an obvious deviation from an originally intended plot. I almost feel deceived. Brockmann led us to believe one thing, but we ended up with something different. The book was good, but you have to completely shut out the voices that are asking "what?" "how is that possible?" "She is so not that smart!" etc.

title: friendly handbook becomes unwieldly textbook
text:
At first I was in denial. It's taken me a while to admit that my spiffy $200 purchase
(aluminum cover plaque= sustainable?) is perhaps not what I would like it to be. I have found a few
useful pages (like the discussion on accessibility requirements)
Otherwise it's difficult to find anything in it , and the page layout is
often abominable....sometimes a title on one page is for a drawing on the next page...
or in the next column.did someone actually check the page layout before it was published?

Such a contrast to the readability of previous editions.

Where the previous editions were chock full of useful information,
this seems to be a theoretical treatise, lacking many useful cross references.
Some of the discussions are very interesting...like the section on
sustainable building...but it is not a good reference book in my experience.

It is a very different animal from its predecessors..

One could argue that I am just too used to the old format...yes....but maybe that's because
it was a good format. I would like to see a free 11.1 update, :-) or at very least
a good cross referenced index made available for $10, not $59.95.

Check it out carefully before you buy....Of course it was written by many intelligent
and knowledgeable people, and you may find it useful, but in a different way from the previous AGS.

title: Magnificent book, absolutely horrible edition
text:
If I were to list the favorite books of my life time of reading -- a list that would include many thousand books -- "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" would be either first or second, vying with Henry Roth's incredible "Call it Sleep". Bottom line, I love this book -- have read it (and listened to it) at least eight or nine times and I'm not done yet. It's my turn-to book when I want the comfort of reading something I know I love.

So why two stars? I bought this particular book for a young friend who doesn't read all that much - she's the "Why are you giving me a book? I already have one" kind of person. But I thought that if ever there was a book that would hook her from the first page, that she would glory in, identify with, day in, day out, this would be it. How could anyone not love, not revel in, the tale of Frannie's incredible life?

Sorry to tell you, that didn't happen -- and I'm still convinced the problem is this particular edition. The book itself is very thick -- which I personally love, but which scared the bejesus out of my young friend. But compounding that, the print is SO TINY!! Why would a publisher do that? Put WIDE margins on the pages, and make the print so small even I -- 20-20 vision! -- had to struggle with it?

The result? It's an intimidating-looking book: so many pages, such little bitty tiny small print. If I'd SEEN this edition myself, I'd never have bought it for my friend -- I could see right away that this would look was too formidable for a non-compulsive reader, no matter how good the story itself was.

Too bad, too bad. I still think this is a great "intro" book for a person who hadn't yet acquired the reading bug, but most definitely not this edition. There are a lot of different editions out there -- pick one of them that LOOK inviting. An edition that has a picture or something on the cover -- AND the traditional back-cover blurb about what this story is all about, something else this edition lacks.

If anyone could make "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" look uninviting, this publisher managed it. What a shame!

title: Perhaps suitable for entry level engineers?
text:
It may be suited for entry entry level engineers, and they find it an interesting read. I didn't learned anything, I am afraid, and was irritated at times when I disagreed with authors opinion that was being passed off as facts.

What bothered me the most is the lack of rigor, for instance, he advocates for incremental design which costs 10-20% and if you don't it will make you 10%-20% slower after some point. The only motivation a graph with no units. It may matter if is 10% or 20%, as that is after all a factor of 2. Also, it's not really clear that once in a while 10% investment, let's call it 45 minutes is a very different cost than a recurring daily 45 minute overhead due to cost being a mess. I don't have any data to dispute the numbers, btw, but on the other hand, I have not seen any studies to support it either, and the author does not tell us where he is getting this from.

His advise of avoiding lots of small functions as it means you will be bouncing all over the place to understand the code is not necessarily wrong. It adds lots of boiler plate, for example. Using an argument from the book itself, however, you could argue that good names and comments would mean you didn't need to read those lower level functions. The counter argument is that smaller functions are much easier to unit test. Then you have the unit test vs integration test discussion of course.

There are 3 chapters on comments. Why?! I am towards the "good code is self-documenting" end of the spectrum, although I would say a lot of comments is often (but certainly not always) a code smell that suggest refactoring using better names, extracting code to function etc. I do like how he describes good comments as either lower or higher level than the code.

The text editor example that runs through most of the book becomes trite. What I find way more interesting is when he talks about his experience with TCL (design mistakes, or the benefits derived from unit test suite), or towards the end RAMCloud and a specific implementation detail.

title: Great series with some additional work
text: By no means am I a professional book critic or do I claim to be. I am just a lover of a good book mainly romance novels. I started the first book on Thursday and was through by Friday. That same Friday I started book two and was done by Saturday. I am now currently on the third book so that should give you an idea of how quick of a read these novels are. I really enjoyed reading these and deciphering what would occur next. However, please bare in mind that these books contain some MAJOR grammatical errors and printing mess up’s in the text. For the amount of money one novel cost and the number of novels in this series I found this to be very irritating and sloppy to say the least. I also found that some of the character issues were drawn out beyond what was necessary which would and did cause many readers to not continue after the second or even first book. I managed to over look these issues because I was already invested in the story line. I do plan on continuing with more books from this series but at these price points it’ll be drawn out to treating myself to 3 books a piece over a duration of months.

title: Nonsensical  words  useless for vocabulary
text:
Advantage: This book is truly extra large print, with the word search grid on one page and the word list on a separate page.

Disadvantage: The words seem to be chosen via a computer program. Many are simply the names of foreign cities such as "Kioto" and "Fukui." These have no translation into Spanish except as the city in Japan. Likewise "borne " is an English word which should be "suportada" in Spanish. I found all of these errors, and more on the FIRST page. Look for another source.

title: Not all about Beck
text: Warning: If you are a true fan who is interested in reading about Beck, you may be disappointed with this book. "Playing with Matches mostly concentrates on his grandfather Al Hansen. This was annoying. I got this book because I'm a true fan who wants to learn and get inside the head of beck which I thought this book would do. There is a short interview with beck but like I said, it centers on his grandfather. I'm sure Al Hansen is an honorable, talented, and creative man who means the world to Beck, and maybe there is a book out there about him but that's not who I was interested in reading about. One other criticism I have is that although there is some great illustrations of Becks artwork, there is no explanation of what any of it is or what any of it means, so you end up looking at his artwork that pretty much has no meaning to the reader. I will not discourage any fans by telling them not to buy this...they still may find this book an entertaining read. For me though, I'll pass this one onto friends that are fans of Beck.

text: I really hate that Michelle and Diana ruined much of this book IMO. Back stabbers aren't my favorite people, and while Michelle's behavior was par for the course, I expected better of Diana.

title: Western-novel fans only
text: I bought this Western novel because I got "hung up" on Western themes for some reason.  I'm a HUGE Lonesome Dove fan.  One of the best books ever.  But most Westerns are just Westerns -- not very good, in my opinion.  So . . . The Searchers might be excellent for Western-novel fans, but it won't be good at all for fans of literary fiction.  Ditto for the movie.  The movie with John Wayne suffers from early-day production, of course, but taking that into account, it's still not very good.

title: Don't be fooled by all the positive reviews
text:
Very over rated. It is a collection of CLI commands organized broadly eg. UNIX, Windows, Wireshark, NMAP. If you have had a job as a SA for a few years, you likely already almost everything in this book. Whats more, each command is only followed by a very short (3-6 word) description. So, if you don't already know what its used for, you probably still wont.

This book is targeted at people who don't have Google available and don't have time to RTFM. What a pathetic assumption. StackOverflow or StackExchange would offer better results, and the man(ual) pages generally include a good examples. Instead of this book, I recommend that you actually RTFM.

title: Too violent for me
text: I really enjoyed the first Asher Benson book and promptly bought the second.  But this one was just too violent for me.  Seemed like hardly a page escaped having corpses strewn everywhere.  And so many of them were innocent citizens - couldn't even get angry with them and justify the deaths.  I liked Asher's personal struggle, but will not be buying any more of the series because I don't like that many gory details.  Might as well go watch Nightmare on Elm Street.

title: form was irritating and lacked climax
text: While starting with wonderful character depth and analysis the further the plot developed the meaning and depth faded. For a mystery many loose ends and rich sub plots left to wither. And FAR too long. I felt cheated. An excellent writer who got carried away with an obscure form. The star charts Meant nothing to me.

title: A slasher film lovers dream in the form of a book
text:
Noelle Ihli’s “The Thicket” is a slasher film lovers dream in the form of a book. A quick read about a Halloween hotspot that turns deadly, you get gruesome deaths, a menacing masked murderer, angsty final girls and a quiet town rocked by tragedy. It’s straight-forward without much depth, but neither are any of our favorite horror films or books centered on the concept of a night of terror. I came for the scares, the screams and the quick pacing and Ihli delivered.

The book gives us multiple perspectives from a victim, a group of girlfriends and the killer. Many of our characters are angsty teens— emotional and horny and up to such antics like brooding over boys, drinking and gossiping. Given the slasher formula, they are doomed. A couple of them have their head on a bit straighter than others—including Norah, who is grieving her brother’s death. It’s fun to predict who may or may not survive. We also get into the head of our killer. I don’t always love when this happens because I think it takes the scare factor down a notch. Once we are in his head it humanizes him and he becomes less scary. I loved the concept of a haunted forest/camp site turned deadly. It’s the perfect setting for a horror story and Ihli does a great job of setting up the scenes with vivid details. You go into this knowing what you’re going to get and I won’t fault it for a lack of depth—it’s a slasher story and while it’s a good one, it definitely lacks layers. It’s exactly as to be expected—the perfect slasher horror formula with new, interesting characters and an epic setting. I’d love to see a book to film adaption. 3.5 stars.

title: BORING
text: hate seems a strong word but these books are always BORING.

title: Three Stars
text: very informative but the recipes are not taste at all. I stop cooking from this book.

title: Would have been 5 stars
text: So much cursing. The F word just ruins a book for me and is so not necessary. I would have rated it a 5 if that had been left out.  Please consider this. Lots of authors write amazing crime books without all the cursing. Then it’s a good book for everyone.

title: Rather Silly
text: Anyone who can't see that a flying machine is being used by the murderers halfway through the story must be brain dead.  It is a very complicated plot for a simple jailbreak, and the "death from the air" aspect of the book is just plain silly.

title: Like the Author, but This Book Was Disappointing
text:
I have read all his books, but this book was disappointing, and did not hold my attention.
It is good to like the characters, and I found both sisters and their life styles disgusting and
trashy, and the mixed up switches with one of them apparently bipolar was tiresome. It
was a dismal, dull book to me, and I forced myself to finish it. Too many deaths and not
enough story line. Also, skipping along with everybody dying, as though that were nothing, and
no riveting or uplifting happenings, left me disliking all the characters and looking for
an interesting and exhilarating book to read.

title: Was a little turned off by the message of "you can return a pet or animal friend if you don't like it".
text: I had high hopes for this book but it's just ok.  Was a little turned off by the message of "you can return a pet or animal friend if you don't like it".

title: Nice pictures
text: It's an okay book. I thought there'd be some rhyming or at least a meter to the words but it's pretty much straight prose. The pictures are interesting and the vocabulary is accurate. I just expected... more.

title: Average
text: Didn't really love this one.  The flow of the storyline didn't do it for me, and I had a tough time staying interested.  It is the type of Audiobook I typically enjoy, but this one isn't one I will tell my friends about.  If you got as a gift or something I would give it a listen, otherwise move on.

title: Not much fun
text: Kind of a lot of work to get through. Disjointed story hoping to be book one of a series. Very little character development and an easily forgettable cast. No place to identify  with the characters.

title: I don't get it
text:
A lot of people claim this book to be a classic. 100% disagree. I disliked this book so much - the writing is hard to follow, makes no sense - that once I was done reading I didn't read any of the notes at the end, which I have always done.
Sadly, it's going to be a long time before I decide to read another Faulkner story, that is if I actually decide to try his writing again.

title: Maybe a Little Too Wholesome
text:
After reading "A Brilliant Night of Stars and Ice" (2022) by this author whom I'd never read anything or heard of before now, I was looking forward to enjoying this book, one of her earlier works which was published in 2018. However, this weak plot was all wrapped up by chapter 14 (there are 21 chapters total) and by that point, for this reader, this book was very much over. This is the first in what is supposed to be a fun, lighthearted even whimsical series about a group of single women who get married off, one by one.

It did start off promising.

A large group of mostly forgettable single women, way past their expiration date for the time period in which it is set, 1815, London England who publish articles about their experiences in the local papers. Except for the main heroine of this novel, Georgiana Allen (Georgie) all of her single friends and fellow Spinsters "with a capital S" were hard to root for or follow thanks to all the stereotypes this book couldn't seem to get away from. There's a "shy" spinster, a "play the field having too much fun to commit" spinster, a "plain and homely" spinster...You get it. And it seemed on every single page one of these women was either: scoffing, smirking, hiding a laugh in her sleeve, choking back a laugh, groaning, snorting or huffing as they discussed their single state with each other, the lack of eligible men and usually doing so with the only male character of any importance in this book, Captain Anthony Sterling. Naturally, Tony is your typical romantic novel male who never looked at another woman in his life until he saw our heroine.

One of Tony's friends wants him to break up the Spinsters, they are throwing off the groove of all the carefree bachelors who don't want to settle and commit. These wholesome women must be stopped! If Tony were to get into their inner circle, get the ringleader Georgie to fall in love with him, then all the eligible maidens in Society would again be fair game for the single men to pursue without the cynical, rain-on-our-parade influence of these old maids who, nevertheless, hold a place of general respect in upper-class Society with their opinions and articles. Not a bad story idea by the author but even a 21st century reader knows such women have NEVER held such a place in culture or society. Childless women who have never married achieve their fame by CHOOSING such a life, which was unheard of in 1815 and these women are most certainly NOT single and childless by choice. They just haven't found a husband yet and are the victims of skewed numbers in the dating circles of their day. Even today, such women never make headlines, are treated like second-class citizens and largely ignored and forgotten by everyone. I'm speaking from personal experience here.

This explains why this book by an LDS author was NOT published by Deseret Book or Covenant like "Brilliant Night" was. Not sure exactly why, maybe because of the weak plot and story idea, maybe the fact one character dropped the forbidden "D" word, the only place in the book I noticed while reading-sorry I can't find the reference. Or perhaps when Georgie and Tony realized they couldn't swipe left and hold out for their nine or ten to come along and decided to get together that they couldn't stop sneaking off into corners to steal kisses and passionate embraces. Nothing offensive, don't worry it was all good, clean wholesome fun but, again, just not as well written as "Brilliant Night" which I highly recommend.

Pick this up if you need something to read but I recommend waiting for this author's next book to come out as published and edited by more professional houses than the one this came from.

title: Therapeutic Writing
text: It's not often that I don't finish a book. I fell in love with Cheryl Strayed after reading Wild and Dear Sugar, so I was looking forward to consuming everything I could get my hands on. It's clear, though, that Torch isn't what made her for a reason. There is nothing wrong with the book, it just isn't very compelling. After reading the other books and being familiar with Strayed's story, I can't help but think of this as more of a therapeutic writing project for her to explore her feelings about her mother's death than a story that we are all to share. Maybe if I had never read the other books, maybe if I didn't know it was the same author, maybe then I would like it. But for now, I'm admitting defeat and putting this one down.

title: Some solid concepts
text:
Update. I have re-read sections of the book, and I get it now. While this will not give you a specific stock-picking system the sections on risk management are very good. I am making this a solid 3 stars as a good read.

----Original Review: The book provided an overview of what a system might consist - an evaluation of your beliefs and expectations. No detailed steps to get there, just some references to the need to develop a aystem, and some plugs for Dr. Tharps study courses on his website - including references to his supertrader program that might cost $40,000 to $50,000.

title: Flimsy and thin paper
