title: Utter Trash
text: Waste of a book! Disappointed Amazon sells it.

title: Wish people in book bathed!
text: Book was interesting but depressing. I’ve read two books by this author and she focuses a lot on odors, sweat and bodily functions. Book left you hanging at the end. Did she get rescued or was she hallucinating?

title: Dry diplomatic history
text: I eagerly bought this book because it's probably the only one dealing with the Sino-vietnamese war of 1979 as its main theme. Although it contains a very thorough overview of the political and diplomatic relations of the two countries from 1947 to 1979, analysing many issues ranging from the Chinese community in Vietnam to the US-Chinese and Soviet-Vietnamese relations, the actual military operations of the war are covered in only 16 pages of a single chapter (number 5). The writing is also completely dry, reminding official diplomatic report. For someone who's looking for a better military account I would recommend "PLA Warfighting" which is much more detailed on the subject, and also "Brother Enemy" by Nayan Chanda which has an easily read narrative, albeit it focuses on the Vietnam invasion of Cambodia (December 1978 - January 1979).

title: Typical Cotton Malone Book
text:
If you've read one Cotton Malone "thriller", it feels like you've read them all.

Berry does a great job of weaving historical fact with plausible historical fiction, which is the formula he copied from Dan Brown. This is a formula that works well for him, as he's made a great career out of it.

Perhaps I'm just growing tired of this formula, as I did not really enjoy this book. I give Berry credit for moving away from the rather open Misogyny of his earlier books, as he clearly did not know how to include female characters in his story without turning the. Into complete monsters. However, the character development is poor, to the point where I'm struggling to like any of the characters. Cotton comes off as obnoxious while everyone else is a liar/con artist.

The rundown of the history of Mormon mistreatment, along with the reasoning as to why Secession is legal/illegal is interesting, but those historical themes are all this book had going for it. I doubt I'll be picking up another Steve Berry book.

title: Confusing
text: I am an avid reader, usually reading a book in one or two days. I really struggled with this book as I found it very confusing with the multitude of characters and the back and forth with the plot. I will say, it did all make sense at the end, however it seemed to take forever to get there.

title: Three Stars
text: I may not do any of these.

title: Feeling cheated
text: Love Diana Gabaldon's writing, including the novellas associated with the Outlander series, but I object to purchasing three stories I've read already just to read two new pieces. It's probably my fault, the description probably said some of the stories were previously published, but the fact that she is republishing old with new is pretty low, especially for the price! Not impressed.

title: Painful to finish.
text: The narrator and her crush are supposed be in middle school, but they talk and act like they are in their twenties. The main character keeps reciting a list of books that are like 30 years old. Not much in this story is relatable for middle school today. Nothing interesting or exciting happens, its way too emo preachy with unrealistically simple answers to hard problems. Didn't like it.

title: I was ready to love this cookbook but I find I never use it
text: Sorry, I was ready to love this cookbook but I find I never use it.  No pretty pictures for one thing and way too much detail.  Not what I was looking for in a good cookbook.

title: PRINT IS TOO SMALL !!!!!
text: Most young people get this kind of information on You-Tube and internet so it's older folks who like to have a hard copy in hand to study. WHY then are the publishers not aware that we need a LARGER PRINT so that we can actually read the book. I can read most of it but the songs that you are suppose to practice are way too small, worthless. A ring binding would be so much better so that you could lay it flat or put it on a music stand to practice. The pictures on how to re-string the instrument are so dark that you can not tell a thing of how to do it. There is some good suggestions so the book is not all bad and my complaints are not with the author - just with his publisher. NO more dummie books for me.

title: A Big Dud, a Small Book
text: While Rothfuss is a masterful writer of epic prose, with this short tale he falls flat.  I was very anxious to read the story of Auri, a minor but fascinating character in his Kingkiller Chronicles, but unfortunately, it's a lot of nothing.  Deadly dull and boring description, and not much else.  I can't believe he would release something like this, and I hope he gets enough feedback not to try something like this again.  Also, the illustrations are terrible.  Even if you're a diehard fan, I can't imagine you liking this as much as The Name of the Wind or The Wise Man's Fear.  Skip this one.

title: Too little about Chris, too much about other people...
text:
I was hoping that this book would be entirely about Chris McCandless, but a huge portion of it was about the author's own personal life, the lives of McCandless' relatives and friends, and other travelers who the author compares to McCandless. I didn't want to read about other people, I wanted Chris's story. And what we actually get of his story is fascinating and riveting. I just wish we got more of it.

I was also perplexed by how many times we got references to Chris's camera and journal, but the entire book is without photos (save one in the very beginning) and almost nothing from the journal (though we get to read a handful of postcard messages and letters). But upon further research, it seems that Chris's family plans to release another book that will include some photos and other material. Why they weren't included in this book puzzles me. I don't want to believe that the family is using this poor kid's tragic story as a money-making machine, but with multiple magazine articles, a book, a film, and another book on the way... one has to wonder. Chris, after all, wasn't especially close to his family.

I would much rather have had a book filled with photos and journal entries, than Krakauer's confusing, wandering tales that jump back and forth in time (we begin the story with Chris's death? why isn't that at the end?). The timeline of the book is so jumbled that I had trouble keeping track of what was happening, where it was, when it was.

So this book gets 3 stars from me. It was too much like a tease - giving bits of Chris's amazing story, then giving me page after page of other, unnecessary "stuff" before going back to Chris again. Whether he was a reckless idiot or an unfortunate philosopher, his story is touching and tragic.

title: Weir excels at science writing and world-creating, but struggles ...
text: Weir excels at science writing and world-creating, but struggles at character building, dialogue, and plot. His effort to write from a woman’s perspective is especially weak and a serious mistake. The dialogue and narration induce eye rolling at times. Weir should stick with what he knows: physics, space, and problem-solving.

title: OK
text:
Thank you to the author, publisher and Net Galley for providing me with a free Ebook ARC of this book in exchange for my review.

I wanted to like this book. The summary sounded good and I wanted to like this book. But the characters were so wrapped up in self deprecating monologues and complaining, I couldn't connect with any of the characters. I didn't care what happened to any of them and just wanted the book to be over. The world does not need more books full of women complaining about their lives/work/bodies/children/partner's - we're full of that, thanks! Let's have some books with women who are positive about their lives! That don't hate their bodies! That love their families!

Maybe I'm the only one looking for that.

2 stars - I didn't like it.

title: Not everything is on it.
text: Nice laminated map that fits in ur pocket. For most part a good map. But alot of business missing. Even my hotel wasn't on map and it's not like it was brand new. Oh yeah I stayed at the Hilton garden in. So it's a good referance, but not for everything. Must of been who payed to be in it? Who knows.

title: Worth reading, but poor writing.
text: To be valued as a unique Japanese-side perspective on the pacific naval camping, but is equally a narcissistic exercise for the author.  He takes every opportunity to buff his reputation down to the silliest of details, and his criticism of Japanese naval strategy and superiors often comes off as petty, all while dismissing Japanese crimes against humanity as "over-exaggerated," referring to the Rape of Nanking.  His own self-criticism is drowned in a sea of fantastic implications, which would have you think he could have chased the American Navy from every corner of the Pacific, had he been given Yamamoto's job.

title: I was deeply disappointed by the words written in this book
text: I was deeply disappointed by the words written in this book.  The writing was well done, but I was offended by all of the profanity.  I have read great books in my lifetime, and it is not necessary to use such language to get your point across.  I was completely turned off by the book and threw in the trash!

title: Not an introduction, but good to get a step further
text:
Deleuze’s way of thinking is notoriously hard to understand. I’m not sure I understand it. This book offers some good guidelines, but I wouldn’t recommend it as an introduction.

In the form of various interviews we get a different angle to Deleuze’s philosophy, such as Anti Oedipus and A Thousand Plateaus. We also get a sense of how Deleuze understands the nature and purpose of philosophical activity.

I really liked the interviews about his reading of Foucault. These interviews are insightful to understand concepts from Foucault’s philosophy, such as subjectivation, truth and archaeology of knowledge, as well as the intersection with Deleuze’s philosophy and connections to Nietzsche.

title: This book is fiction
text: This book is unsubstantiated as history; however as an attempt to recreate the life of ancestors of a certain time, it's okay, basic and simple.  Unfortunately it can't be said these people are either the author or my own ancestors.

title: Less Than Perfect
text:
I bought this book after reading, A Paris Wife, which I truly enjoyed. I thought this would have more of his
family life along with his travels, but I found it to be more of a drinking book with not much substance.
I was disappointed and sorry I spent the money for it since it isn't available as an e book and it wasn't long
enough. I struggled to finish it, and as an avid reader that doesn't happen very often.

Barbara Ryan

title: Unbelievably Silly and One Dimensional
text: So an Irish princess would help an invading wounded viking escape? Really? If you want really good historical fiction, read Bernard Cornwells Saxon Chronicles or his grail series. I don't know if the intent is to attract female readers, but so much of the plot is made totally unbelievable by the ways he does include women. Cornwell has many strong female characters that are believable.

title: Strange writing method
text: I though I would be reading a novel but Kuhn talks directly to the reader.  The story line is OK - not super compelling and definately not one of those "can't put it down books."  But if you like "hit man" stories this one is not that bad.  Just not a writing style that I personally enjoy --but that's just me --I am sure others will.

title: Don't pay full price for it
text: The characters are really irritating. A silly novel about ugly people. No redeeming features.

title: Cute but flawed
text: This is a fairly cute intro to the Boston Tea Party for young elementary kids. I liked the basic premise of the story, the kids doing time travel with their grandmother was fun. It does include some humor which is nice in a children's history book. I was very glad to be reading it to a non-reader so that I could skip the boy calling his sister a dummy and the part about the risk of being put to death for treason. We luckily just grabbed this off a shelf at the library and I'll be happy to return it.

title: phoning it in
text: Come on, Dana. You kind of phoned this one in. And ending on that note was just lazy. I feel let down, not because of what you did to the girls, but for writing such a BLAH story, then ending it on something so high pitched. It didn't have the feel of every other Shugak, which rolled through multiple highs and lows and typically ended with at least some resolution.

title: The 'big reveal' was disappointing.
text:
Liane Moriarty is a popular best-selling author and her latest book, Truly Madly Guilty, garnered a lot of hype and many good reviews. That said, the book was just okay for me.

Set in Sydney, Australia, the story is about an unfortunate incident that occurs during a backyard barbeque. The cookout's hosts are Vid and Tiffany - a rich sociable couple that live in a luxurious home with their 10-year-old daughter Dakota. The guests include the hosts' next-door neighbors Erika and Oliver and their friends Clementine and Sam who bring their two little girls Holly (5) and Ruby (2). The story skips back and forth in time, depicting events before the barbeque, on the day of the barbeque, and after the barbeque.

As the story unfolds we learn the backstories of some of the characters. Erika had a difficult shame-filled childhood with her mother Sylvia, a narcissistic and delusional hoarder. Feeling bad for Erika, Clementine's mother Pam took the girl under her wing and pushed Clementine to be friends with her - which Clementine resented. Erika's husband Oliver also had a dysfunctional childhood, with two alcoholic parents. Thus Erika and Oliver - both damaged - understand each other and have a quiet successful marriage.

Clementine, by contrast, had a happy childhood.....aside from being irritated by Erika's constant presence. Clementine had loving parents, a nice home, and musical talent that was nurtured by her family. Clementine is now a professional cellist, happily married to public relations honcho Sam. Though Clementine and Sam's lives are somewhat fraught - with two small kids, two careers, and Clementine's constant fretting about auditions - the couple meanders along quite happily.

Vid is an electrician who resembles 'Tony Soprano' and Tiffany is a successful property developer with an eye-catching sexy figure. Tiffany unashamedly admits she once worked as a pole dancer to make money for school. The couple enjoy throwing parties and Vid loves to cook - so he serves tasty dishes from recipes he finds on the internet. (I got a yen to try some of his dishes....ha ha ha.)

On the day of the barbeque tension arises early because Erika and Oliver make a request of Clementine and Sam that throws the couple off-kilter. So it's not surprising that there's a little too much drinking and hilarity at the cookout, leading to an unfortunate occurrence. A good part of the book drops hints about the incident at the barbeque, details the emotions and actions of the characters, and relates consequences after the cookout. I have to say - after the HUGE build-up - I found the 'barbeque incident' rather predictable and mundane, and the consequences overblown and unrealistic.

That said there are things I like about the story. It has some clever surprises and twists, and some memorable characters and scenes. For example, Sylvia the hoarder (Erika's mom) is sly, phony, funny....and VERY irritating. And social worker Pam (Clementine's mom) is overly self-righteous in her do-gooding, interfering zeal. At one point Pam gives a dinner party speech that made me (and the book's characters) quite uncomfortable. These behaviors - though squirm inducing - add interest to the story. On the other hand, 5-year-old Holly is a hoot when she sprinkles her conversation with "air quotes" on random words.

The first two-thirds of the book held my attention, after which I was slightly bored. And the story's final scenes didn't ring true to me. I would mildly recommend this book to fans of Liane Moriarty but it's not as good as her earlier work (IMO).

title: Pretty dull
text: The storyline covers two obsessions, which seem to reflect the authors' own, as there is far too much repetition and detail -- especially about railroads -- and too little movement and character development. The plot is clever, but takes too long to get to the point.

text: This 40 page booklet contains relatively little info, much of which is available online as much of it is merely basic information. Further, an additional 30 pages are an advertisement for an unrelated breathing device; this content is wedged into the middle of the very slim booklet. I returned this product, disappointed and surprised at the unforthcoming other reviews posted about the product.

title: She still asks me to buy them because we have not been able to find better quality in the US
text: I buy these books for my 77 year-old mother who loves to keep her mind active. She uses them but complains a lot about the many mistakes the book has. Missing words or words placed in the wrong category. She still asks me to buy them because we have not been able to find better quality in the US, but whenever somebody comes from South America she asks them to bring her a "good one".

title: A History of Modern French Philosophy; Das ist alles.
text: Copleston mixes explanation with critique and the reader often can’t tell which is which. This is the fault of the editor that let his prose, which is rambling and repetitive, be published as is. This is especially true for the chapters on Sartre. It might have been the result of Copleston’s age, for the last chapter is weak, which is unfortunate, since Merleau-Ponty is widely studied today.  Also, the short biography of Albert Camus has errors. Camus was indeed a member of the French Communist Party but was expelled as a result of his sympathy for absurdism and anarchism. He joined several anarchist movements but refused to explain philosophically or rationally the meanings of absurdism or anarchism. He chose the easy way out, writing fiction, which could not be easily criticized, and also offered him a sizable income, to be sure, winning the Noble Prize for literature three years before his death in 1960. Nonetheless, Copleston was well aware of the influence world events had on philosophers and his books are true to this history. Unfortunately, this volume of his History of Philosophy is a misnomer, since it covers only modern French philosophy, which was heavily influenced by Husserl, Heidegger, and other 20th Century German philosophers.

title: A flawed but encouraging first novel
text:
There's no denying the writing style needs improvement. Dialogue is stilted and very narrative. The characters basically say they are going to do something and then do it.

Also, I found a lot of typos near the end of the book. "Your's" instead of "yours", "had" for "hand", that sort of thing. Enough that it was noticeable.

All that said, the story was interesting enough that I wanted to see it through to the end. I did feel vested in the characters and the conclusion is satisfying.

title: This book was fantastically well written I loved every moment of it - but was really disappointed ...
text: This book was fantastically well written I loved every moment of it - but was really disappointed by the ending - wasn't worthy of all that came before. Still a very good read.

title: She's angry
text: I started off with an open mind about this book and for about the first half of it - I realized there are things that White People do without realizing it and it was an eye opener.  But as the book went on, all I sensed was anger and hostility towards white People.  I am so SICK of hearing the term white privilege.  We have no choice into the families or race that we are born.  She seems to be able to read minds and know how and what "white people" think and that's pretty judgmental, especially for being the Christian she claims she is.  She's got a huge chip on her shoulder and is just as racist towards whites that she claims whites are towards blacks.  This book is not a uniter but a divider. title: I Don't Like "I Don't Like Gloria"
text:
I'm not one of these people who thinks every children's book has to be a treacly tome of sunshine and rainbows and unicorns dancing hand in hand with happy endings; far from it, we really enjoy books that take the real emotions kids go through and treat them in a way that lets the kids process them on their own terms.

This is not one of those books. It does not have a redeeming feature or any nuance that makes it good reading for kids, and it's not funny enough to be read by other audiences.

The premise is the dog is jealous of the cat, and the humans are ignoring the dog. OK, fine comic premise. But there's no resolution AT ALL - there's just a rabbit introduced, and now the little girl ignores both the dog and the cat. And then dog and the cat agree they hate the rabbit.

There were places this book could have gone, like the dog and cat learn to play with one another, or they look at the rabbit and realize part of being a family is taking turns getting attention, and so forth, without turning into the aforementioned unicorn-hugfest.

When my five year old read this book -- and we gave it quite a number of spins, with and without adult commentary, because he enjoyed the illustrations -- he processed the negativity but had no appreciation of what might've come next. A book that just focuses on hating somebody else because you're jealous of them is not a good children's book. And it's not funny enough to be read as a joky adult's book or a satire for older children to read, like, say, "Dumb Bunnies" or "Go the @)*$ to Sleep".

Books that provoke kids into purely negative emotions without an appropriately cathartic release are bad books. You might as well take them to an R-rated action movie, where they will at least be entertained by the explosions.

title: Pleasant Diversion for an Afternoon
text:
I enjoyed reading "Don't Lose Her" by Jonathon King, but after I finished, I was left with a sense of dissatisfaction. Private Investigator Max Freeman is called in to investigate the kidnapping of the wife of his best friend, a federal judge who is 8 months pregnant. King head hops from the judge's POV, to Freeman's to the kidnapper's to give the reader a good understanding of what is happening and to allow us to develop sympathy for all who are involved.

King moves the plot along, and it was hard for me to put the book down. I especially enjoyed the setting in the Florida Everglades. Yet, I found the rationale for the kidnapping to be kind of silly, and Freeman largely was a reduced to the role of gofer while his friend Billy, husband of the kidnapped victim, is the one who does the heavy lifting in terms of solving the identify and motive of the people behind the kidnapping-- and he pretty much does it off scene, presenting his conclusions to Freeman as fait accompli.

I don't know that I would read another book in this series, but it was a pleasant enough diversion for an afternoon.

title: Horrible book doctors deeply concerned about.
text: The American Association of Pediatrics ([...]) argues: it "has raised concern among pediatricians because it outlines an infant feeding program that has been associated with failure to thrive (FTT), poor milk supply failure, and involuntary early weaning. A Forsyth Medical Hospital Review Committee, in Winston-Salem N.C., has listed 11 areas in which the program is inadequately supported by conventional medical practice. The Child Abuse Prevention Council of Orange County, Calif., stated its concern after physicians called them with reports of dehydration, slow growth and development, and FTT associated with the program. And on Feb. 8, AAP District IV passed a resolution asking the Academy to investigate "Babywise," determine the extent of its effects on infant health and alert its members, other organizations and parents of its findings."

title: Didn't Clive Read the Galleys?
text: I admit I'm a big Clive Barker, but the first hardcover edition of this book appears to have been rushed to print without anyone reading the galleys, including the author.  And the bottom line is that the buck stops with Mr. Barker, since it is, after all, HIS work.  This book, beyond any doubt, has more copy-editing and typesetting errors than any book I have read in print.  Ever!  At one point, I decided to take notes and filled two pages by the time I was done with the book.  Most of the spelling errors were easy to correct, but took a human to do it -- not an automatic spell-checker.  For example, during one of the orgy sequences, "Roman" is substituted for "Ramon" (when the author obviously intends a reference to Ramon Navarro and not Roman Polanski).  A more serious error involves how the actor Todd Pickett came to hook up with the surgeon who performed botched plastic surgery.  There are two divergent accounts with screwed-up time frames regarding appointments, one that seems to take place before and one after the death of a beloved pet. Obviously, Mr. Barker had done some rewriting here and had forgotten to change what came earlier.  No one else seemed to pick up on this.  The story is enjoyable, with certain similarities to "Weaveworld," but the constant errors are annoying and would deserve a better rating than I have given it if someone (the author? the editor? the copy editor?) had shown enough concern to read through the galleys with a red pencil BEFORE the book was published.

title: The First Angel Book I Didn't Like!!  I loved the others.
text: What I have liked about all the prior books is Angel at his office, directing the murder investigation - with a constant flow of people stopping by his office or on the phone, sharing information and getting new orders, as Angel puts the puzzle together and training his team.  What I don't like about the books is where Angel stupidly faces off with local toughs where he is unarmed and nobody knows where he is, and he ends up in the hospital, having accomplished nothing.  This is apparently meant to be the "adventure" side of the book, and I put up with it because it's usually only 10-20% of the book.  I often skim it.  But THIS book is 80-90% of the confrontations with the local (armed) toughs, multiple trips to the hospital and only 10-20% murder resolution. There is no real team effort even then.  Angel just figures it out on his own.  I'm sorry to see the series take this turn.

text: We purchased this book in the young readers ages 8-13 section at Target. She came to me later a little ways into the book and said that it was too scary for her to read because there was a section where the girl was getting raped.  Not that teen girls shouldn't hear about what rape is and to better know how to protect themselves, but this should come from parents in my opinion, not graphically detailed through some fictional book.  I am just glad that my daughter wasn't 8 years old and reading this!  Bad move on Target's part to put this in such a young age bracket.  I would say 16+ for readers (after having been talked to by a parent about such tragedies).  This just coming from a concerned parent.  We will be taking it back.

title: Stupid people doing stupid things for money
text:
Nerve was not the exciting action packed book I hoped it would be. I had a LOT of problems with it.

Nerve is about an anonymous online game, which is basically truth or dare, without the truth option. Each person can complete dares to earn prizes and money, and the best ones advance to the grand prize round. High school Junior Vee is typically more of a “behind the scenes” type of person, and never dreamed of ever entering Nerve. When she’s snubbed by the boy she likes, she decides she needs a change, and enters Nerve.

The dares get progressively more “intense” until she’s in the final round with 5 other people who all have to play together in order to win. The further she competes in the game, the more she realizes it’s maybe not a game after all.

I really expected Nerve to be more intense than it was. A lot of the dares felt really easy, but Vee reacted like they were the end of the world, and literally cried at almost every dare. It would be one thing if she was being forced to do things she didn’t want to do, but she voluntarily signed up for the game!?! She also has the option to quit, but she’s too obsessed with the prizes to do that. She’s also obsessed with the boy who gets paired as her partner, so she doesn’t want to stop working with him.

The beginning of the book opened with a prologue that I was really intrigued by, but then the book never really answered what happened with the prologue and never touched on it again – it seemed like it was forgotten, and I found myself wishing more of the book was like the intense prologue!

I found the way some of the characters acted to be unrealistic. Vee’s parents grounded her for something that was important, but the dumbest reason to ground someone. It seemed like a really bad reaction to the event, and made me dislike Vee’s parents.

I also hated how many of Vee’s actions revolved around a boy. She gets in a fight with her best friend over a boy, enters the game because of a boy, chooses not to quit the game because of a boy, and so on and so forth. I wanted to shake her and tell her to form her own identity and NOT make it wrapped up in men! You’re worth more than that!

That said, I hated the epilogue. WHY was it necessary for this book to end on a “cliffhanger”? It could easily have been wrapped up, and it left me rolling my eyes.

Overall, I was disappointed by this one. It was a lot of stupid people making idiotic decisions in order to win money and prizes. I felt like the author WANTED to make it like The Hunger Games, but fell way way short. I can’t say I’d recommend this one.

title: The Same Very Average Book Repackaged  Endlessly
text: Bryan Peterson has got it made. Thirty years ago this book came out and it was just average, nothing notable. Seeing all the incredible ratings, I thought there must have been a major rewriting of this book in the intervening years. I can can confirm that this is the same average book from 1990 with a different cover and the same (but updated) relentless name dropping of the latest Nikon cameras. There’s your difference over 30 years. Peterson shamelessly shills for Nikon with an average book that is the same as it was thirty years ago. Don’t believe me? Go to the copyright page and you will see “Copyright 1990, 2004, 2010, 2016”. This book is being returned pronto. Gosh , it wasn’t a good book even n 1990. Cash cow book.

title: Okay read.
text:
This book wasn't what I was expecting. I was expecting a cute love story where the popular boy meets the new girl and they fall in love and everything's great. That is not this book at all.

This book was not worth all the hype honestly. It was an okay book, but there were way too many stereotypes for me. The dumb jock, the sexual cheerleader, the nerdy "cool" kids, it was all too much and seemed a little forced.

One thing I really, really enjoyed about this book is the main character, Ezra's growth. He definitely changed throughout the book and it was for the better. As a reader, I got to see him change from a popular jock to someone who wanted to go to college and do something with his life beyond high school. I also really enjoyed Ezra's voice. The male narration was refreshing and I enjoyed it greatly, but that couldn't save the book from getting three stars.

If you like the idea of a manic pixie dream girl, then this book might be for you. It reminded me of Looking For Alaska by John Green, although I never finished that book. A manic pixie dream girl is basically a girl who comes into a boys life and teaches him about adventures and living life. In The Beginning of Everything the manic pixie dream girl is Cassidy Thorpe. I did not like Cassidy. I felt like she wasn't dealing with her problems the right way and not growing like I felt she should. Her mysterious past was a let down when the reader discovers what it is.

All in all, 3 stars. It was okay and there were parts I enjoyed. But I didn't love it.

Dame Agatha didn't depend on sexual innuendo.  Guess it's back to Will Thomas, Charles Finch and Jane Cleland, who are all, good clean authors.

title: A unique kind of awful
text:
A unique kind of awful. This might very well be the worst book I have ever read. The strange thing is, usually when I dislike a book, I stop reading and choose something else. This book, however, was so unbelievably awful that I couldn't make myself stop. I had to see how much worse is got and I was really really rooting for every single character to die a horrible death.
The two women characters are both dumber than a bag of rocks and the main male character is so terrible that there is no way either of these women would want him, let alone both. I was hoping he would end up murdering them both, then some random character like Jason Voorhees showing up at the 11th hour and killing him. That's how bad the book is, I daydreamed about the characters being murdered.
Add in some sex talk with words like c*** and Daddy, and you've got a nice, flaming crap cocktail. I even wanted the stupid house to explode!
I'm curious to find out who the author really is, because it has to be someone with their foot already in the door. There is no way this book impressed someone so much as to offer this person a contract. Someone's daughter or lover who was blackmailing people... Something! I refuse to believe this crap got published based on its merits alone.
And what the hell is Ron Howard doing with this? His movies have been some real stinkers lately, but this is bottom of the barrel. This will make the Grinch look Oscar worthy.
AVOID AT ALL COST!!!

title: Not so much a guide as a treatise
text: I was looking for a book on inflammation, aging, and diet. This book has a chapter called "The anti-inflammatory diet" that I read first. It taught me a few new things but mostly confirmed that the eating and activity plan that I created for my my husband should help relieve his inflammation problems. That chapter being helpful, I returned to the beginning of the book to read the whole thing. I quickly found myself skimming the pages and looking for interesting tidbits. Overall, I found the writing style tedious, explanations too long, and the little "real life stories" uninteresting. I know this book has many good reviews, so others obviously found what they needed in it. Maybe because I had already read so many books on aging, diet, supplements, disease, etc., I did not find the rest of the book very informative and certainly it wasn't a guide. It contains very detailed information on aging and its physiology. I admire Dr. Weil very much, but this book just didn't provide me with the information I was looking for.

title: ... finished this book only because Faye Kellerman is a best selling author and I was hoping to find out ...
text: I finished this book only because Faye Kellerman is a best selling author and I was hoping to find out why. I did not.  I enjoy historical fiction; this book is certainly fiction, the historical part is more doubtful.  Many reviewers mention that it strains credulity.  No question.  Most of the premises are ridiculous.  My favorite historical mystery writer, Margaret Frazer, has died and I would love to find another of her caliber.  Kellerman is not one.  This book was plodding most of the time, with brief periods of frenetic action and graphic horror and gore that I had to skip over.  I read pretty much all the reviews to find out if this book was representative of her work.  It seems that it probably is not, but not for the reasons that would have me pick up another of her books.

I really don't think an instructional manual should be sarcastic at all.  It is also a bit condescending to those who are just starting out.

title: Orphanage turned mental asylum
text:
Maggie is constantly torn between her English father and French mother and in Quebec, the divide is huge. Maggie falls in love with a poor French boy and becomes pregnant at 15. Her parents force her to give up Elodie for adoption. The book alternates between Elodie's life in the orphanage, later turned into an asylum, and Maggie's life.

This was an interesting story, particularly how the orphanage was turned into a mental asylum and the orphans were labeled mentally incompetent - purely for money. My biggest problem with this book was the time transitions. Some of the chapters had dates, most did not. Most of the time I was left guessing how much time had passed, which was pretty frustrating.

text:
What can you learn in 32 pages? The topic of Latin bass is huge and to cover it in so few pages is like covering the history of the Americas in 50 pages. Its going to be sweeping with generalizations.

The books by Oscar Stagnaro, Carlos del Puerto or Manny Pati¤o cover this material in much greater depth.

The positive is that it tries to convey the rhythms and understanding of the various forms. But these go so fast that you'll only get taste.

Why would someone buy this book? If you were unsure what the heck you were doing in Latin Bass or if you were unsure if you wanted to go into Latin Bass. This book is very cheap with a CD on Amazon so you can buy it and see if wanted to go deeper. You might just want to learn some new rhythms to expand your bass playing a bit with a little sprinkling of Latin flavors. This book could help you with that.

title: Pre-Storyville
text:
New Orleans certainly boasts a colorful history, what with Andrew Jackson and pirate Jean Lafitte teaming to defeat the British at the close of the War of 1812 (actually after the Treaty of Ghent had been signed, so technically after the war had ended), the city constantly battling the encroachment of Gulf waters, and, the subject of this book, the confinement of prostitution and bordellos to a red-light district. While many cities have had formal red-light districts (and some still do, like Amsterdam and many German cities), New Orleans’ version has always held a sort of romantic appeal, perhaps because of its nickname, “Storyville,” or that it is way back in history.

Lynn and Martin attempt to resurrect the period, really 1898, the time leading up to the inauguration of the district, by novelizing the life of a young prostitute. While interesting and definitely portraying the misery that was (and is) street prostitution, it’s never as compelling as you might expect a novel on this topic to be. Truth be told, it’s kind of flat. Lynn and Martin might have done better by shortening the build-up to the instituting of the district and lengthening the portion devoted to the district.

In fact, there was a real Mary Deubler, the central character. She, however, wasn’t nearly as downtrodden and hapless as her novelized version. She proved a quite shrewd entrepreneurial type who did operate a house called the Arlington, who even in short biographical sketches sounds intriguing. Probably many of the characters who have basis in history, like Tom Anderson and Lulu White, were more interesting than as Lynn and Martin portray them. Which highlights the weakness of their novelized approach, weak characterizations.

In the end, Madam isn’t really the place to seek out information about or titillation from Storyville. Those wishing to pursue these might try a source cited as a favorite by the authors, Storyville, New Orleans: Being an Authentic, Illustrated Account of the Notorious Red Light District and the extant photographic work of E.J Bellocq, E.J. Bellocq Storyville Portraits, as well as novels using the period and location as a backdrop.

text:

Overall, it read more like a YA romance than a contemporary romance, to me. Some of the description of events and places just felt like too much. I couldn't help put feel that the author had never actually been in a school. It all seemed just - wrong. I also had a hard time trying to connect or care about any of the characters.

Overall, I wanted to like the book just just couldn't. But I'm willing to admit that maybe, as much as I wanted a light read right now for a break from the world, this wasn't the right time to read the book. Or I'm simply not the right audience.
A 2 star rating for me means that the book was ok, but I didn't really like it, and it won't really be memorable to me at all. I feel bad rating ARC books this way, but I was asked for my honest review.

title: The Dating World Through A Guy's Eyes - Nice for a Change
text:
When I first saw this book, I had the title in my mind as Great Expectations which reminded me as a Classic novel , and I thought possibly it would be a rendition but it turned out to be something very different indeed. Greater Expectations is a romantic comedy book told through the view of a male called only as "Z". It starts off with a simple statistic about people divorcing over christmas and I was like hmmm, I liked that part as being a fan of random facts myself and then it moved to a neighbour telling a story and I was like - this is odd as to me it didn't really fit and I started to feel a bit confused. But, as the book moved on we read as "Z" started to hook back into the dating game and we read of all his up's and downs in the dating world. What was interesting as a reader is that this book is all told through the male perspective and we get a glimpse into the relationship basics of what it's like through the guy's eyes. I do admit being a female and reading this book in parts was quite difficult as the humor was definitely guy's humor and I was like hmmm, ok that's just cringeworthy and not worth talking about e.g jerking off etc. But overall, it was an eye-opener reading this book and glancing from the male's point of view and also written by a male as in the world of romance fiction, it is very rare to have a book with this content written by a male author.
So readers, if you are wanting the "LAD" point of view on relationships and wanting to catch a glimpse of what goes on in your guy's head , then check out Greater Expectations by Alexander McCabe and you will not be disappointed.

title: Lovely writing, but unsatisfying
text: The writing kept me engaged, but the stories of the 3 women are ultimately not very compelling.  Their expatriate status is not really central to the story; the plot points could have happened to them anywhere.  One is truly the victim of a horrible tragedy, and the descriptions of her grief are very well done.  The other two see themselves as victims because they choose to be "floaters" -- they exercise no personal agency, take no responsibility for their bad choices or complacency or indecisiveness, and just allow life to happen to them.  The ending is sudden, sentimental and pat, with an idealized view of motherhood as the ultimate calling and solution to all life's problems. I feel sorry for the kids.

title: Continuing Story of Deputy Coroner Clay Edison
text:
Ballantine Books and NetGalley provided me with an electronic copy of Half Moon Bay. I voluntarily chose to review this book and my opinion is freely given.

Deputy Coroner Clay Edison has a new baby and is working the graveyard shift so that someone is always home with the little girl. Clay gets called in to investigate a skeleton that was uncovered when workers were demolishing a local park. A call soon after, with a possible identification, leads Clay on a long pursuit to find the truth.

Having read the other books in this series, I was disappointed in the lack of progression of the character of Clay Edison. This novel was unnecessarily convoluted, with elements of the plot that did nothing to progress either the characters or the story as a whole. Had the book been edited down by around 75 pages, Half Moon Bay would have been a better read. Overall, I liked the novel, but I cannot say that I will remember it a few months from now. For these reasons, I would be hesitant to recommend Half Moon Bay to other readers.

title: Mistaken Methodical Assumption from the outset...
text: The author makes the fallacious claim that "the correct translation begins with a correct understanding of the alphabet," though it begs the question whether the Torah was revealed to Israel using the ancient Phoenician (or even Canaanite) script...  A better hermeneutical principle is that the alphabet is a tool that expresses the thoughts of a particular community, and therefore that alphabets evolve over time.  The proper interpretative principle is therefore to understand how the alphabet was used in relation to writing using that script, in terms of its historical context and the intent of the original author.

title: Interesting read
text:
A free e-book in exchange for an honest review.

This was not what I was expecting… As literary fiction it is driven forward by the characters and this left me underwhelmed most the time. The story focuses on four siblings and their various reactions to a prophecy of their death days. It brings to question destiny and if you can change the outcome or if its all self-fulfilling prophecies. Nothing is fully answered or even discussed, just briefly mentioned.
It was interesting to see the various reactions to their noted death days. Especially since we were never told how they would die it made you question did their choices lead to death or they would have died regardless. Overall though, I didn’t really care about any of the characters. The first two stories being the least interesting made it even more of a struggle. Bits and pieces were interesting but their overall lives were very boring to me. Even the side characters were rather dull and added very little to the overall story.
Something I absolutely hated, the random sexualized text. The story opens with a thirteen year old being introduced by the status of her pubic hair. Another scene adult Klara is skinny dipping and her “pubic hair blooms” before she dives in. Seriously… just why. What does women’s pubic hair have anything to do with a girl walking up steps or a woman diving into a pool.

text: Well, this would be a really interesting cook book if the editors and author had done their editing jobs. The mistakes make several recipes impossible to make unless you look up the corrected recipes online- some of which don't even resemble the recipe in the book. For example, the brownie recpe in the book calls for steeping the cocoa- but gives you no volume of the water ("tk" is not a volume measure). However, when you spend some time searching the web for the corrected recipe and finally find it, there is no steeping of the cocoa at all! That's a MAJOR error- not just a typo. If you want this book, wait until it is re-edited... or buy something else.

There could have been so many great reasons for this but the one that the other chose didn't pass the suspension of disbelief in the major twists and turns. It just got messy. Too messy. There were mental health issues used which just ruined it all for me. And I just couldn't believe that the girls were kept that isolated from the world they didn't know bare basics. title: Doesn't live up to the restaurant
text:
I have fond memories of Uglesich's from when I lived in New Orleans. It was an institution. Unfortunately, the cookbook doesn't do the restaurant or the family justice. In fact, the cookbook is just weird. I don't know how else to explain it. Many of the recipes are for large, large quantities and need to be modified to serve 4-6. Others have glaring typos (egg "yokes," anyone?). The few photos are blurry. Some recipes seem to be missing a step or two. The cookbook seems not to have been edited by a cookbook editor. These sorts of things bug me, but I realize that not everyone may be bothered by this.

What the cookbook does have is recipes that made the restaurant famous, and lots of historical tidbits about the family and its suppliers. For that, it deserves a few stars.

title: Jeff Shaara has JUMPED THE SHARK
text:
In the To the Reader section Jeff explains, ". . . this is not a history book." He's not kidding this is more of a work of fiction by a much lesser writer than Jeff Shaara. The book starts with Doolittle's raid on Japan. Doolittle's co-pilot, instead of being a respected comrade who had won the confidence of the mission commander reads like Gomer Pyle's, golly gee Sergeant Carter. Take for example this important exchange between the two officers. "Keep your eyes on the flight deck, Lieutenant. He's in charge." "I see him, sir. The sailor. Guy with the flag. He's gotta be miserable. Hope he don't fall off the ship."

This scintillating dialogue continues for another 350 pages.

The characters are flat, predictable; with the eccentric code officer; the beloved squadron commander who is killed in a training accident; Japan stuck in its unwritten Samurai code; commanders of both countries who are presented as depressives rather those with the steady, engineer-like personalities who remain calm and composed no matter the situation.

I don't know if Shaara has lost the fire in his belly, whether the publisher in pushing for more stuff to publish than Jeff can produce and maintain his previous believable voice. Something's gone way wrong and it's a shame to lose a writer like Jeff Shaara.

PS If you prefer a paperback form of book be aware that in fine print it says LARGE PRINT.

title: Introduction to the Calculus - Herstein, Sandler
text:
My earlier aquaintence with I.N. Herstein is through his Topics in Algebra (1964, 2nd edition 1975) which was my first encounter with abstract algebra. In 1971, Herstein's Introduction to Calculus was published, written with Reuben Sandler. There were no further editions. This is not a typical calculus textbook and I wonder how popular it was in its day. The book is cramped and plodding, verbose and tedious. Their intentions, however, were admirable enough.

"There has been a tendency in the last 10-15 years to do the calculus for the beginner in a completely formal, rigorous, and - to our minds - stilted way. This preoccupation with detail and technique of proof, rather than with the basic ideas involved, have made a dark mystery out of concepts which are essentially clear and simple. The student, unaware of the basic direction of the subject, confuses the detail of rigorizing an argument with the fundamental ideas being developed. In consequence, the average student, upon finishing his first year of calculus, has neither a full and coherent picture of what the subject is about, nor a mature understanding of mathematical technique and rigor. His ability to use the reasoning and results of the calculus - and let's never forget that the calculus was devised to handle large classes of problems in and out of mathematics - unfortunately is too limited by this formalistic approach.

"Our motivation for writing this book is a desire to fight this recent trend. In this we are certainly not the first - in recent years a fine attempt in this direction was made by Serge Lang. It should be pointed out that the calculus was taught unrigorously for the largest part of this century; unrigorously, but, unfortunately, too often sloppily. One can give an intuitive approach to the subject which is honest and correct without being sloppy, if one limits one's attention to well-behaved functions. Fortunately, such well-behaved functions exist in abundance and are, in fact, the functions that arise in the basic material of mathematics, engineering, physics, chemistry, and many other fields.

"We have tried to be completely intuitive and to motivate the various ideas and concepts introduced. But there are times when one must get down to the fine points of an argument in order to give an honest presentation.... All in all, we have tried to keep a uniformly intuitive approach, paying as little heed to formalism and rigor as possible without distorting matters."

That "fine attempt" by Serge Lang has faired far better than the effort of Herstein and Sandler. Lang's calculus books (his "First Course" was already in a 2nd edition by 1971) are enduring classics and still in print. Others from that period, and still going strong, include texts by Salas and Hille, George Thomas, Thomas Apostol, and Michael Spivak.

This book by Herstein and Sandler is probably nobody's idea of a classic. They essentially talk you through single-variable calculus. Their approach is to pretend to discover the methods of calculus through "intuition" and futzing about. The book is laid out in block paragraphs cluttered with mathematical notation without any offsetting emphasis of formulas, theorems, or especially significant information. With extremely few exceptions, every bit of mathematics in this book is written within the linear confines of a prose sentence embedded within a multi-sentence paragraph. The page layout in this book is annoying.

Here's what the blurb on the dust jacket says: "This text presents a short, intuitive treatment of the one-variable calculus. The approach, although careful and honest, does not emphasize rigor, but instead makes great use of heuristic arguments. In preference to the theorem-proof format, plausibility arguments that easily convert into formal proofs are described in a smooth, free-flowing narrative style. Analytic geometry is presented through examples rather than formal presentations. Key points are summarized at the end of each section. In the last chapter, the notion of limits is rigorously defined and used to give proofs of the more important theorems found earlier in the book and to indicate a general way of rendering rigorous the subject matter of calculus."

I came upon a second-hand copy of this in a local bookstore and bought it, despite the cluttered blocks of text I saw on the pages, because of a good price and Herstein's name on the cover. I thought it'd be okay. His algebra book does alright. But getting the book out recently and trying to read it, I find after little less than 60 pages, and some impatient skimming ahead, that I simply cannot endure it any longer. I do not recommend this book. Those of you who think Stewart is bad (and I agree with you), try choking down this one.

title: Doesn't exactly soar
text:
Having just enjoyed "Hawk Quest", by Robert Lyndon, I allowed myself to be lured into ordering another falconry-centric historical fiction Vine selection. Unfortunately, this is one book I'll have to cut loose and whistle down the wind.

Unlike Lyndon, author Katia Fox knows little or nothing about falconry. My husband is a fireman, and he refuses to watch firefighting-themed movies because they're so annoyingly unrealistic. That's how I felt when I started reading this book. The main character, William, rescues a falcon that has been injured while trying to subdue its prey. William is a young kid who gathers up the falcon in his cloak, sneaks it home and hides it in an outbuilding, where he treats the bird's injuries. All with no training, no equipment, no knowledge of animal husbandry (or maybe this was established in the first part of this series, which I haven't read). We are introduced to a falcon as tame and harmless as a golden retriever puppy.

The characters are flat and predictable. The dialogue is stilted. The author would have greatly benefited from an editor willing to ruthlessly cut away some of the overblown language and pare this book down by at least 200 pages.

I like accurate historical fiction, and I think this particular series could have been a great introduction to 12th Century England, especially for a young person who thinks history is boring and overrated. Too bad the book didn't rise to my expectations. Maybe someone who knows less about falconry would enjoy the story more than I did.

title: This book is ultimately not very instructive about just war - Fourth Edition: Terrible wine in a new bottle
text:
At a lecture at West Point United States Military Academy April 6, 2006, Naom Chomsky argued, "Just war theory" literature "deserves special attention but is ultimately not very instructive about just war". "Just war theory" is "declarations of personal preference", which "never tells you anything. It doesn't tell you when it is proper to intervene, what it tells you is 'I think it is proper to intervene'...there is a big gap between assertion and argument, between surmise and evidence." "We learn very little about just war from 'Just war theory'" what we do learn is "mostly about the prevailing moral and intellectual climate in which we live." Walzer's book relies crucially on such premises as "Seems to me entirely justified, or I believe, or no doubt." Chomsky then discusses scientific studies on human behavior which is noticeably absent from Walzer's book.

Walzer uses the term "I think" at least 52 times in the book. "I don't think" 7 times. "I believe" twice, "no doubt" at least 41 times, and "seems to me" 12 times (I write "at least" because the same phrase twice on one page would be counted once.)

Walzer's hypocricy

In a book which suffers from terribly bad organization, on page 62 Walzer finally systematically lays out his arguments, stating that "Once the agressor state has been militarily repulsed, it can also be punished."

On December 29, 2005, in an interview on NPR Morning Edition ('Just and Unjust Wars' Author Critical on Iraq.) Walzer stated that the Iraq war was not a just war:

"If you are going to use military force in someone else's county...There has to be a cause of some urgency, a massacre in progress. A massacre in memory is not a just cause."

Therefore, if you follow Walzer's assertions to its obvious conclusion, the Iraq war was not a just war and therefore "the agressor state", the US, should "be punished."

But Walzer signed and endorsed The Euston Manifesto, which states in part:

"We are also united in the view that, since the day on which this occurred, the proper concern of genuine liberals and members of the Left should have been the battle to put in place in Iraq a democratic political order and to rebuild the country's infrastructure...rather than picking through the rubble of the arguments over intervention."

Therefore in Just and unjust wars, Walzer argues that "agressor states" should be "punished" but yet Walzer signs a document which criticize those who "pick through the rubble of the arguments over intervention."

Although the Iraq War is not covered in this book, Walzer's inconsistent views on the Iraq war should give serious students of International affairs pause before subscribing to his arguments. It is one mans opinion, full of statments such as "Seems to me entirely justified" "I believe" or "no doubt."

Walzer's arguments are unscientific rablings of one intellectual which are "ultimately not very instructive about just war".

title: Where are all the pictures?
text: Hardly any photos of the finished recipes. I won't cook a recipe without seeing a picture of what I'm making. There are plenty of other cookbooks out there with half to full page photos to tempt the senses and give a good idea about what the finished dish will taste like. This cookbook is not a keeper.

title: Extremely interesting read
text: I had to read this for one of my classes in college and it was extremely interesting and well written. I learned a lot

title: I couldn't make it past chapter three
text:
Usually, when I start a new book, I set a rule for myself. If I am hooked by the time I make it to chapter three, I can continue reading. Now before you call me "unfair" and "overly judgemental", let me remind you of the fact that usually publishers ask the writer for the first three chapters when they write a new book, and if they are impressed with what they have read, they usually give some advice and let the writer continue with the book.

So as, you guessed, by the time I had finished chapter three, I went "eff this" and threw the book across the room. Mind you, I have no problem with the book's concept itself, because I think it is a wonderful idea, but by God, is the writing in the book SO FREAKIN BORING. I was ready to dismiss this on the notion that this may be MacGuire's first bok, but as I'd had found out he had written seven books before this. That's definitely never a good sign.

The writing is utterly lazy and worst of all, boring. The book is so padded with with descriptions and purple prose to the point where you're forgetting about the characters. Too much telling, not enough showing. I'm sorry, but there should be some character development within the first three chapters of a book. It's unfortunate that MacGuire replaced character development with overly long and unnecessary detail that no one cares about.

title: If you like watching other people's endless home movies, this is the book for you
text: One word: boring. The idea (instead of retiring, hit the road and see the world) is great, and maybe their experiences were fun, but the rendition is SO bad. I endured until page 48 and now the book is in my donate to the library pile.

title: A bit disappointing when compared to The Chosen One
text:
I had extremely high hopes for Miles From Ordinary considering that I loved The Chosen One. That book was deep, shocking, and heartwrenching. I remember sobbing for a half hour after I finished The Chosen One about three hours after I started it. I expected the same thing from Miles From Ordinary and ultimately, I ended up a tad bit disappointed.

I'm going to start out by saying that Miles From Ordinary starts out sloooowwww, like really, really, really slow. It took me about three days to get through the first 50 pages. It just didn't hook me at first and I kept wanting to put it down. It was like pulling teeth for me. Sure, it was mildly interesting, but I guess there was a disconnect between me and the protagonist that prevented me from making any true headway until after the initial 60 or so pages.

That's another issue I had with Miles from Ordinary. The voice of the protagonist was a bit...off. She seemed a bit on the juvenile side even for thirteen. I kept forgetting she was thirteen and thinking she was about ten or eleven. I understand that dealing with her mentally ill mother must have stunted her growth a bit, but I just expect a thirteen year old to be a little bit more...aware than Lacey was. Oh, and I totally didn't buy (mild spoiler here) the whole thing with Linda not being able to help Lacey because the mom kept kicking her out. If Linda had made a big deal about not wanting Lacey to be with her mom because of her initial depression, chances are Child Protective Services would've gotten involved. Maybe they wouldn't have initially snatched the child, but it would've been enough of an issue to have them, at the very least, make an unannounced visit to check out that everything was fine. That, of course, would've proved that everything wasn't fine and Linda would've had a good chance to keep Lacey. (end of mild spoiler)

Besides my issues with the book, I do have to say that the last 40 pages or so of Miles From Ordinary were filled with tension. In fact, the last chapters were absolutely terrifying. I really felt for Lacey there and have no idea how she managed to keep semi-calm because there's no way in hell I would've been calm. I would have been freaking out immensely. So, all in all, I thought that Miles From Ordinary was just okay. It didn't compare at all to The Chosen One and was a bit uneven. I'm not sure that the last fifty pages make up for it.

title: Hated This Book

text: I am not surprised at all that there is 17 people don't like this book why not more then that?This is the second book of hers I have read and not sure I am going to be reading anymore of them.I am trieing to like her with no success.This book doesn't have much story content mostly sex,sex,sex which gets very old after awhile.How about the story line include the main man and woman getting to know each other as friends first then after that start hopping into bed that to me would be a true love story a true romance.Also the main man in the story after bedding the woman once pushes her to get marriage seems to kind of bully her anony her for sure to get married.If a guy keep bugging me to do that I would kick him to the curb after awhile.During the time period the book takes place I know things were different it was still annonying.The book was also part murder mystery as well and that wasn't blended into the book well at all.So if you like romances with alot of sex and not much story line this is the book for you.

title: Read something else unless you are obsessed with Crowley
text:
Yawn. The only part of the book that I found truly interesting was toward the end when he covers the O2 reunion and the aftermath of that. Other than that, he is mostly regurgitating information I have read in other more interesting biographies about Zeppelin.

He doesn't even delve into the re-shooting of large portions of the concert footage at Shepperton Studios in 1974 for "The Song Remains The Same".

He did manage to devote and entire pointless chapter to Aleister Crowley. I ended up skipping that chapter after reading about a 1/4 of it.

Throughout the book he inserts these italicized flashback sections that he says are based on fact, but they are his own words. Whatever. They're stupid and distract from the flow of the book.

My last irritation with this book is the fact that he repeatedly refers to the album "In Through The Out Door" as "In Through The Outdoor". He obviously doesn't grasp the concept of the title.

Based on the photo of him on the back of the book, I would say that he should consider a career as a Phil Collins impersonator. He might actually be good at that...

title: Poorly Organized and Very Dated
text:
This is one of the poorest textbooks on the introduction to the Spanish literature that I have ever seen. The content is extremely dated: the first work of literature under discussion here is El Cid (evidently, the authors were educated in the tradition that refuses to acknowledge the existence of any literary production in the Iberian Peninsula that predated El Cid), the XVIII century in Spain is qualified as the century of the "afrancesados", etc.

The way the textbook is organized makes it pretty much no use in a classroom (which was the purpose I had in mind when first consulting it). The textbook's authors seem to have some kind of a mania grandiosa because they print their own analysis and commentary in a font that is much larger than the font in which the excerpts from Lope, Cervantes, Galdos, Goytisolo, and other Spanish authors are printed. As a result, it looks as if excerpts from actual works of literature were some kind of an afterthought to the ideas of Perez Rivera and Hurtado. The authors love retelling and dedicated a lot more space to retelling (pretty badly, I have to say) the plots of famous works of literature. This is yet another feature of this textbook that makes it useless in a classroom setting.

If you are looking to adopt a textbook for a course in Spanish literature, my honest opinion is that you would do better with no textbook at all than with this disgrace of a book.

title: Not impressed

title: You'll Need a Microscope to Read the Tiny Type
text: I love the idea and intent of this book. And it seems to have good photos that accompany the text. But it is impossible to read the book because the type size is like a 2 font (usually fonts in books and defaults on computers are a 12 font, as a point of reference). If the publisher would provide a PDF of the book to accompany the print version, or ditch the current edition and reprint in a larger font it would be possible to comment on the content of the book. Too bad. It's a popular topic that could have enjoyed a wide readership. But this edition was pretty much wrecked by the publisher's design layout choice. Be aware of this if you don't have 20 year old, 20-20 vision.

title: I'm totally on the fence about this one.
text:
So it has taken me a bit to gather my thoughts enough to review Grey by E.L. James, which if you didn’t know is Fifty Shades Of Grey told from the male leads POV, Christian Grey.
I was really interested in this retelling of the original story to see if there was much of a difference from the story we all know and if it’s been altered a bit since the recent movie. I was also interested in seeing how the authors writing style may have matured since the original as well. Lastly, I wanted to see if there were more details into Christian’s childhood or backstory that we didn’t get in the first telling. So here’s my review and a bit of a synopsis.
Christian Grey is a man obsessed. A man who is in control of his world. That is until Anna Steel crashes into his office and into his life. She is an innocent and definitely not in control of anything. The two will embark on a journey of discovery; in and out of the bedroom and only their willingness to be together and bend their own rules can love prevail.
This book is a cliffy, so be warned. I wouldn’t recommend it if you haven’t read the original Fifty but let me say this, if you haven’t read Fifty, you could pick this one up as a standalone, seriously! Even though it’s a cliffy, it does wrap up nicely. A newbie could walk away with having sampled a taste and know that the two will ultimately be together.
Anywho with that being said, I did like hearing the story from his POV. I personally prefer male POV’s much more then female. I like the darkness of them verses the usual light and fluffy female telling. I also liked hearing him cuss and call her sweetheart and baby in his head, it was a much more endearing telling of the same story verses her take. You walk away from the story understanding his stalker-ish tendencies a bit more and how she becomes a lifeline for him, only to completely screw the pooch and cut the line by hurting her and how it takes him finally bending his ways and deciding rather then fit her into his life, he needs to fit into hers. He tries so hard in the first book to make her into what he needs that he ultimately loses her until he realizes through therapy that rather then make her into what he needs, he should try the opposite and try to be what she needs, which I don’t think came across in the movie or in the first book. So I did love seeing that POV of the story.
What I didn’t like was that we didn’t really get much more of his past. We got some scene snippets and we do feel the heartbreak of an abused child but I really didn’t feel like it added to the story as much as I had hoped. Granted, I don’t want to relive his childhood through the book but I didn’t feel that much more was gained through the scenes that I didn’t know about from the first telling. Also, I felt it was basically the EXACT same story but with a male slant, if that makes sense? Scene for scene, it follows the original Fifty except with a build up or interjection of his life.
I'm not sure if it's worth the read or if it added much that you didn't already know. I'm totally on the fence about this one. Check out what I said above and if you want the new slant on an old store, give it a shot. If this is new to you, give it a shot. If you're tired of the original, this one isn't going to change your mind.

title: Fascinating wilderness world, but ultimately this story frustrated me
text:
This might be the first time where I picked up a book that a few of my SF&F blogger friends enjoyed... and didn't like it as much as they did. Which is a bummer, because Sarah Beth Durst does a few things quite well in THE QUEEN OF BLOOD. I just wish its weaknesses hadn't frustrated me so much.

THE QUEEN OF BLOOD is the first book in a YA/adult crossover epic fantasy series that features malevolent nature spirits, human youths (mostly girls, but also the occasional boy) who can control these spirits, and queens who are skilled in this practice and chosen by the spirits to keep the tenuous peace between nature and humanity. Daleina is one such candidate for this honor. At age 10, her village is destroyed in a spirit attack, and her powers manifest for the first time as she saves her family. The horrors she endured spur her to join one of Aratay's academies later on so she can protect her people. But as Daleina grows older and learns to harness her powers, spirit attacks like the one her village suffered continue to plague Aratay. Who's behind these attacks? Is Queen Fara losing her sway over the nature spirits? Most frightening of all, what if the attacks aren't accidents at all?

For me, the two dominant strengths of THE QUEEN OF BLOOD are worldbuilding and plot. The best word to describe the forest realm of Aratay is "wilderness." It's inhabited yet untamed, dangerous and beautiful. Its people are closely tied to the land and the spirits they co-exist with. Entire villages and cities are constructed in gigantic trees. The lore of the nature spirits and the overall way of the world is demonstrated quite well without info-dumping, so it's easy to become immersed in Aratay's happenings.

As for the plot, it seems fairly straightforward until the second half - and then HOLY PLOT TWISTS. This story serves turn after turn as it closes in on the end, and the suspense mounts to the point where you absolutely NEED to know how it ends. I did predict one of the plot twists correctly (it's easy to guess who's behind the spirit attacks), but the others... Wow. I did not see them coming, and they make for a fitting yet unexpectedly brutal ending.

The characters of THE QUEEN OF BLOOD, though... I did like Daleina a lot. She's far from any "chosen one" or "special snowflake" trope. Rather, she's one of the weaker students in her academy magic-wise, but she compensates for it with courage, determination, and an enviable work ethic. Her motivations are noble, too; she's more concerned about her family and the welfare of Aratay's people than power or prestige. But the other characters... Apart from Ven, I don't feel like I got to know them very well. The other academy students seemed too similar and blended into one another by the end, and Queen Fara was a stereotypical corrupted queen-seductress-madwoman.

I also wasn't that impressed by the writing in THE QUEEN OF BLOOD. Durst certainly knows how to build a believable world and plot an exciting story. But for a fantasy novel that's meant to appeal to both YA and adult audiences, the writing lacked a distinct voice and sense of maturity. And for me, the quality of an author's writing can either enhance the story and fold me further into its spell, or disengage me from the experience. I think you can guess where this book fell on that spectrum.

Ultimately, THE QUEEN OF BLOOD frustrated me as much as it fascinated me. And that's a shame, considering the stunning and unique worldbuilding. Maybe if the sequel improves on this first book, I'll continue the series.

Maybe...

title: An inspiring concept, but lacking in execution...
text:
I liked this book.

The antagonists were really vile, which was great...it makes rooting against them that much more fun. The problem? The protagonists weren't much better. Darren Street isn't a particularly likable character.

I had a real problem with Mr. Street's behavior following his meeting with Jalen Jordan. A professional gentleman, who has even an iota of sense, would be figuring out how best to protect his son...not going to person after person telling them he's going to "kill Jalen."

Mr. Street said dingbat words and did dingbat things, and then was surprised when he ended up in jail? I mean, I'm a parent. I get the fear. But a man who spends every day of his life working in the criminal justice system should know better.

Otherwise, I really enjoyed the perspective of the story. It's not often you read a story about an attorney in a maximum security prison. That part of the story was super interesting, and I honestly wish Mr. Pratt had delved in a bit more deeply.

The final 20% of the book....meh. A little implausible, but satisfying, nonetheless. Not sure whether or not I'll continue with the series or not at this point.

title: Husbands and Trees
text:
Aunt Bitzy writes to her niece begging for help to save Emily. Emily is a tree house the new neighbor is going to chop down.

That's true enough, but Bitzy leaves out her plans to create a real life romance. Her main characters being Susannah and neighbor Jake. It's a cute and fun read. I wish it had been longer so the characters had more development. Bitzy is a hoot. The lovers aren't nearly as fun.

It's good, but it could have been better. I was irritated when I started the book because the last Kasey book I read before had a Suzanna as the main character too. It was a bit confusing!

title: Preaching to the Choir
text:
I tried to be open and listen to this. I reached a point, I just couldn't go any further. Maybe it was the style. Maybe it was the vitriolic writing rather than impartiality? Or perhaps it was the opinions stated as fact? Maybe it is the glorification of the past without regard for what it has caused in the future? For example: While it is true that social security initially started as a social redistribution program paid for by the rich, it isn't a glorious program when it became compulsory to be paid for by everyone. Dare I mention that it has now grown to be one of the largest unfunded mandates in the U.S.? And Medicare? Has it really pulled the common people out of poverty? Between Social Security and Medicare they are the top two problems with the national debt. So while they might have been good ideas at the time, over time they act as the biggest debt chains on everyone in the U.S.

Or another example - the term 'Economic Equality' when used by a liberal. Economic equality to a liberal means that those who work or have money support the lazy ones . Why don't they just say socialism or communism and bring up Russia or China? Russia collapsed and China found that people wouldn't work if they couldn't be rewarded for their efforts.

So while it may be true that conservatives Bush and Reagan did bad things, it is also true that the liberals have done some abominable things to take away the rights and economies of the common person.

So while this may be a study in viewpoints that perhaps shows a different perspective to conservativism, this book isn't what I had hoped it would be. The Conscience of a Liberal appears to be one that only states a half truth rather than a balanced viewpoint.
