title: Good, but......
text:
Original review, 2 November 2004

Revised 25 January 2005

Turns out my original review was referenced to the wrong edition, and with that I accept the objections which Raks and Nick raised. The problem goes back to Amazon.com, who sent me the wrong book.

That said, much of my original review still holds, though I am raising my evaluation from three to four stars.

This book has much to recommend it--especially for beginners in a classroom situation. However, it has too many errors and omissions to be fully satisfactory for unassisted use by the beginners it targets.

This is a tutorial, not a reference work. That is, going page by page from the beginning to the end, one gets reasonably complete coverage of the main features of Wildfire. However, many features and operations are omitted from discussion or covered only superficially. This would not be a problem in a classroom situation, or if there were an experienced Pro/E user close by to answer questions. But a student working on his own will often be left floundering. It helps if one has recourse to the Pro/E Help Center, though that is unnecessarily difficult to find answers from.

Given the nature of Pro/E and the editorial style of the book, it is not practical to use an edition of the book which is not specific to the particular release of Pro/E. Among other things, PTC Corp is in the process of converting the Menu Manager with its submenus to dialog boxes, so that a student may be misdirected unless matching editions are used.

This edition appears to have fewer errors than the previous one. Still, Mr. Tickoo needs to submit his manuscripts for editing, both of grammar/punctuation and of technical directions, by persons competent in English and in the programs. The language errors are aggravating but do not diminish the technical value of the book. The technical errors and omissions are more serious. The instructions are often incomplete or incorrect to the extent that the indicated operations cannot be completed based on the information given. For example, on page 4-14, Figure 4-24, the student is instructed to select the Edge. That doesn't work. The correct instruction is the corner--the "Vertex." The discussion of the Datum System, perhaps the most difficult and most critical aspect for a working knowledge of Wildfire, is skimpy at best. The examples and instructions given in the text only equip the student to stumble around looking for workable solutions.

The tutorials are for the most part explicit and complete, though sometimes excessively redundant on common features and short on instructions for new or uncommon features. The Exercises, at the end of the chapters after the Tutorials and Review Questions, often rely on operations which are not discussed until a later chapter.

Neverthless, all things considered, I would judge this book as a qualified success--excellent for classroom use or under the tutelage of an experienced user, OK for a resourceful independent beginner willing to poke around for solutions when things don't work as expected.

It should be noted that Mr. Tickoo has provided extensive material on his website supplementing this book. However, those materials work only for the Student/Tryout version of Wildfire, not for the commercial release. A person using the commercial release should obtain a tryout version (free for two months) if he wants take advantage of Mr. Tickoo's supplementary materials.

title: Why Must They Interject Political Biases Into Everything?
text:
To be honest, I couldn't get past the fifth totally unnecessary, snarky, partisan political jab. I haven't read everything he wrote, but, in all the books I have read I don't remember Robert Parker ever interjecting, in any way, his political views into his story or his characters.
One of the reasons I read is to get away from the constant barrage of partisan politics from both sides of the political spectrum on television.
Mike Lupica, on the other hand, used Sunny Randall's asides to take shots at Republicans ("as white as a Republican National Convention") and Fox News (here I paraphrase: they use single syllable words to accommodate their audience). Why? These shots added nothing to the narrative and only serves to alienate at least 50% of readers. Again, why?
Obviously I won't be reading anymore Sunny Randall books by Lupica. I miss Robert Parker.

title: Not overly for me, but still a good reminder to focus on others, and not self....
text:
I'm super sensitive to people bragging on themselves. It's one of my many character flaws, but I don't connect very well to those that do it a great deal. It's why I sometimes have to unfollow people I know online. They're perfectly sweet and lovely people, but their bragging causes my mind to attach a bit of negativity to them. This book comes off like a constant bragging session, and while I'm sure that's not how it's meant to come off, it caused a huge disconnect from the book for me.

When I was able to look past that, it was interesting to see this particular family in action when it comes to hospitality. Hospitality will look different for each and every personality, but this book is full of great ideas on helping more.

If you're like me and are sensitive to bragging, I'd say pass this book up. If you're not like me in that area, it is full of ideas and the reminder to focus on others, and not self.

title: Not my favorite

title: Complete, but not really for the hobbyist
text:
This book covers a number of radio designs, starting with the simple and building up to the state of the art.

However, they are all presented merely as schematics. If you aren't VERY familiar with schematics, the book will be useless to you.

Many other books on electronics, aimed at hobbyists, also include drawings of breadboard circuits. That is much easier for a hobbyist to follow, and reproduce, than schematics alone.

I am a software engineer. I have a General Class ham radio license. I have built various microprocessor-controlled gadgets on breadboards, with hand-wired SPI and I2C busses. But I do not think I could turn the information in this book into a functioning radio without a lot of effort. So it's collecting dust on the shelf.

title: Simple, Unseful Idea that Makes Sense.
text:
We relate to companies and brands the same way we relate to people, according to research conducted by Chris Malone, Wharton MBA graduate, who has held senior marketing positions at companies such as Coca Cola, Aramark and Choice hotels, and Susan T. Fiske, a professor of Psychology at Princeton.

Humans, for their survival need to make quick, spontaneous judgments about others' intentions and how capable they are of carrying out those intentions. Are they trust worthy honest and kind? Are they competent, capable and skilled?

Successful companies need to exhibit both qualities.
Too much of one attribute without the other is ineffective or detrimental.

The authors use grids with emotional responses as illustration. `Each combined pattern of warmth and competence perception leads to a predictable set of emotional responses.'
High warmth and low competence makes us feel pity.
High warmth and high competence make us feel pride.
Low warmth and low competence makes us feel disgust.
Low warmth and high competence make us feel envy.

Think of a cold, yet competent surgeon with no bedside manner or a kind-hearted yet bumbling neighbor who bakes cookies.

The authors highlight the brand Lululemon as using the winning formula by of what they call the Principal of Worthy Intentions, `a customer relationship strategy that involves attracting and keeping customers by consistently putting their best interests ahead of those of the company or brand.'

This was written before the recent debacle with Lululemon's recall of Yoga pants that customers complained about being too sheer, (made too cheaply) and CEO Chip Wilson's inadvertently insulting apology, a cringe worthy example of how to destroy customer perception of worthy intentions. According to the ideas presented here, Lululemon has most recently exhibited low warmth and low competence.

The book presents a simple eye-opening concept that makes sense and is backed up by research.

There's another book entitled Compelling People by John Neffinger and Matthew Kohut which offers similar ideas to The Human Brand. That book says we judge by our unconscious perception of a person's strength and warmth.

The Human Brand is worth reading, but in light of what we know to be Emotional Intelligence, this book doesn't really break new ground. It just further proves what we've known all along.

title: Just fair.
text: To many characters and dragged out. I tried him but just not for me. Bill

title: Boring..............
text:
I followed the coverage of the Scott Peterson trial from gavel to gavel, and when I saw Amber Frey and her attorney Gloria Alred hyping this book all over TV, I thought that maybe this book would shed more light on this story. Well, I was really surprised at what I read.

I am not one to cast shadows over some people, but Amber Frey has portrayed herself in this book to be a God loving individual who was a victim of Scott Peterson. But I must totally disagree. Amber Frey is a victim of herself and has put herself out there for the whole world to see. She appears to be a very needy girl, who was willing to compromise herself and her daughter, just to have a man in her life. When I read some of her descriptions about the first couple of "dates" she had with Mr. Peterson, I couldn't believe that this young woman didn't see what he was right at the beginning.

This book is boring and Amber has painted herself to be a saint, which she is not. Any halfway intelligent human being could see that Scott was using her from the very beginning as part of his plot to kill his wife, and after reading this book, Scott Peterson picked Amber as the weak and needy person that she is, and hoped that she would be his alibi. Amber Frey has portrayed herself in this book as a strong willed woman for coming forward, but I'm not buying it. Any person with any amount of decency would have come forward and reported what she knew.

The only thing good about this book is that it really shows the world what type of young lady Amber Frey really is. I would also be curious to see how much money she made with all of the "endorsements" that are dropped throughout this book.

title: Disorienting
text:
I wanted so much more from this book. It looks pretty, but it doesn’t deliver. First, the ingredient lists are illogical, and make it hard to visualize the recipe. The haze is compounded by the lack of visual cues. Instead of showing me a picture of basil, how about showing me a picture of the pesto? Instead of the dozens of pictures of family members holding bowls and pointlessly chopping vegetables, please show me, in many steps, how to peel an artichoke.

The book aims to be the cookbook of the Pollan family, and indeed, some recipes feature a vignette by one of the family members. Far too many recipe intros simply state how hearty or flavorful the dish is without giving much context.

title: It's OK
text:
The first story, Counting Crows by Mercedes Lackey, gets my nomination for best of the three. The only thing was that I figured out what was going to happen quite early - and hoped for the rest of the story that it would surprise me by going a different way. I was wrong. Oh well! It was also littered by some issues I have with Lackey's writing style, in particular the separation of words describing action. This isn't an example from the book - just an example. Lackey would say, "I'm going to look the house over before I sign" instead of "I'm going to look over the house before I sign." It has more punch (and is grammatically correct) the second way. Her writing style is actually quite plain; it's her stories themselves that I find appealing.

The last story, Moonglow by Catherine Asaro, gets second place, because the general way the story was outlined and proceeded didn't appeal to me. It also seemed just a tad more "amateur" in its writing style, although it was more complex than Lackey's story.

The middle story, Drusilla's Dream by Rachel Lee - well, it was frustrating. Lee wrote a prologue wherein she indicates the characters didn't do what she originally intended. Too bad. I only got a couple chapters in and decided I'd had enough.

title: The book of the super-werewolf
text:
"The Sacred Book of the Werewolf" is one of those rare books that truly and completely defies classifiation.

Rather than a straightforward fiction or genre story, Victor Pelevin's symbolism-crammed book hops from one style to another -- Eastern mysticism, Russian urban fantasy, inhuman love story, wildly funny satire and postmodern exploration of Russia's place in a post-Soviet world. Despite the wealth of symbolism and a heavy dose of Buddhist philosophy woven in,, it's not stuffy or boring -- instead it's a wickedly funny personal journey that slowly slips into a bittersweet pathos as our shapechanging heroine learns some truths of the universe.

A Hua-li is a werefox -- an ancient, genderless creature with a hypnotic tail, a currently obscene name, who feeds off the energy emanated by humans during sex. She's also a virgin, and is starting to get an "old maid complex."

And to stay energized, she works as a prostitute in Russia -- she doesn't have actual sex with her clients, but manipulates them with her tail. But after some disastrous encounters, she finds herself being investigated by the Russian authorities -- and particularly by the handsome Alexander, a werewolf who transforms and molests A Hua-li. She's shocked but captivated by the young werewolf, and soon they're in the middle of a passionate affair. Yeah, great message to be sending.

The subject of the super-werewolf prophecy comes up when A Hua-Li's older sister and her flaky English aristocrat hubby come for a visit, with said hubby intent on becoming the super-werewolf himself. And A Hua-Li sees the werewolves being used to call oil from a dry well. But when a shocking change comes over her werewolf paramour, A Hua-Li must reexamine their relationship as she keeps her lover safe -- and reveal what the prophecy of the super-werewolf truly means.

Buddhism, wereanimals, aristocrat/chicken-hunting, mass media, Rainbow Streams, Nabokov, DVD sex games and hypnotic tails who contain all the truth of the universe. Victor Pelevin has a knack for bizarre postmodern fiction that is rarely seen outside a Haruki Murakami book"The Sacred Book of the Werewolf" is like a brightly coloured mosaic of randomly sized and shaped pieces.

Along that ride, we're privy to A Hua-Li's intricate meditations on everything from sex to watermelons -- often described in carefully numbered lists. Pelevin fills his meandering storyline with literary allusions (hello, Nabokov!) and infuses it with plenty of wry humour ("We foxes are keen hunters of English aristocrats and chickens"). There's even a hilarious scene where Alexander and A Hua-Li contemplate what DVD movies they should play out as their sex games ("Listen, how old are you, twelve?" "Okay, let's forget the Matrix").

Yet he has a knack for hauntingly memorable scenes as well. Any creature as ancient as A Hua-li will have a sense of bittersweetness in their life, and her view of her lover's shocking transformation and his subsequent fear and confusion are striking. And as the book winds toward its esoteric end, Pelevin unrolls a heavy swathe of Buddhist philosophy that finally explains who/what the super-werewolf is, and what the prophecy means. Let's just say that it's not your average "chosen savior of Group X" prophecy.

And modern Russia, as Pelevin paints it, is all grimy cold urbanity speckled with American products and foreign businessmen. He injects a lot of symbolism (Alexander, the oil well, the super-werewolf, the hypnotic tails that can reveal the true nature of things) as well as a mocking satirical edge (a doomed aristocrat's nonsensical ramblings about how HE can become the super-werewolf without any enlightenment).

The one thing I didn't like? A Hua-li being raped by Alexander and immediately falling for him.

But A Hua-Li is a pretty oxymoronic character -- she can be ruthless, manipulative, loving and sweet, has the enthusiasm of the young nymphet she pretends to be yet is ancient and experienced beyond even her own measure. And Alexander is her total opposite -- rough, brash, traditional yet modern, and possessing a straightforward mind that struggles with the more unusual spiritual paths of the "super-werewolf." And then there's A Hua-Li's sister -- merciless and wickedly funny, especially since she marries British aristos in order to "hunt" them.

"The Sacred Book of the Werewolf" is a bizarre crazy-quilt of genres -- a sort of symbolic Buddhist urban-fantasy satire, with a mingling of bittersweet and hilarious.

title: Meh
text:
My least favorite literary genre is fantasy. I’m just not a fan. Every now and then I read one that I enjoy, and sometimes I read one that blows my mind. However, most often I just don’t love them. I likely wouldn’t have even had this one on my TBR list if it hadn’t shown up on one of the book lists I follow. This one was an add-on option for the Book of the Month Club’s May 2022 box. I didn’t add it to the box, this isn’t one I would want for my personal library, but I did add it to my TBR queue and grabbed it from my library (I love the library! So many free books!). I wasn’t excited.
This book has a setting I can identify, and the characters are actually people instead of some other entity with which I’m unfamiliar. Those two facts worked in its favor. I dislike most fantasy because I don’t want to have to visualize a completely different world and try to picture non-human entities. I just want to dig into a story and lose myself. While this book’s format allowed me that privilege, I found myself struggling with the story.
I became increasingly frustrated with back-and-forth timeline within Charlie’s story. I understand that Black needed to allow the reader to fully grasp Charlie and her background, I didn’t like the way it played out. It didn’t seem to have a specific format, i.e.: one chapter now and one chapter then. Black just sprinkled in Charlie’s backstory whenever she felt like it. I also felt like the story meandered. There were minor storylines added in that seemed to have little purpose, despite being part of the bigger picture. Then when the big picture was finally revealed, it felt very anticlimactic.
And finally, I wanted more of Charlie’s sister. I can only assume that further volumes of this series will dive more deeply into her character, but until then I’m just disappointed. Posey comes across as an integral part of the book, but the part she plays really never does a lot…she just exists.
I’m not sure if I’ll read anything further in this series. If Holly Black’s sequel to this one pops up on one of the lists I follow, I will pick it up, but I will definitely not seek it out.

title: List of suggestions when in the mood
text:
DK's "What to Watch When" is a bit overwhelming. I did have an immediate soft spot for it because when I first opened the book, it went to a page with "Hell on Wheels" which is a series that I loved.

Anyway, I got it because I don't watch as much TV as I used. Even with the streaming services, I don't binge much. The last series that I binged and LOVED was "A Crime to Remember." So so good. That's kind of what I was looking for when I got this book. Find series like that one. It wasn't listed so I was immediately at 50/50 on this book.

I feel like it is a book for a specific audience. It has a lot of shows that I could go to twitter to find out about. The first entry on the chapter for "When you want to learn something new" is "The Crown." A show a lot of people already talk about. And "Fleabag" (a show I hated and gave up on) gets its own page.

So it is a mixed bag for me, but it did have "Hell on Wheels" on that first opening of the book so it is at least a 3 start for me.

title: In some ways amazingly good, in others, amazingly bad.
text: This guy can write suspense and kept me on the edge of my seat at times. He also frustrated the crap out of me. He clearly did not do any research in critical areas. He said there has been only one female serial killer in history. Wrong! Per Google, the first reported in the US lived from 1793 to 1820. There have been a bunch. He had characters keep saying Yuh instead of Yeah. His slang is all wrong. I have never heard the term half ten (etc) used in the US as opposed to 10:30 or half past ten.  Everybody significant drove British cars, drove them really fast, and never got stopped. He has characters having some sort of national identify numbers or a similar term, but we don't have them. SSN? Who knows? As other reviewers commented, he does not know US distances. He kept referring to beef sandwiches--maybe roast beef??? He has characters fixated on Latina girls,but apparently doesn't knew enough Spanish to know that is redundant.  At $.99 for the first box set, I would recommend it, but at the prices for later box sets, I would not. I'm delighted to know he writes a book a month. Maybe if he took time to get a US editor, I would read more. Now, I'm going to read a thriller/police procedural set in GB, by a British author whose language and setting are consistent.

title: Find something else.
text: I thought it would be cooler than it is. The outside packaging is nice. The inside stuff, ehh.

title: So dissapointed
text: I have loved Cornwell's Kay Scarpetta since the first time I opened one of her books.  I was so excited when I saw a new one was out and couldn't wait to dive in.  Unfortunately I found the water to be more than a little murky and the swim, quite disappointing.  The overall tone of the book was very angry. Whereas Kay was once the voice of reason and an island in the midst of all the insanity, she too was angry at all around her.  Gone were the rich descriptions of Kay, her home, clothes, cooking; all that made Kay, Kay.  I found the book very confusing and disjointed.  It was as if Cornwell lost her love of Scarpetta and was just cranking out another story because she had to rather than wanting to.

title: Pass the Challah, Please
text:
Would the average person know where to find a loaf of challah, Swiss Chard, goat cheese, Thai red curry paste, coconut milk, Sciracha chili sauce, panko bread crumbs, Aioli dressing, smoked paprika, large jalapeno chilies, frozen puff pastries, and cremini mushrooms?
Certainly not me. Yet these are some of the ingredients that the recipes in this book call for, as well as others - less exotic, but still challenging. I'm afraid this cookbook will spend most of its time collecting dust on a shelf.

title: This third edition is truly a rip-off!
text:
OK, what have we got here? To cover six years worth of Star Wars continuity since the last edition of the Guide, we get around 100 pages of new materiel. Except it isn't new. The author made a point to include materiel fom The Phantom Menace and Vector Prime, but other than that it seems nothing released in the last 2-3 years made it in here! No material from Allston's X-wing books, no Union, no prequel-era stuff except for the movie itself. While there is a bit about Kyle Katarn from the Dark Forces game, nothing about his role in the sequel, Jedi KNight, which came out about four years ago. There are virtually no new pictures, most of them are merely lifted from the Essential Guides.
But perhaps the biggest problem is in the organization. Gone are the categorical indeces of aliens, droids, ships, planets, creatures, etc... which were so helpful at the beginning of Edition 2, gone is even a rudimentary timeline, absent is the galactic map which has been gracing most of the more recent Star Wars fiction. Also gone is the neat seperation in the earlier edition between "canon" materiel -- that established in the movies and their novelizations -- and just about everything else.
For about twice the price of this book you can get the Star Wars Encyclopedia, which has more materiel, many, many more color photos and illustrations, and better organization of materiel. I recommend that you do. This book is a waste of time and money. It was three years outdated when it came out, overpriced at that.

title: Dead in the water
text: I enjoyed this book but at the same time it was ok.  The authors did a fine job of telling a story but I guess for me with a title like Drowning with Others, I expected it to be a bit more suspenseful.  While it covers a taboo topic or topics, I don’t think the journal entries were enough to convey the long lasting effect of traumatic events that take place at a young age and how it could carryover through adulthood.  It seemed to take a little long to get the story moving.  With the big event taking place at the very beginning, it seemed to take very long to get to the climax.  I also found that everything string was tied a little to perfectly.  I would still recommend giving this a read, but it’s not one that I would read again.  Once you reach the conclusion of the story, there’s no mystery.

title: Three hundred some pages of nothing happening.
text:
Three hundred some pages of nothing happening. It's not too hard to discover the nastiness behind the motive, but to guess the murderer you might as well throw at a dartboard blindfolded.

I suppose some will find the coarse Aussie dialog funny. And the finale is dramatic, but it takes so long to get there, it hardly seems worth it.

Next time I'm going to make sure a book has at least 100 reviews before buying it. Less than that is probably because nobody is finishing it.

This book is not for the average income family. its maybe for the top %1 of wealthy families. There are so many bad messages in this book and only a couple good ones. title: Well written, but a miserable reading experience  .
text:
Yes, it's well written. And I applaud any effort to raise awareness and appreciation of trees. But do I really want to read a book where a kind, talented, man grows old and blows his brains out, another family dies of gas poisoning, and an artistic child is abused by his parents and siblings? These narratives are filled with pain and misery.

The prose are exquisite, but this is a terribly dark, depressing a slit-your-wrists kind of book. I can think of better ways to spend my time and energy.

title: Sound and Fury, Mostly Impotent
text:
I was going to just move on until I saw the preponderance of five-star reviews. Some folks are easy to please. The Fifth Heart is a ponderous elephant that doesn't even try to pick up the pea in the corner, but just talks endlessly about it. Simmons sophomoric attempt at metafiction (Holmes suspects -- wait for it -- he is a fictional character) is nothing more than a silly thought experiment, resolved by the intervention of a profoundly fictional character from another undistinguished Simmons novel (But not until James and Sam Clemens discuss whether they too are merely fictional characters: Deeep, dude!). His infatuation with Henry James seems to mainly center on whether the novelist was gay; his interest in Holmes centers around an [invented] taste for heroin. We are treated at one point to a two-page description of dinner (the food, not the event) in which Simmons flaunts his research by putting cigarettes on the menu only to be crossed out as vulgar. We are given not one but two tours of the Columbia Exposition. Likewise two anecdotes are both told twice, each of them half a page and barely necessary to the plot. The entire book rants about "anarchists," which is a code word in SImmonsspeak [See Black Hills] for socialists and the labor movement. But it turns out that anarchists (the point is not explicit) are not responsible for the nefarious plot after all. In the last fifty pages, Simmons finally realizes that he has to deliver something after dragging us through a 550-page Baedeker, so something actually happens -- something totally void of credibility. I'm sorry, but even SImmons' misogynist recreation of Irene Adler would not do what she does. Just no.

Simmons seems to feel that any historical personage he can wedge into his novels should be smirched in the process. This teenage nastiness made reading Drood a exercise in masochism and left me wanting a brain rinse after Black Hills. I don't care if John Hay and Henry Adams cheated on their wives. I don't care if Teddie Roosevelt was a buffoon (who knew??). I don't care if Henry James liked to look at naked men. I don't care if Sam Clemens missed the Columbia Exposition because he had a cold. After 620 pages of masticated research and sniggering, I really don't care if Dan Simmons ever writes another novel.

title: My mistake, but still a horrible calendar
text:
I saw a calendar and I thought it was, you know, a wall calendar. I am not sure what this is. It is too big to be a planner and way too small to be a wall calendar. It doesn't even have a hole to hang it on a nail or hook like any normal calendar.

The picture shows this calendar in comparison to my current calendar that I was hoping to replace. Not even close.

I should have read the description, but when you see a calendar, don't you think it will be a normal sized wall calendar?

title: A good book cheapened by the ending.
text:
I was all set to give this book 5 stars. And I would have done so were it not for the last chapter. That last chapter cheapened the story and made the effort of reading this very harrowing book worthless for me.
I found Handle with Care a very compelling and affecting book, despite the many plots and very distracting and bizarely included recipes...Why?
it was a very interesting experience to read a book where I didn't agree with anything the main protagonist did but still liked her in a way. The ending made me want to literally throw the book at a wall, and I would have had I not been listening to the end while driving my car. ( I was doing double duty with this book; reading the print version and also listening to the audio depending on where I was.)
I have read other books by Jodi Picoult so really should have expected what she did at the end, especially after "My Sisters Keeper". In hindsight, it was quite predictable. After this heavy tale of unending misery I need a serious fluff infusion.

title: Get a magnifying lens
text: Ordered this for my high schooler (yes it’s a word now), if she reads this I’ll be getting eye doctor bills by the end.  Ridiculously small print.  Should be part of the description. Since whoever put this together and thought it was appropriate needed my money so badly as to hide this fact, I’ll let them keep it.  Do NOT order unless you like to read squinting or using a telescope.

title: Falls flat and has no meat as a story about Detroit
text: Detroit:an American autopsy is a fitting title were it for a book about just that. Instead, this book represents a set of tabloid-style, heart-on-my-sleeve polaroid snapshots of Charlie's adventures in a city in great decline. There's very little meat to the story of Detroit and its people. Sure, there are some hearfelt moments (those describing the fire department's plight come to mind), but I quickly got tired of the "everybody loves Charlie" feel of the book (except of course the bad guys). As the pages turn the author comes over as a man who is writing on quickly formed emotions, rather than as a man who is a reporter telling the story of a city. As an example, consider the moment where a German reporter looks at him the wrong way from a distance: Charlie's response on paper is to groan about the fact that the only thing worse than American reporters are foreign reporters. My reactions to off-topic comments like that were combinations of "how many pages are left" and "Is this guy really a reporter". Anyone who wants to have an informed perspective about the history of the city of Detroit is encouraged to look elsewhere,

title: For most part wonderful but the detailed needless violence towards end makes it hard to recommend
text: I loved so much of this story, but the best part for me was the character of jamie--such a vibrant, joyous, innocently beautiful man but also with faults that he admits to.  i feel he is unique in many ways out of the vast array of male romantic figures--and feels like someone you actually know after reading much of this book. I would have given it a 5 were it not for the gross, extremely detailed and gratuitous violence done to jamie near the end of the book. i understand the need for dramatic and difficult things to happen to heroes or heroines so that they may overcome them. But this went beyond that somehow into something that made me feel sick and almost betrayed. as if the author was either trying to appeal to something very prurient in people or else had some issue she needed to get out herself.  why do something that horrific to someone that has been made so lovable? in order for the strong heroine to get to bring him back from something that awful? it just didn't feel necessary, and was out of tone and jarring in terms of the rest of the boook. the flow of the book was shattered for me by the incident. i'm surprised, in reading reviews, that there is not more about it.  Women complain about the violence done to claire but don't talk about this part.  not sure i can really recommend the book due to this.  too bad, because it was so good otherwise. The author did such a great job of writing in this book that it drew the reader into the world to the degree that it became almost real.  For me the images became part of my day==which is why I really don't like the turn it took with the ugly sexual violence. No one needs those images in their head.  If you are a journalist and need to portray horrific details in order to try to achieve a change in some situation, that is one thing, but to do it in a romantic novel is not only pointless but perverse.

title: Not just about the shark
text: Overall I enjoyed this read. The author did great in his descriptions of scenes involving the shark and I actually would have liked a few more of those. Sometimes I felt it was hard to fully understand some of the descriptions of military happenings and thus occasionally skimmed in those. I would recommend this book.

Main character, the chief of police, is taciturn, somewhat damaged by failure in love, excessively sexual, seems to find lots of attractive women to share his bed. Some cute dialogue. A pleasant enough book to read in an afternoon, but nothing special.

title: Two Stars

title: Did Not Meet Expectations
text:
The Good Girl by Mary Kubica was one of those books that I have been looking forward to reading, believing that it’ll be a great read especially from all the positive reviews I’ve seen and heard. Unfortunately, the book didn’t live up to the anticipation and expectation that I have been carrying around.

While the book had a good concept and merit, the majority of my issues was mostly on the execution of the story. First, the writing was just average. I thought there were instances in which scenes and actions could’ve been manipulated in such a way that it wouldn’t have taken as long as it did to get to the point. As a result, the story had this slow pace that took the energy away from the story which in turn took away my energy in reading it. I wasn’t exactly eager to get back to the book, even though I was close to finishing it. If the book isn’t evoking a sense of excitement or eagerness in the reader, it would be difficult for said reader to reciprocate it in reading it.

Second, I couldn’t muster any kind of emotional attachment/reaction, positive or otherwise, to the characters. In a remote way, I know what I’m supposed to be feeling but I just didn’t feel it. I just felt the portrayal of the characters were stuck to the surface, never going any deeper or giving something new. Considering how the book was advertised, I was expecting something deeper and more complex than what I got.

Finally, my biggest issue: the different viewpoints. I didn’t have problems following the story through the switching of POV’s. What my issue was the way Kubica used it. I thought the book could’ve been better if she narrowed the number of POV’s and assigning a particular character/POV with either the past or the present. If there wasn’t a lot of switching of POV’s and time flipping, it would’ve made the story move at a faster pace and more efficient in its storytelling. As it was, it created a sort of discombobulated story flow to compound the issue of the story’s pace.

This book was one of those that I would include with the others who didn’t meet my expectations. Perhaps that is my fault, I should know better than to have such thoughts going into a book. But I did and unfortunately, it fell a little short. The core of the story had potential and there were moments that captured my attention, but the execution wasn’t able to keep it for long.

title: Two Stars
text: It wasn't what I expected; the letters were not as interesting as I thought they would be.

title: Just sayin'....
text: This is a cute story for very young children who want to make a Jack-o-lantern. If you use your noodle you can have a great one with no harm to the creative child OR his pumpkin. However, at some point they're going to wonder why their Jack-o-lantern won't light up. This story isn't gonna help at all with that one, Mom and Dad. You'll be on your own then.

Raven Mocker has the same characters which is normally something I like, but i had trouble connecting with them this time.  I found this story hard to imagine, which I didn't have any trouble with Cade's Cove.  Maybe I'm just not into such deep haunted stories.  I like to be able to think maybe it could happen but I just couldn't make that leap with The Raven Mocker.

title: I guess I'm not a dummy
text: Too simplistic to be truly useful.  I only learned two or three things I hadn't already discovered myself after a few days of playing with the phone.  I need a level somewhere between "dummy" and "code writer."

title: I had no idea what I was reading
text: Was this book written by one person? It didn't make any sense, the writing styles kept on changing, and there was no plot or consistency. Maybe I missed the point of the book entirely, but after 30 pages I threw it out.

title: Three Stars
text: It was entertaining although very improvable

title: Different than expected, but good
text:
I'm still not sure what exactly I expected from this book, but either way, it was different than I thought.

I guess I expected that Lizzie would be the main character in this book, and instead, found that Ruth was, so it threw me off a bit. The story doesn't follow historical fact down to the letter, but I appreciated that the author knows how to tell a good story either way.

As a continuation from the first book, I was surprised that it was set in a different location and didn't really go as I would have thought after that book, but it was still interesting and very creative.

Overall, this was a good book, but I was a little dismayed that Lizzie wasn't as important as she could have been. She could have been a nameless main character that wasn't an important character in history and still served the same purpose.

This review is based on a complimentary copy from the publisher and provided through Netgalley. All opinions are my own.

title: Disappointing
text: After reading Patriots, I was enthused.  I even got my wife to read that one, and gave a copy as a gift.  I ordered this story even before it was published.  Boy, Rawles got me!  I'm not sure this is a new book, or just a description of  of some events in other books or notes.  The book gets two stars for spelling, good grammar, and it's perfect recitation of Christian principles.

title: Um, seriously, it is that bad...
text: The Enemies Among Us marks the first volume of Superman/Batman since the departure of writer Jeph Loeb, who was on board since the series' launch.  Enter Mark Verheiden, who takes the reins, and as you can tell by a majority of the other reviews posted here, his take is definitely not for the better.  Superman and Batman find themselves in the middle of a plot involving alien invasions and the Martian Manhunter (or is it?), all of which adds up to making little to no sense, as things wrap up to an incredibly confusing conclusion as well.  Popular supporting characters make appearances as well, for no apparent reason, and amount to nothing.  The only thing that saves The Enemies Among Us from the scrap heap is the great artwork from Ethan Van Sciver (Green Lantern: Rebirth), but other than that, the rest of this is quite forgettable.  All in all, even the most devoted fans of the series may have a hard time swallowing what they get here.

title: Missing a few cards?
text: Beautiful deck however I got some doubles and missing a few cards-- I got two hierophants and no emperor and two knaves of cups and no knight or cups.... really disappointed :(

title: Great start then goes downhill from there
text: It is a page turner in that I read it quickly but the only part I liked was the beginning. The Nanny begins to be less sympathetic and more pathetic as the book continues. She is a doormat to her employer yet you don't feel sorry for her because as the book states numerous times she's white, grandmother has money, parents not as much but still it's not like her visa status or own kids well being depend on keeping her job. The ending was terrible and though I haven't seen the movie I suspect it's probably better than this book. Bridget jones diary this ain't.

title: Plot holes, no logic, dull
text: I’ve read some bad books in my time, but this one takes the cake. The plot holes are so big a semi could disappear into one. Even if I could set logic aside for a couple of hours, the characters’ behaviors and attitudes are so unrealistic and all over the place that it was completely non-believable. The prose itself is dull and unimaginative. I regret wasting my time reading this.

title: One Star
text: took too long to go to the point

title: it's a wonder he lived as long as he did
text:
another book about a heroin addicts woes.....boo hoo.
halfway through the book I quit caring about Mark and the problems he brought on himself, a real loser.

title: Good but...
text: I'm not a food or anthropology expert and the author definitely seems well educated and includes many interesting facts but I must say I was looking for some cross between Andrew Zimmern (Bizarre Foods) and Alton Brown (Good Eats) and what I got seemed heavily slanted to "We should all stop eating meat and feed the world." Not to sound cold hearted but assuming you actually bought this book because you care about feeding the world it should be noted that you will find nothing accept vague notions and catch 22 situations regarding how to go about it. Maybe the topic is too complex to really lay out a plan but it certainly is sickening to read without one after a while.

title: What shadow?
text: This is the third book I read by this author.  It was okay.  I would not consider this book to be modern gothic.  It was not one bit scary.  The author should consider updating the story.  The reviews that were written 15 years ago do not stand up to today's standards of a gothic/ghost story.

title: Mildly interesting, mostly off-topic
text: As someone who has done a considerable amount of taxidermy and preparation/curation of museum specimens, I looked forward to this book as a treatment of the subject from a psychological perspective.  While some historical background is useful, the return to Ackley again and again was annoying, since the author was obviously copying material published elsewhere.  The fact that he didn't even try to make a mount seems hypocritical and his demeaning rationale doesn't ring true.  I most enjoyed the discussions of novelty taxidermy and the preservation of pets.  These areas would seem the best material to use in considering the psychology of people who desire such bizarre creations.  I found it also bizarre that the author would try to write an entire book (with much off-topic filler and repetition) about a subject he claims to be obsessed with, yet doesn't deviate from his position as a somewhat disgusted observer.

title: I enjoyed the book
text: As a microbiologist, I enjoyed the book, especially the description of the science behind the vaccine making. Generally, I thought it became a bit repetitive with the Nazi characters, but found the historical narratives interesting and the scientists remarkable.

title: Beginner photo guide, creative?
text: Judging a book by its title, as we all know, can be a dangerous thing. I was expecting tips and ideas to take my photography to new level. But really this book is about basics - which of course is a good thing - like light, composition, exposure (ISO, aperture, shutter speed). These are all covered in great and better detail in other classic books (like "Understanding Exposure).  The writing it okay, the images are okay (though often too small to judge some more subtle effects). All in all, an okay book, just not the more advanced one I was expecting given the title. Good for a beginner - but there are far better books out there for that.

title: good common sense
text: difficult to understand.

title: Not really into it.
text: Was really disappointed in how all the abbreviations were used throughout the novel in reference to the names of the radical groups.  Maybe I just don't like reading about terrorist cells and what makes them tick.

title: Could have been better.
text: It was just too obvious what the plot was and what the ending was going to be. This author seems to have the same things going on in his books : Lady with troubles, gets in more trouble, meets a man, things don't go so well with man, still having trouble, end of story gets man/ no more troubles.

title: OK --not great
text: nothing added

title: Different, confusing, entertaining in the end
text: It is written in a very different way from most "courtroom thrillers." But it was compelling and interesting, even if I was lost for a chapter at a time about why the protagonist was doing what they were doing. I had to have trust that Grisham would bring us into the overall story sometime in the upcoming pages.

title: Disappointed
text: I have enjoyed all the Tracy Crosswhite Books. This one started out great.  As it got closer to the end, I thought that the ending was going to be a great, quick surprise.  The joke was on me.  There was no ending!  I'm hoping there is more to come to wrap this story up.

title: some sort of grief sandwich
text:
Ariel Levy has not had an easy time of it when she writes this book. My heart went out to her, and I respected her ability to form a sentence, let alone write a book after the loss she's endured.

It's hard to review these things. She does a remarkable job of explaining the loss of her child. It's truly moving. I wish she had stuck to just that event and the relationships formed around that child and the loss. It's so much more important than many of the other things that fill up this book. While her career might be of interest, it doesn't fit here. And while the blurb makes it sound like unimaginable trauma, we learn that basically she lost a child and because she already had a dysfunctional relationship where both had their own issues, shockingly - they can't withstand the stress. Then she loses her house because that's what happens when people get divorced or break up. So while there are bits that really speak, she should have stuck to those and not tried to load it up like some sort of grief sandwich.

When she was sticking to one clearly painful loss, it worked. All of the other pile on topics were why I never felt allowed to fully connect with the author or her pain.
